RISK_STATEMENT: Existing utilities in project area will likely be cut off by floodwalls, box culvert, etc. and will need to be relocated. Need to identify any critical utilities that cannot be impacted and must be designed around. Pending utility survey will help mitigate this risk. Up-to-date utility plans should be requested from providers throughout project duration. One example is the gravity sewer that crosses the Peckman near the Little Falls pump station.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Due to urban nature of site conditions, power, communications, water, and sanitary sewer lines will interfere with or cross proposed features of the Peckman RIver FRM project.
In particular the force main that sends sanitary sewer flows from LIttle Falls township to the Passaic Regional WWTP is currently in conflict with the proposed diversion culvert.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Realignment of sanitary sewer may compromise the operability of the sanitary sewer utility thus requiring additional maintenance expense.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
No schedule delays will be encountered from modification of known, existing utilities.

There may be a risk of encountering unknown existing utilities and this would impact the construction duration; this risk will be addressed separately.

RISK_NAME: Stakeholders may not agree to location of project features
RISK_STATEMENT:
School stakeholder may not accept floodwall between baseball and football fields.
Little Falls Twp may not accept realigning floodwall/levee to permit stormwater storage in current wooded area behind High School (Rose Street Extension)

Township request that access to Peckman River project be reached  via Rose Street extension.  See letter here: R:\Projects\Peckman_River_Feasibility_(NAN Support)\Peckman River PED FY22 Design Mgr\Little Falls Correspondence\Letter to ACOE re Rose Street 9.7.22.pdf.  If USACE does not agree to this plan, possible that township could limit access to DPW facility across river that USACE was planning to use for staging/storage."

Future public meetings may introduce further concerns.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PDT will design project with stakeholder concerns in mind, but environmental, hydraulic, and constructability concerns may cause some stakeholder dissatisfaction with feature type or location.  The paramount objective of the PDT is to maximize the effectiveness of the FRM project as a whole.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Stakeholder concerns regarding type or location of project features should not have an impact on overall project cost.  Some administrative/management expense can be expected to be incurred if the risk materializes.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Risk can be addressed concurrent to design activities and no schedule impact is expected.

RISK_NAME: PED H&H model may require changes in project features
RISK_STATEMENT:
Stormwater flows and water surface elevation outputs from H&H model conducted during PED phase may vary from H&H modelling performed during planning phase that impact project features or existing features outside project limits.
Examples include changes to project features and impacts to existing features outside the project limits (scour at bridge piers; scour at downstream elements; sedimentation at other areas; floodwaters may encroach on bridge superstructure, high water elevation above bridge lower chord elevation, etc.)
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Preliminary H&H model outputs result in some changes in flows and affects to water levels by tying floodwalls into existing ground. (07FEB24)
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Project features will take H&H model outputs into account.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Design costs included analysis and feature revision necessary to address the updated H&H model results.

Construction costs will increase due to increase in length and size of project features.
Construction costs impacts will be defined NLT 35% issuance of CWE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Design Schedule includes time to address these concerns.

RISK_NAME: PED H&H Modeling uncertainty may prompt additional analysis
RISK_STATEMENT: Depending on the certainty of the results of the PED H&H modelling 3D or physical modeling may be required to better understand how critical features (e.g. intake and outfall of diversion culvert) will behave during storm events.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: At this time HH&C does not have evidence that 3D or physical modeling will be necessary, but updated understanding and discussion with external SME(s) is pending.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Results of additional modeling efforts would drive appropriate design analyses.

RISK_STATEMENT: The District has an archaeological monitor under contract to monitor the excavation of two of the borings. Should significant materials or features be identified and it is determined by the archaeological monitor that further investigation of the area is required, the archaeological monitor should inform the Contractor, who should involve the District COR and the District Archaeologist.  The archaeological monitor, the Contractor, the District COR, and the District Archaeologist shall meet to confirm this requirement and determine the level of effort and time anticipated. The District Archaeologist will coordinate this effort with the New Jersey State Historic Preservation Office. Any work related to the need for further archaeological investigation and coordination may cause schedule delays or increased costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is very unlikely that cultural resources will be identified during the excavation of borings.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If unanticipated cultural resources are identified, a modification to the current task order will be required to include additional data recovery investigations. This contract mod is not likely to exceed $100,000 in total.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If required, any data recovery efforts would likely be completed in 20 working days, or roughly one month.

RISK_STATEMENT:
There is always a potential to encounter HTRW-related contamination throughout the planning, design, and construction process of any project.  A limited Phase I Environmental Site Assessment was completed for the proposed alignment in September 2023 which found several Recognized Environmental Concerns; however, the current documentation does not indicate that they pose a significant risk to the project alignment.  The risk will be further characterized with the completion of subsurface chemical sampling during the PED phase.

The risk associated with the presence of HTRW-related contamination along the alignment is primarily associated with the need to revise the alignment design to avoid/minimize impacts from HTRW and/or schedule delays (with associated costs of such delays while pending remedial action at 100% non-federal cost when there is no other practicable solution).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Timely acquisition of permits for construction
RISK_STATEMENT: Permits required to construct project include a NJ Flood Hazard Area Control Act (FHACA) Individual permit and an Individual Freshwater Wetlands (FWW) permit. Per FHACA Rules, DEP must approve/deny application within 90 days of application being deemed administratively complete. There is no such clock with the FWW permit applications. Based on experience with other projects, approval of FWW permits have ranged from 6-9 months. Additionally, U.S. EPA reviews permit applications where impacts to wetlands/open water exceeds five acres which can increase review/approval time.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Experience with other projects in construction.

RISK_STATEMENT: An Environnmental Assessment was prepared during the Feasibility Phase to meet National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) requirements. Should project features or alignment/location  change in a manner that is significantly different than what was authorized, a supplemental NEPA document and re-coordination with various environmental resource agencies (EPA, USFWS) will be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on discussions during the PDT meeting and the level of analysis deferred during the Feasibility Phase to PED due to SMART Planning, the likelihood of potential changes to features and/or alignment are possible.

RISK_NAME: Seasonal construction windows for protected F&W species
RISK_STATEMENT: Seasonal restrictions for direct in-water construction to protect fish species and seasonal restrictions for tree/shrub clearing to protect endangered and threatened bat species and migratory birds.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NJDEP includes conditions restricting construction of in-water work as part of the Flood Hazard Area Control Act permit. Indiana and northern long-eared bat (endangered) and tri-colored bat (proposed endangered) have been identified as potentially occurring within the project area. A seasonal tree clearing restriction from 1 April - 30 September is typically required absent of a survey indicating the absence of these species. USFWS also requires a 15 March through 15 August seasonal tree/shrub clearing restriction to protect migratory bird species. Bald and golden eagle have been identified as potentially occurring within the project area which may result in having to include protection guidelines in construction specifications.

RISK_NAME: Sedimentation or Scour may be accelerated post Construction
RISK_STATEMENT: At entrance and outfall of culvert structure sediment may accumulate at an accelerated rate causing a need for O&M throughout the life of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Site visits indicate significant sediment moving through the Peckman River system.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Sedimentation impacts will be mitigated through design (sediment bypass, etc.), or detailed in anticipated O&M to sponsor.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Sedimentation analysis is ongoing, and was included in original HLE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Sedimentation analysis is ongoing, and was included in original schedule.

RISK_NAME: Passaic stormwater flows may limit outflows of culvert.
RISK_STATEMENT: The Passaic River may be unable to receive stormwater from the diversion culvert in certain conditions, reducing the effectiveness of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Initial H&H assessment indicates likely elevated flows in Passaic at peak flows in Peckman.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: May results in reduced performance of proposed project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: H&H analysis is ongoing, and was included in original HLE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: H&H analysis is ongoing, and was included in original schedule.

RISK_NAME: Passaic RIver stormwater may reverse intended flow of culver
RISK_STATEMENT: Box culvert and related infrastructure must be designed to avoid backflow from Passaic River into Peckman if analysis identifies certain stormwater conditions that this could occur.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Initial H&H indicated this is likely.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Project features will be designed to account for this.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: H&H analysis is ongoing, and was included in original HLE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: H&H analysis is ongoing, and was included in original schedule.

RISK_NAME: Classification of Weir #1 as a Dam
RISK_STATEMENT: Possible changes to design if weir needs to be formally designed as dam. Currently not considered to be a dam, see meeting notes here: R:\Projects\Peckman_River_Feasibility_(NAN Support)\Peckman River PED FY22 Design Mgr\Dam vs Weir\Peckman_MFR_NJDEP Weir Meeting 26Nov2019_Final.pdf
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: To be determined depending on ongoing H&H analysis/modeling and any resulting updates to weir parameters, if required. PDT currently assumes that weir design will ultimately be consistent with NAN/NAD's position as articulated in above-referenced meeting minutes from 26 Nov 2019, and will "not qualify as a dam according to Corps standards (e.g. ER 1110-2-1516)."
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: PDT assumes that design would be functionally and hydraulically similar, whether designed as weir or dam, and that project performance would be comparable.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[Input from H&H required; preliminary response:] If weir is required to be redesigned as a dam, assumption is that design will be accomplished within existing PED budget. Dam design, if required, might be more robust than current weir design and therefore entail higher construction cost.

[Placeholder cost impact of $100k added]
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PDT assumes that design and construction of dam could be accomplished within timeline currently estimated for design and construction of weir. Additional permitting would likely be required (including approvals from NJDEP), but PDT assumes this permitting effort could be accomplished within current schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: Per current Google Earth layout, box culvert runs very close to building at 75 Harrison St and houses on Willow Ave. May need add'l real estate. How wide of ROW is needed beyond actual culvert? Possible to construct w/o demolishing ex bldgs? If so, monitoring of ex buildings should be implemented.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: [DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: Based on current design, edge of culvert's stone bedding is approx. 20 ft from edge of warehouse building to south and approx. 8 ft from residential patios to north. Design of project should carefully consider these existing features, including understanding constructability of culvert while minimizing disruption or damage to existing features. Input will also be needed from Real Estate regarding ROW that will be required for culvert, and how this relates to existing property boundaries.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: PDT goal will be to meet design constraints without sacrificing project functionality.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: Depending on final design, construction cost impacts could result, including from: need for extensive shoring, protection/reconstruction of existing structures, vibration monitoring, etc.

[need to add cost impact value; $500k added as placeholder]
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: No issues anticipated re: completing design within allotted schedule. Potential construction schedule impacts could include having to adapt to unforeseen conditions resulting from proximity to buildings (e.g. vibration monitoring indicating impacts to existing structures that are intended to remain, causing the construction team to have to adapt and change means & methods).

[need to add schedule impact value; 60 days added as placeholder]

RISK_NAME: BMP Construction to satisfy PCSM reqmts for adj landowners
RISK_STATEMENT: Floodwall at car dealership (Rt 46 Chrysler Jeep Dodge) goes through what appears to be a stormwater management basin. Needs to be confirmed. Might need to be reconstructed somewhere else on site, which may trigger NPDES and other permitting
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: Review of publicly available data (including databases of active NJDEP permits for stormwater management during construction, regulated facilities, etc.) did not yield any records of permitted stormwater management basins on the above-referenced site. 

No stormwater management features are visible in aerial images of adjacent parcels to the east along Rt 46, therefore it is unclear whether this feature is actually a stormwater management BMP.

The preliminary topographic survey used for the feasibility study drawings labels this area as "RUIN". However, review of historic aerial images (inc. from historicaerials.com/viewer) indicate that this area of the site was originally cleared between 1995 and 2002, and no building appears to have existed there.

Feature may be a simple depression that is not designed to meet stormwater management regulations. To be reviewed further during site visit in the coming months.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Any reconstruction of BMPs would be designed in such a way as to avoid impacting the functionality of the FRM project features.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: If stormwater BMPs are required to be reconstructed as part of project, additional effort would be required to design stormwater features which would need to comply with the current NJDEP Stormwater Management Rule. Additional construction costs would be incurred to build these features.

[need to add cost impact value; $200k added as placeholder]
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: If stormwater BMPs need to be reconstructed, additional time may be required in the schedule to accommodate the design, permitting, and construction of these features (depending on scope and scale of required BMPs). 

[need to add schedule impact value; 90 days added as placeholder]

RISK_STATEMENT: Additional flood risk management infrastructure beyond that identified during the planning phase may be necessary to accommodate interior drainage flooding for levees/floodwalls. FRM project features may cut off existing drainage paths, and provision must be made for drainage in such areas to prevent ponding and related damaged on adjacent parcels.

COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: If FRM features cut off existing drainage patterns, additional design and construction will be necessary to mitigate resulting ponding. Solutions could include regrading, installing drainage infrastructure, etc.

[need to add cost impact value; $100k added as placeholder, assuming some drainage features need to be designed and installed]
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: Intent would be to capture drainage design within allotted design schedule. Additional time might be required within construction schedule to construct additional drainage features.

RISK_NAME: Flood Conditions in Peckman/Passaic during construction
RISK_STATEMENT: Contractor means/methods will need to account for possibility of flood conditions disrupting construction and damaging work already installed.  Design documents should make bidders aware of this risk and provide mechanism (work plan) for government to review how risk will be addressed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Storms will occur during the construction of the project, methods of diversion of channel flows will be necessary to permit project progress.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Specification language will have to be devised to explain requirements to contractor.
Relatively small, regular storm events will be required to be bypassed.
Storms of some larger as yet undetermined size may require shutdown/protection of works.
Spec language can reference storms of a certain size or NWS gauge data.

IGE will need to account for the cost of these measures.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Adverse weather clause will need to incorporate 10 years of climate data for Little Falls, similar exercise to that performed for LEAD S&R.

RISK_NAME: Constructability of Floodwall between playing fields
RISK_STATEMENT: Tight access between the playing fields at the high school was documented during the 2023 site visit, and there is a question of whether the current design of floodwalls/levees is constructable. This could lead to a design change if it is deemed the current design is not constructable.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
[DRAFT INFORMATION, TO BE AMENDED BY PDT]: Likelihood of constructability issues to be further assessed by PDT once full survey information is received. 

In addition to potential constructability issues, PDT understands that USACE has received requests not to run floodwall/levee between playing fields.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: PDT is not aware of performance impacts that could result from realignment of project features.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PDT is not aware of cost impacts at this time; total length of project features would likely be similar if realigned.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PDT is not aware of schedule impacts at this time.

RISK_STATEMENT: Jeep dealership access.  They are already concerned about performing borings and environmental testing on their property, how will they be with the proposed floodwalls being built?
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT:
There exists an opportunity to optimize the culvert as it is currently conceived; a cast in place reinforce concrete structure to ensure minimum concrete structure for required flow channel (arched roofs, minimized columns, etc).

It is also possible additionally optimize the structure to facilitate offsite construction to reduce time and constructability risks. (precasting of culvert elements is a possibility).

Alternate methods of conveying the flow should also be investigated.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PDT will investigate and adopt feasible opportunities identified.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Costs will be reduced to an extent to be determined by 65%.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This activity is included in the current design schedule.

RISK_NAME: Designing for Climate Change Effects on Rainfall
RISK_STATEMENT:
NJDEP has done a study recently which determined that future rainfall is projected to be higher than current. Current USACE guidance accounts for sea level rise but not for changes in rainfall. Question moving forward is - how do we want to address the rainfall study.  https://dep.nj.gov/wp-content/uploads/dsr/nj-rainfall-studies-summary.pdf
We realized this is something that should be addressed with the appropriate stakeholders as soon as possible since it could change design parameters (more rainfall = more runoff).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: We?ve requested from the contractor a schedule for the SSX task order.  We have yet to receive the schedule and contractor has noted a final schedule can?t be provided until all permits are obtained. If permits take longer than expected to be granted it can impact the SSX final report deadline.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_NAME: Real Estate Impacts to Private Lands
RISK_STATEMENT: Significant schedule delays or even study termination as a result of no RE solution that allows ownership retainment of properties. The project cannot impact certain properties (Change hydroperiod, stage, duration) through WERP Implementation. We are considering flowage easements (nonstandard for ecosystem restoration) instead of fee for some properties.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Project was almost terminated in 2019 as a result of significant RE issues and negative public feedback.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If unresolved, project will lose support from stakeholders.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate cost to address additional study performance questions.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Current standards are narrative, not numeric. FDEP developing. Need details form SFWMD on implementation of source controls to reduce Total Phosphorus. More information needed (precisely how much phosphorus to be reduced) to achieve project objectives.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Currently, current standards are qualitative, not quantitative and there is a reliance on non-Federal sponsor to address WQ in West-Feeder Basin.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: May result in lack of information and resources to fully address any potential stakeholders' questions.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate cost to address additional study performance questions.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate time to address additional study performance questions.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_NAME: Aggressive Schedule to a Chief's Report
RISK_STATEMENT: The Draft Report is scheduled to be released in October for concurrent review. Completing a Chief's Report by 31 May 2024 to meet WRDA 2024 is extremely aggressive. This schedule assumes compressed review times that may be difficult to achieve.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Leadership guidance is to meet aforementioned schedule and we do not know the availability of reviewers to meet the compressed review timelines.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The non-Federal sponsor, the Tribes, many other stakeholders and USACE leadership all want the Chief's Report in time for WRDA 2024. If proposed deadline is missed, stakeholders will have the perception USACE has failed, and relationships will be damaged.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_NAME: Optimization: Reduce or Eliminate Real Estate Effects
RISK_STATEMENT: Initial modeling showed induced off-site impacts. The locations are not areas where we will claim ecosystem benefits. Refinement may not reduce RE effects enough to move forward with alternative.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Optimizing the alternative is expected to reduce off-site impacts.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost is for modeling the optimized alternatives followed by post-processing and interpreting the results.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The estimated days are short because this alternative was already modeled and only small changes to structures were expected to be sufficient to avoid off-site impacts.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT:
Team made assumption during plan formulation to propose STAs that included the portion of treatment that SFWMD is responsible for with the portion to treatment that is needed for restoration.  DMSTA model was used to size the STAs to treat to 13 ppb phosphorus.  This represents a numeric interpretation of the narrative standard developed by FDEP.  The state portion of the STAs would treat to 36 ppb. The team decided to pursue one joint STA based on the interpretation of the 2007 Woodley Memo. 
Risk associated with a joint STA is that the Vertical Team may not agree with interpretation of Woodley Memo that full construction can be cost shared, with OMRR&R being 100% non-federal to 36 ppb and then 50/50 cost share from 36 to 13 ppb.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
It is likely that support for construction at 50/50 cost share will likely drive a need for a cost share policy decision to be made by ASA(CW). O&M cost share discussions are likely to be determined by a policy determination, as well. 

Risk consequence is lack of project support. One example is a different interpretation applied to the EAA project in 2019, although that project was subject to the Consent Decree and had a different source of water.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Two WQ cost share white papers were shared with Vertical Team in Spring 2022. WQ Tiger Team Meetings held August to December 2022. Two Issue Resolution Conferences held December 2022. No solution reached. Additional coordination required.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time needed to reach policy position on the STAs. HQ Direction is to maintain schedule to make WRDA 24, prepare Draft PIR/EIS with existing assumption; resolution of cost sharing will continue to be pursued.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: RSM-GL cells size for WERP are about 600 acres. High uncertainty could result in a conservative (high) cost estimate for the real estate analysis (needed to satisfy Savings Clause and ensure features are included in cost estimates), or tribal opposition to the project which may ultimately extend the study schedule during review and/or may result in the need to re-study the project via a PACR prior to PED in order to accurately assess water supply and flood risk impacts and update features/costs if required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are opportunities to refine the plan and design during the study and also during PED for minor changes. However, this risk has been considered early in plan formulation to prevent choosing a TSP that would be too hard to adjust in PED while maintaining benefits (such as a TSP that focuses fully on backfilling versus operable structures).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Significant time and cost increases during PED. Previous CERP projects such as Broward County WPA, IRL South have had challenges in PED with Savings Clause/Assurances that originated from modeling uncertainties during PIR phase resulting in significant time and cost increases during PED.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate time to address additional study performance questions.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: If unknown cultural resources are discovered, higher cost and schedule delays during PED phase: further investigations and/or major delays in construction to avoid impacting cultural resources that were not known in the study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Since two Tribal Reservations exist within our study area, we have a high likelihood of having cultural resources in the region that we could overlook during plan formulation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If unknown cultural resources are discovered, study delays and cost increase to be expected.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If unknown cultural resources are discovered, study delays and cost increase to be expected.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Discovering burial resources during PED would require redesign and have an impact on Tribal trust.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Likelihood is significant due to the location of two Tribal Reservations in the area and long history of Tribal use of the study area. Consequence is high due to expense and delays associated with redesign in PED and the effects of loss of trust.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If new burial resources are discovered, study delays and cost increase to be expected.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If new burial resources are discovered, study delays and cost increase to be expected.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: 3x3x3 Exception approval for additional budget and time is needed to avoid running out of funds to respond to comments on the Draft report and prepare the final report. Approval level is ASA(CW).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: 3x3x3 Exception Requests often take a long time to approve. Additional budget/funds needed more quickly than normal coordination times.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Within the aggressive timeframe given to produce Draft Report, Class Three (3) Cost Estimate may not be fully developed. However, the planning process typically allows for additional information to be gained between Draft and Final Report so ultimately Class 3 Cost Estimate will be thorough, and the performance of the project is not expected to be jeopardized.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is possible Class 3 Cost Estimate will not be fully developed before Draft Report under the aggressive schedule aimed at meeting WRDA 2024.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is a best practice to have all necessary cost engineering estimates early, however if additional information is gained between Draft and Final Report and Class 3 Cost Estimate is adjusted the overall project performance will not be impacted.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impact of additional coordination necessary to meet goals (project objectives, schedule, etc.), including all necessary components including cost engineering requirements.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Phasing DQC/TRB review, Counsel review, followed by 508/technical of draft report by 20 Oct 2023. Phased approach, instead of sequential, has been identified as method of conducting reviews in order to meet WRDA 2024. Risk lies in schedule delays leading to missing milestone.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Phased approach was identified as a means to reduce duration of reviews.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If WRDA 2024 is missed, project benefits will be delayed (performance impact).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: With additional review time, labor costs increase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: 2-year schedule delay if WRDA 2024 is missed.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Team members may want to take leave during December (multiple holidays, "use or lose" leave stipulations, etc.), putting meeting proposed schedule at risk.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While it's likely people will take leave in December, it is unlikely to derail WERP objectives because activities scheduled during the last week of December will be avoided and contingencies are being built into schedule where possible.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: With normal planning-ahead, performance of project should not be impacted.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional coordination / possible overtime required to meet proposed schedule.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacted if team members who are expected to be available over December holidays aren't / work slows to an unacceptable pace.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_NAME: North Feeder Storm Water Treatment Area
RISK_STATEMENT: Risk lies in the acceptance of the effectiveness of the proposed NFSTA within Corps internal review chain. If NFSTA isn't accepted, cost/schedule delays, required redesign, and/or potential that project may not move forward remain possibilities.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The potential that the NFSTA isn't accepted by all involved parties remains.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If proposed NFSTA isn't accepted for inclusion in TSP, project performance is unknown as another alternative would be required to address WQ, environmental and stakeholder concerns to meet WERP objectives.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost reflects potential redesign required to achieve WERP benefits if NFSTA isn't accepted for inclusion in TSP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If risk is realized, team may miss WRDA 2024 milestones.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_NAME: Feasibility of Natural Connection in the Western Feeder
RISK_STATEMENT: Wingate Mill (WF area) had an STA but it has been removed and replaced by a more natural connection. FDEP is developing planning targets as a result of the change. If the new feature isn't feasible / doesn't function as expected and / or the involved Stakeholders don't accept the proposed feature, WERP objectives / deadlines may be jeopardized.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Involved parties are optimistic proposed natural connection will function as expected and a) meet WQ goals; b) be accepted by Stakeholders; c) be restorative of the natural sheet flow historically found in this area.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If proposed natural connection isn't feasible, major impact to project performance as cost/schedule delays would follow.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If risk is realized and proposed natural connection isn't feasible, a redesign of feature may be required to meet WERP objectives.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If risk is realized, two-year schedule impact is possible as meeting WRDA 2024 would require project to not deviate from schedule at all and all features function as expected.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Implementation of the Programmatic Agreement - The USACE has worked with the Signatories to develop the Programmatic Agreement to accommodate concerns with the approach/methodology on Tribal lands. The PA is unique, and it has been developed hand-in-hand with the Signatories.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Extensive coordination has taken place with the Signatories.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: PA is needed to implement the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Although not cost impacts, not signing the PA will result in delaying implementation of the project.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It might delay the project up to 6 months if PA is not signed.

PROJECT_NAME: Fairfield & New Haven Counties, CT Flooding
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a risk of unknown or incorrectly located utilities interfering with flood protection system construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is unlikely that there is a completely unknown utility but there is a likelihood that a known utility is in an unexpected location, differing from record drawings.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Lowest cost would be to install the flood protection system with minor deviation from original design.
Highest impact would be a substantial impact to the design requiring design work.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Redesign and construction change could be completed in a day or may take up to a month of dialogue.

PROJECT_NAME: Fairfield & New Haven Counties, CT Flooding
RISK_STATEMENT: The end locations of the floodwall were never well defined during the feasibility study and initial LIDAR mapping data does show existing elevations of +15 NAVD88 within the project limits but not in great excess. There is possible conflict with the highway embankment as being the local high ground.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that high ground is limited locally around each end point of the floodwall. The city has indicated they plan to construct an access road to the proposed pump station which could provide the required elevation; discussions on highway embankment usage are planned.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: A longer than expected floodwall may be required in order to obtain the necessary high ground of +15 NAVD88 and provide complete protection to the long wharf area.

RISK_STATEMENT: Relying on older seagrass surveys in the feasibility study phase increases the risk of duplicating mitigation efforts and inaccurately estimating mitigation costs, potentially diminishing confidence from environmental agencies. UPDATE: The proposed 3x3x3 exception for seagrass surveys aims to significantly mitigate this risk by allowing for more current, detailed studies, thereby reducing risk likelihood.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The ephemeral nature of seagrass beds and the typical "expiration date" of seagrass surveys. The changing conditions of seagrass over time make outdated data increasingly unreliable. However, with 3x3x3 Exception approval, additional seagrass surveys will be conducted, and a more accurate picture of seagrass habitat would be developed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If risk occurs, the project's credibility could be undermined, leading to reduced confidence from environmental agencies and stakeholders. This loss in confidence may complicate future permit acquisitions and could impact the overall success of the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If this risk materializes, there could be an overestimation of mitigation costs. This has the potential to allocate unnecessary resources and funds, leading to a financial impact that could have been avoided with updated surveys.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Relying on outdated seagrass surveys could lead to delays in the project timeline due to possible re-evaluation or re-surveying needs. This would disrupt the planned project execution and may necessitate changes in the schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: The existing ODMDS (Ocean Dredged Material Disposal Site) may be insufficient in size and placement to handle material from potential navigation improvements, especially if these exceed 15 million cubic yards. There's a concern that material from Phase 3 might shift the sediment, affecting the ODMDS's effectiveness. UPDATE: Exception approval would allocate time and funds to properly evaluate and potentially expand the ODMDS, effectively reducing the risk level from medium to low.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Prior to the exception being considered, the risk was labeled as medium since the ODMDS seemed to have enough capacity for the project, but uncertainties remained. Coordination with EPA is underway, lowering the risk likelihood further.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: An insufficient ODMDS could lead to ineffective sediment disposal, drawing concern from EPA and potentially causing environmental issues. This could hamper the projects overall performance and regulatory standing.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the ODMDS is found to be insufficient and requires modification, the project could face additional costs related to expanding and permitting the disposal site. This financial impact, however, has been accounted for in the 3x3x3 exception package.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A delay in approving or modifying the ODMDS could hold up the Chief's Report and the overall project timeline, especially if early coordination with EPA doesn't yield prompt agreement on necessary modifications.

RISK_STATEMENT: The primary method for scoping dredging, which involves blasting and mechanical means, poses a high/medium risk due to potential environmental impacts and unanticipated mitigation costs. UPDATE: The risk has decreased from high to medium/low as of August 2020 due to a reduction in the anticipated number of blasts and a new interpretation by the NMFS allowing one blast per day, regardless of calculated level B take. The 3x3x3 exception waiver allows for additional time and funds to make a more refined determination on the number of blasts required, although it doesn't completely eliminate the risk as additional core borings were not included.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Risk decreasing due to a) 3x3x3 exception request will allow more time/funds to evaluate current core borings to better inform the team whether 1,000 blasts will meet the minimum threshold; b) with more time, a more refined determination on blasts expected; c) reduction in the number of blasts anticipated to be needed to accomplish the work; d) new interpretation made by NMFS that we will be allowed to blast once per day regardless of the calculated level B take.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Realization of this risk could lead to legal and regulatory complications and could compromise the project's environmental standing. The project might also face public scrutiny and could suffer in terms of its overall reputation for safety and environmental stewardship.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the risk is realized, there could be greater-than-anticipated environmental impacts that may require additional mitigation efforts. These efforts could potentially exceed the appropriated construction funds, leading to financial overruns.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional coordination and mitigation actions could cause project delays, especially if legal concerns arise due to environmental impacts. The waiver provides some relief but does not remove all risks.

RISK_STATEMENT: Future Turbidity Restrictions (lower thresholds than present) in project area. FDEP is in the process of developing a water quality standard for turbidity specific to areas with coral and hardbottom habitats. Expected to be less than the existing 29 NTU above background and would affect this future study/project since hard bottoms surround the project area, limiting construction methodologies to those that generate less turbidity or may result in more frequent shutdowns during construction in order to meet the new standards and increase in costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: FDEP has been working on new standards for several years. No timeframe for announcement of new standards has been shared.  Once FDEP makes an internal decision, they would still have to go through their formal rule making process.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If turbidity restrictions/thresholds are established, elements of the project, especially in the construction phase, may incur increased cost and schedule delays. However, a 3x3x3 Exception will allow additional time/money during the waiver period to coordinate with FDEP and investigate turbidity control items such as bubble curtains and open-ocean boom effectiveness, which are included in the waiver and drive down risk of future operation shutdowns (cost) and environmental impacts of plumes which would shift risk to low.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Increased cost associated with alternative construction methodologies generating less turbidity, as well as more frequent shutdowns.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Could take longer to dredge due to weather, sea conditions and shutdowns.

RISK_STATEMENT: Consultation with THPO and SHPO indicates high probability of sites containing cultural resources within project footprint. Recent surveys identified two new sites within Paradise Run. Further phase 1 surveys in PED may identify additional NRHP eligible sites. If a NRHP eligible site is found within the project footprint, the footprint would need to be adjusted or the site would need to be mitigated. The consequence is the additional labor of a recommended plan re-design or a changed project footprint, potentially resulting in a loss of storage and reduced project benefits. If National Register of Historic Places eligible sites are encountered and cannot be avoided or effects cannot be minimized, mitigation costs may apply. If a site is encountered and not avoided, the project could further loose support from the tribes. This could result PED schedule delays causing and increase cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on cultural resources surveys and consultation, there are likely to be NRHP eligible sites within the project footprint.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Although there is a possibility of cost increase and/or schedule delay it is not expected that the discovery of unknown cultural resources would impact the performance of the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Comparison to similar projects: Another CERP project, the C-23 reservoir, is currently re-designing the reservoir due to unanticipated cultural resources discoveries. Broward County WPA spent millions of dollars redesigning the footprint and create ring levees to avoid burial sites. Impacts to cultural sites is a major concern of the Seminole Tribe of Florida as indicated in numerous letters to USACE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If unknown cultural resources are discovered, study delays and cost increase to be expected.

RISK_NAME: Real Estate Cost and Availability: Uncertainty
RISK_STATEMENT: Recommended plan requires acquisition of large tracts of land within the project area. There is significant uncertainty regarding whether the required land will be developed prior to project implementation, how many willing sellers will there be, and how the estimated costs will change. These uncertainties may have significant impacts on projected project cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Prior project experience.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: As a result of the removal of the WAF and 25-colocated ASRs from the Recommended Plan, areas of land to be acquired was reduced. However, risk is still considered medium.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential for re-design (increases cost) in addition to rising prices of RE in the area.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential for re-design (schedule delay) to be required to balance rising cost.

RISK_STATEMENT: Delays in the approval of an additional 3x3x3 exception request for the project will lead to missing authorization of the study in time for WRDA 2024 appropriations.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: 3x3x3 Exception Requests often take a long time to approve. Additional budget/funds needed more quickly than under normal coordination times. However, the Team has been directed to meet WRDA 2024, therefore it is expected exception will be received in a timely manner.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.

RISK_STATEMENT: The possibility of a study cost increase beyond ongoing 3x3x3 exception budget request of $1.06M would require additional funding to complete Chief's Report (i.e., a subsequent 3x3x3 exception).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: 3x3x3 Exception Requests often take a long time to approve. Additional budget/funds needed more quickly than normal coordination times.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If additional funding is not available, study team will be forced to stop, resulting in delays in the schedule. Any stop of work increases the risk that the Chief's Report will not be ready for signature by 31 May 2024.

RISK_NAME: Time to Complete Multitude of Complex Comment Responses
RISK_STATEMENT: Possible study cost increase and schedule delays due to additional coordination needed to close comments.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The complexity of this study is due to attempts to incorporate novel scientific methods and in doing so many comments have been received from the public requiring additional attention than in more typical studies.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is an obligation to engage with the public and give thorough responses to their comments. Although there are many/complex comments, it is not expected that the performance of the project will be compromised.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Multiple and/or complex comments received during reviews may require additional time and attention possibly increasing cost.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Multiple and/or complex comments received during reviews may require additional time and attention possibly delaying schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: C&SF: CERP: Western Everglades Restoration Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Study area includes two reservations of federally recognized Tribes (Seminole Tribe of Florida & Miccosukee Tribe of Indians) and their cooperation and acceptance are crucial to accomplish the goals and objectives of WERP.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Event likelihood is low because the WERP team has been actively engaged with the Tribes and frequently requesting feedback. TSP was conceptualized in coordination with the whole PDT, including the Tribes, NFS and stakeholders.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: One of the Tribes will not provide information outside of the G2G meetings and therefore anything other than having frequent meetings with the tribe would limit our ability to work with them on this study. Loss of Tribal support, and diminished relationships/trust would hinder efforts to implement WERP objectives.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Tribal involvement needed because we need to flow water across their Reservations to accomplish restoration throughout the study area. The evidence for the time and cost for the additional G2G coordination is based on tracking the resources needed in the first 4 months of conducting this level of G2G coordination in WERP (Nov 2016 - Feb 2017, 3 months -cumulative- and $200K).

RISK_STATEMENT: Choosing ATHOS as the design vessel for ship simulations in the 9.5-11.4K TEU range poses the risk that its dimensions may not accurately represent the most common world fleet beam for that TEU size from an economic perspective. Consequently, if a 14K vessel doesn't fit within that footprint, a separate ship simulation may be required to assess the feasibility of accommodating such larger vessels, even with restrictions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: ATHOS was selected for its intermediate footprint between Susan Maersk and Daniela, not for being representative of the common world fleet in the given TEU range. There is a moderate to high likelihood that another simulation will be necessary to analyze the restrictions and feasibility for the 14K TEU size, which could be more economically relevant.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the risk is realized, project performance could be compromised due to inaccurate data from the initial ATHOS simulation, leading to flawed decision-making. This could necessitate costly and time-consuming adjustments later in the project, ultimately affecting its success and ROI (Return on Investment).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Conducting another ship simulation for a more representative or larger vessel will incur additional expenses, ranging from data collection to simulation execution and analysis.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The need to perform another simulation will extend the project timeline, causing delays that could impact downstream activities and decision-making processes.

RISK_STATEMENT: ASA guidance Jan 2021 is to look at all four benefit accounts. There is currently no implementation guidance on how to do this, and many questions still unanswered. Deeper understanding needed to better understand how the four accounts could play into the final TSP.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: The risk centers on the delay in receiving exception approval from SAD/HQ/ASA, which has a cascading effect on the project's timeline and costs. If not approved by September 2021, the process would push back the availability of exception funds to March 2022 at the earliest, causing a potential 12-month delay in the study. This is critical because environmental surveys, especially those related to seagrass, must be conducted in the summer and require four months of preparation post-ASA approval. The delay could also result in increased project costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The delay in obtaining exception approval poses a significant risk to the overall project performance. While options like expediting the FCSA approval process have been explored and deemed unfeasible, the team is evaluating existing funds to determine which environmental contracts can be supported. Suboptimal allocation of resources could compromise the quality or comprehensiveness of the environmental studies, particularly the ESA/Benthic Recon Survey.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The inability to secure exception funds in a timely manner is likely to lead to increased project costs. High-cost items like the ESA/Benthic Recon Survey may need to be postponed, potentially resulting in escalated costs due to rescheduling, inflation, or missed opportunities to conduct surveys during optimal conditions.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the exception approval and subsequent funding are not processed by the critical September 2021 deadline, the project faces a possible 12-month delay. This is especially true for time-sensitive elements like the seagrass survey, which can only be conducted during the summer growing season. Existing funds are being assessed to see if they can cover essential tasks, but any workaround will still entail schedule adjustments and potential delays.

RISK_STATEMENT: Exception was for $4.48 million and 41 months and was developed to accomplish study completion with the intention that an additional exception would not be required. Recent WRDA 2020 Section 360 stipulates that the ASA cannot grant exceptions greater than three (3) years, therefore there is now a high risk of another exception and the cost/time delays to get it approved. Possible study termination, cost increases, and study delays if an additional exception cannot be granted.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: WRDA 2020 stipulated ASA can only grant exceptions 3 years at a time.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Termination or incomplete study if funds evaporate after TSP when PDT is writing the draft report.

RISK_STATEMENT: Miami environmental surveys are planned for Summer 2022, but there is a risk that Port Everglades surveys may be conducted around the same period, thus creating a labor shortage and increase in competition within SFL - resulting in substantial cost increases for the labor associated with surveying. Additionally, exception costs were developed in June 2020 and the pandemic supply chain may affect amount and cost of surveys.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Example; Broward County Project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If surveys are being conducted simultaneously in SFL cost may increase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Delays are possible if survey demand increases creating labor shortage.

RISK_STATEMENT: A modification report to the previous project (Phase 3) has been introduced by PM/NFS. Inner Harbor depth is under-utilized; design vessel from Phase 3 cannot fully load in the Inner harbor because of the inadequate depth in Outer harbor (Cut 1 and 2). If the modification is deemed viable, it may have the potential to affect the benefits of the current study by changing the FWOP condition. Risk to reduce benefits and effect study BCR (deepening/adding under keel clearance (UKC) of Cut 1 and 2 of the Outer Channel may affect FWOP of study, potential to reduce study benefits. Initial ROM estimate of possible loss of benefits being 25% (per DDN-PCX)). A BCR of 1.6 was estimated in 2020, which has the potential to be reduced, should modification be initiated without full analyzation of projected effects.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PDT, DDN-PCX, SAD, and HW are working together to analyze the likelihood and effects of proposed modification.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional analysis of proposed modification and coordination may increase study cost.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule delays are possible as modification is analyzed.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: Exemption Plan risks: Public Opposition & USACE policies.
RISK_STATEMENT: Public Risk: -Public opposition to NS only alternative in favor of structural alternative. -NS only alternative implementation is voluntary and has historically very low participation rates for the area for similar programs. USACE Risk: -NED analysis limited to cost update only of Dam and 25YR NS, with limited assessment of acceptability and technical criteria-Limited EJ evaluation that may not address all of EPA's request.-Limited sub-aggregation of NS plan. -Limited Comprehensive benefits assessment. -LPP waiver approval-Since the NS plan is voluntary, will the plan demonstrate that the disadvantage communities/population can be accommodated i.e.. a) since they are likely to be unable to accept that burden for temporary relocation b) If structures are valued less than the cost of elevation, how is USACE accommodating?
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: -Support comes from the public that represents the owners of approximately 36,000 structures that would receive benefits from the Darlington Dam structure alternative vs. the approximately 300 structures in the footprint of the dam.-NEPA letter submitted on 2/20/20 requesting EJ outreach and survey. -Historically difficult to document inclusivity in implemented nonstructural plans'-Presently the study does not have technical conclusion that Presently the study does not have technical conclusion that the Darlington dam alternative is not feasible.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
An additional exemption request is currently being prepared to incorporate the time assumption length needed in case of NED waiver.

Can not estimate project performance impact if NFS no longer concurs with a NS only plan due to the public opposition.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time; however, an additional exemption request is currently being prepared that would include the NED waiver time estimate (of 4 months) based on MVD provided assumptions to include.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: NFS will not agree to Nonstructural Plan.
RISK_STATEMENT: NFS will not agree to USACE Plan.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Confirmation of the Non-Federal Sponsor?s support for the TSP (Darlington Dam) was necessary to proceed with USACE Headquarters' approval for the exemption request in February 2021. At that time, the Governor of Louisiana expressed concerns regarding the potential impacts of the recommended plan, including impacts to Environmental Justice communities within the footprint of the Darlington Dry Dam. On May 29, 2021, a request was received from the State of Louisiana Office of the Governor requesting that CEMVN provide additional protection for citizens and to align objectives to proceed with 25-year nonstructural only plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Study will be terminated and have a restart.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: Exceeded approved timeline for the study
RISK_STATEMENT: With the study?s  extended timeline having ended on July 3, 2024, an request for additional time a is necessary for addressing ATR and policy and legal review comments on the Recommended Plan.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This  study, is funded through the Bipartisan Budget Act of 2018 (BBA 2018). The current exemption timeline for the study expires on 7/3/24.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The  study?s approved  timeline  has already been surpassed  on July 3, 2024.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: NFS will not agree to all NFS responsibilities
RISK_STATEMENT: NFS will not agree to all NFS responsibilities identified in the implementation and Real Estate Plan.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The state of Louisiana through NFS CPRA has committed to their obligations on several other large nonstructural projects in Louisiana with USACE.  Refinements to the NFS are continuously being worked on as the NS implementation is being implemented on those projects.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: No way to be able to calculate.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: High adverse disproportionate impact to EJ Communities.
RISK_STATEMENT:
There is a potential for high and adverse disproportionate impacts to minority and/or low-income with implementation of nonstructural.

USACE needs to be compliant with: 1) Executive Order 12898 of February 11, 1994
Federal Actions To Address Environmental Justice in Minority Populations and Low-Income Populations, 2) EO 14008 of January 2021 including the Justice40 Initiative and Sec. 219: Securing Environmental Justice and Spurring Economic Opportunity and 3) EO 13985, ?Advancing Racial Equity and Support for Underserved Communities Through the Federal Government.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Six of the 12 parishes or counties in the study area, have a significant (>50%) minority population and four of the 12 parishes/counties in the study have 20 percent or more of individuals living below poverty.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_NAME: Individual Structures  not confirmed until PED for nepa
RISK_STATEMENT: Because the actual structures in the plan will not be determined until PED, conducting field investigations to identify threatened and endangered (T&E) species, including identifying the presence/absence of species, Fish and Wildlife Coordination, Preparing draft and final Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act Report, and conducting T&E Coordination will be deferred to PED.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Although possible, it is unlikely that significant T&E populations will be identified in developed properties eligible for nonstructural measures.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule and Cost of Implementation: Coordination with resource agencies may  delay implementation schedules. The potential for unrealized mitigation costs exists following the issuance of a ROD and the obligation of construction funds.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_STATEMENT: Because the actual structures in the plan will not be determined until PED, conducting field investigations to identify HTRW, including identifying the presence/absence of HTRW, will be deferred to PED.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Because the actual structures in the plan will not be determined until PED, conducting field investigations to identify HTRW, including identifying the presence/absence of HTRW, will be deferred to PED.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The USACE/NFS will be unable to screen properties for HTRW prior to the obligation of construction funds for the project. Phase II HTRW assessments and/or mitigation on the part of the NFS/Landowner could be lengthy and delay implementation schedules and ultimately lead to properties being dropped from further consideration for nonstructural measures.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Schedule of Implementation: Phase 1 Site Assessment for HTRW is cost shared by the USACE and NFS and the Phase II and mitigation is paid by the NFS or land owner. Coordination with the NFS and landowners during Phase II HTRW assessment and/or mitigation may delay implementation schedules. 
The USACE/NFS will be unable to screen properties for HTRW prior to the obligation of construction funds for the project. Phase II HTRW assessments and/or mitigation on the part of the NFS/Landowner could be lengthy and delay implementation schedules and ultimately lead to properties being dropped from further consideration for nonstructural measures.

PROJECT_NAME: Amite River and Tributaries - East of the MS River Analysis
RISK_STATEMENT: NED Plan was misidentified and lack of Nonfederal interest without a plan in these cases.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Concerns were raised by  USACE and NFS that in some cases the cost of raising the structure is much greater than buyout or a total rebuild of the structure.
