COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate cost for field data collection.

RISK_STATEMENT: Compatibility of modeling tools is crucial in any study. As some of the tools to be used are approved for use but not HH&C CoP preferred, there are some risks of incompatibility between modeling tools. This could lead to uncertainty in risk characterization and/or analytical error.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are some projects that have used different modeling tools to cover study needs outside of HH&C CoP prefered tools and compatibility has been an issue. However, study team as tested tools with a smaller subset and all models ar compatible so far.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could trigger the need to revisit modeling tool selection and additional coordination with PCXs and CoPs.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate cost for one round of modeling and coordination.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate time to execute one round of modeling and coordination.

RISK_STATEMENT: Unacceptability of a study plan with stakeholders could delay study. There are multiple stakeholders within the study area, with different priorities in terms of what is more important to address in the region (e.g. flood risk, water quality risk, water supply risks,  ecosystem restoration needs, quality of life, community development needs, and others), with different levels of understanding about feasibility of alternatives and overall purposes of the study. This could lead to different alternatives being selected by different stakeholder groups or complete non acceptance of an alternative; need of additional time and resources for enhancing and balancing alternatives.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: As an example, the Miami Dade Back Bay Study proposed a plan during its previous study phase that consisted of constructing  floodwalls within the urban setting and the plan  was not accepted by stakeholders. LOSOM is another example as there are still discussions about balancing different stakeholders needs. Therefore, Project Manager and PDT is communicating early with stakeholders and getting feedback on each measure/ alternative being discussed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Coordination with stakeholders could lead to an opportunity of building trust.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate estimate for coordination needed through out the study.

RISK_NAME: Analytical Error - Potential future rainfall intensification
RISK_STATEMENT: Future rainfall intensification scenarios is a concern in the area. However, the determination of future rainfall intensification for extreme event scenarios (25-year; 100-year; 200-year) is not yet specified in USACE guidance. USGS and SFWMD developed an study for the region, with strong support from local stakeholders and determined change factors, with associated uncertainty ranges, for future rainfall events, based on NOAA Atlas 14 rainfall frequency. The 216 study will incorporate change factors for future rainfall as part of the TSP sensitivity analysis. Potential adaptation measures or design refinements for the TSP are been considered in the study scope. There is a potential to undersized alternatives, as a result of underestimation of flood risks, based on not accounting numerically for rainfall intensification (future extremes rainfall change factors) early on in the project development / scenario formulation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Runs with extreme rainfall scenario (using a range of change factors from 20% to 75% intensification), performed for the C8/C9 Basins show that for each 1in for additional rainfall, the additional increase in inundation levels at most vulnerable  areas within this basin is equivalent to 0.1 feet (SFWMD, 2022, Technical Memorandum: Adoption of Future Extreme Rainfall Change Factors for Flood Resiliency Planning in South Florida. South Florida Water Management District, West Palm Beach, FL). As inundation levels could be increased by 0.1 feet, the likelihood of under designing or under estimating damages due to this factor is unlikely. However, it is recognized this analysis will be key when communicating with stakeholders and that should be completed for the TSP. TSP design should be able to account for any potential design changes or adaptation measures.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Identifying and performing a potential for rainfall identification assessment will be key when communicating with stakeholders and that should be completed for the TSP.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate estimate based on team input.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Approximate estimate based on previous experience.

RISK_NAME: Study Delays - Sea Level Change Strategy
RISK_STATEMENT: The formulation for one SLR scenario in the initial round of modeling, and only accounting for a higher SLR curve at the final round of modeling, as part of TSP sensitivity runs, might lead to under sizing of alternatives and not full consideration of flooding risks early on, in the planning development phases and alternatives formulation. Likewise, there is also risk of being wrong in projections is selected. Undersized alternatives, as a result of underestimation of flood risks, based on not accounting numerically for higher SLR curves  early on in the project development / scenario formulation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Runs with higher SLR scenarios (using 3ft of SLR for a 50-year horizon, which is near to the NOAA intermediate high curve), performed for the C8/C9  Basins show that for each 1ft for additional SLR, the additional increase in inundation levels at most vulnerable areas (nearby coastal structures and along the downstream boundary) within this basin is equivalent to 0.5-1ft. [Source: C8 C9 FPLOS by Existing Infrastructure for Current and Future SLR Conditions Final Comprehensive Report]. For the South Miami Dade Basins (C1, C100, C102 and C103) show that for each 1ft for additional SLR, the additional increase in inundation levels at the coastline and southern part within this basin is equivalent or higher to 1ft. Flooding resulted from SLR scenarios are a higher concern for farmers (agricultural areas) compared to the urban areas [Source: 2022-04-27-SMD-FPLOS-TASK-611-REV2].    For the Broward Basins (Hillsboro, C-14 West, C-14 East, Pompano, C-13 West, C-12 West, North New River West, C-11 West and C-11 East) show that for each 1ft for additional SLR, the additional increase in inundation levels at the most vulnerable areas within the basins are: Hillsboro: 0.1-0.25ft  C-14 West: 0.1-0.25ft  C-14 East: 0.1-1.0ft  Pompano:   0.1-1.0ft  C-13 West: 0.1-0.5ft  C-12 West: 0.1-0.5ft  North New River:  0.1-0.25ft  C-11 West:  0.1-0.25ft  C-11 East:  0.1-1.0ft [Source: Broward FPLOS by Existing Infrastructure for Current and Future SLR Conditions Final Comprehensive Report_Signed_Sealed]. For the C-7 Basin show that for each 1ft for additional SLR, the additional increase in inundation levels at the most vulnerable areas within the basins is equivalent to 0.5-1.0ft [Source: Task4_3_AssessFPLOS C7 AlternativeFloodProtectionScenarios 3SLR]. Although flooding conditions will be exacerbated by SLC in the future, under-design of any future proposed features is unlikely.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Potential for study cost increase. However, there is an opportunity to improve trust within stakeholders by assessing all three SLC projected curves.

RISK_NAME: Study Cost Increase - Limited Equip. and Construction Sites
RISK_STATEMENT: Limited options for equipment and construction sites could lead to challenges at selecting equipment, and identification of construction sites/laydown areas, and stockpile/mater due to the highly urbanized setting and limited land availability. Potential high costs and schedule delays in PED.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Miami-Dade diesel pumps are an example of the type of pumps that the study might be proposing in the study (pumps are load), and the challenges with placement of material.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Potential increase to PED budget and schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: Over simplification / simplified assumptions to evaluate complex potential solutions have been assumed for study scope. To complete the study analyses, several simplifying assumptions will be important and necessary to make, like looking at compound flooding  using a subset of inland and coastal storm events to develop the water surface scenarios needed for the economic analysis. If these assumptions hold through the study, there are no problems. However, if one or more assumptions are deemed inappropriate in the future, this could result in not capturing compound flooding correctly.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Some aspects of the modeling strategy has been used for the SFWMD FPLOS, therefore, it is likely that  the consequence is medium due to past experience with model built-ups.

RISK_NAME: Study Cost Increase - Acquisition of Private Property
RISK_STATEMENT: SFMWD, by law, has eminent domain authority under Florida Statutes Chapter 373 (Water Resources) Section 139. As this is a flood risk management study, SFWMD should be able to acquire all lands or interest in lands required for alternatives. Projects will be stalled if land acquisition is not completed in a timely manner.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Other projects have a high occurrence of landowners not willing to sell.

RISK_STATEMENT: There is limited/no gage data in or near the site and not enough scope to develop an HMS modeling covering the entire 413 sq mi that drains to the nearest gage. Therefore, this study must work with the available long-term precipitation data near the project area has been used alongside the existing HMS model from the NFS, observed flows during the site visit, and historical point measurements of streamflow downstream to develop the hydrologic data for this study. Duration analysis was performed on the precipitation data to derive hypothetical high-frequency storm events to represent the typical flows from high-frequency storm events (wet season). For the baseflow (dry season), a range was estimated using simplified approaches due to the lack of streamflow data available for calibration of long-term continuous hydrologic modeling. Estimates of stream flow data based on precipitation data may add greater error into the model.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Even with greater error in the model, the stream and drainage area are small, and there is a large area within reach 2 for the team to absorb flow error into the design. There will likely be a greater range in flows than what is modeled, since necessary assumptions were made due to limited data availability.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Greater error in the model could lead to an under design or over design of structures.

RISK_STATEMENT: The project team is using guidance outlined in EM 1110-2-1413 wherein we test the assumption interior runoff and coincident exterior stage are independent (surge and rainfall for the CoSA BB CSRM Feasibility Study). Using the limited available surge data (NOAA Mayport, FL) and rainfall data (SJRWMD) near the water level gauge, the project team showed that there is a weak degree of correlation between the water level residual peak events and the coincident rainfall events as well as the inverse. Due to limited data near the project area, there is a risk in proceeding with this assumption. A more detailed study or collection of data in the area could results in showing that the surge and rainfall events share a strong or moderate degree of correlation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is not likely that more long term data will be available in the project area or that the project scope and schedule will allow for a more detailed review of historical data or a more complicated compound modeling approach.

RISK_STATEMENT: Due to the CoSA BB experiencing compound flooding from surge and rainfall events, the project team scoped the project to include modeling to understand the compound effects of storm surge and rainfall. Past CSRM studies have predominately modeled only surge events that allowed the use of CHS or other sourced hydrographs input directly into G2CRM, the economic model. Due to the complexity of compound flood events, rainfall and surge events will be modeled in HEC RAS and then the resultant hydrographs will be used to inform G2CRM. Due to the additional model effort, the amount of surge event had to be limited. For this study, the team has scoped for a total of 5 surge events and 5 rainfall events to create a matrix of 25 combined events. Adding more surge or rainfall events exponentially increases the amount of model runs required from HEC RAS. However, there is a risk that we are not adequately representing a full suite of possible future storms.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: The non-Federal sponsor has several capital improvement projects that are being considered as "completed" projects in the future due to there current funding and design. These future capital improvement projects will be included in the HEC RAS terrain for the FWOP and FWP model runs that will influence the G2CRM economic model. There is a risk that the non-Federal sponsor does not complete these project in the same timeline as out project start time or they project do not get implemented. Additionally, the team is not using GIS or G2CRM to model these capital improvement projects but relying on the HEC RAS model to incorporate the hydraulic changes to the landscape.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: CHS Savepoint to Drive Coastal Inputs for HEC RAS
RISK_STATEMENT: Due to the modeling approach that requires multiple coastal boundary conditions for HEC RAS, only one CHS savepoint was used to determine the storm numbers for the 2-, 10-, 25-, 100-, and 200-year coastal (surge) hydrographs. The "driving" savepoint is located at the mouth of the St. Augustine Inlet and is one of the more conservative water levels available. There is a risk that the storm numbers selected using the driving save point present a limited representation of possible future storms that the project area could experience.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Sea level rise leads to higher groundwater elevations in areas of fill in the City of Boston.  The areas of fill are currently susceptible to liquefaction and liquefaction susceptibility is exacerbated by rising sea level.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Liquefaction of coastal areas of fill leads to lateral spreading and settlement of overlying coastal protection levees and structures.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The impact of the analysis in PED could change the foundation recommendations of the features authorized in the Feasibility Study. It is likely that the Feasibility Study analysis will paint an accurate picture and only the cost of borings will be necessary in PED to confirm. However, if there is a significant change in conditions, it could significantly increase the cost of the feature's foundation.  It could also change the NEPA impacts.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts could range from 6 months to 2 years in PED depending on how different the conditions are from what is determined in Feasibility.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Preliminary designs will be based on available information of limited scope and detail. Site characterization for potential subsurface construction will not be conducted until PED phase.  Encountering unexpected geologic or hydrogeologic conditions, during PED subsurface site characterization, or during Construction, would likely lead to a Request for Equitable Adjustment (REA) or Post-Construction Claim. The Claim would most likely be for a Type 1 Materially Differing Site Condition.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While there is significant information available and the area has been disturbed over time, there is still uncertainty in exactly what the final array alignment foundations will require.  The very likely rating is based on the amount of information that is available, reducing the likelihood from what would otherwise be Extremely Likely.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If during the PFMA Analysis between TSP and ADM a determination is made that Geotech analysis is insufficient, it could require additional survey and investigation to satisfy risk requirements in feasibility.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Depending on the alternatives in the Final Array, the Engineering team may need longer to gather enough data for the risk informed design process.  Additionally, the qualitative risk assessment and the CSRA will need to account for the uncertainty of subsurface conditions. If not, the risk of insufficient construction costs may be realized.  REAs and Claims would also increase PED and Construction schedule delays.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Determining a proposed action impacts EFH or ESA Resources
RISK_STATEMENT: Identification of EFH resources at any site late in the feasibility study process would add time to the schedule and increase study cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without risk management it is very likely that we will identify either waterside construction or actual in-water work that could impact EFH. If it is waterside construction that is identified as part of the Feasibility Level design, post-ADM, it could have significant impacts on completing the NEPA document.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If baseline surveys or additional investigation is necessary post ADM, it will impact cost and schedule, depending as to where in the study area it is.  If it requires mitigation, then it will require planning and modeling on top of the potential surveys.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If surveys and mitigation planning is necessary it will take much longer. However, the likelihood is, information will be on hand and it is a matter of mitigation planning only.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Recommending features that cut off access to water
RISK_STATEMENT: Building of structures could reduce access to water's edge and associated recreational opportunities that those areas provide.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without risk management and comprehensive benefits planning it is very likely that NED planning will point to hardening shoreline and blocking access to the water as part of risk management.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The worst-case scenario is an unwilling sponsor and a terminated study.  The more likely scenario is going out for public review after TSP and getting significant push-back requiring some reformulation. Reformulation will likely require a second release for NEPA.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: HTRW material at any project site
RISK_STATEMENT: Identification of HTRW during PED investigation will impact Sponsor's ability to turn over LERRDS and could impact schedule and budget
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are contaminated areas in the study area, specifically in the upper Neponset River and along Chelsea Creek.  There are no Superfund sites in the direct area where the study is looking.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If HTRW is discovered that requires Sponsor remediation, it could take anywhere from 1-year to indefinitely.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: City of Boston Leading Public Involvement
RISK_STATEMENT: This is an opportunity. The Sponsor scheduled $250K WIK dedicated to Public Involvement and Outreach.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The city has 7-years of working on Climate Ready Boston which is the foundation for the Corps Study. They have the relationships, they understand the language barriers and interpretive needs and they know the hot-button issues in each neighborhood.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Their experience will be a significant time savings both in actual outreach, but also in responding to inquiries about who and what we didn't do for outreach.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: ERDC Refinement of the CHS Model specific to Boston CSRM
RISK_STATEMENT: ERDC used the Boston Harbor FRM Model mesh as the base for updated models to be used in the study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: CHS and G2CRM will provide a policy compliant product; however, does it provide the necessary data to give the study team the necessary information to make the correct decisions? The existing regional model and CHS will have similar base condition pictures to validate planning assumptions and decision making.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Without the refinement period, the study will likely move forward and develop a policy compliant product. However, in PED when more detail and an SQRA/SAR are necessary, it could be determined that the feasibility modeling was incorrect. Based on experience, the effort to correct this is about $500k. This triangulation shows that the study could break even at $350K for the effort or realize up to a $250K savings.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The opportunity for schedule savings is not linear.  If rework in the study later on is required, it would likely take 9 months based on experience. However, the 6-month refinement period to update CHS for the specific study is free time because it was already going to be used by the team to identify inputs to the existing and FWOP condition.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Comp Benefits (Jan '21 Memo) and EJ Outreach/inclusion (Jan '23 IG) are two planning areas of consideration that could impact plan selection. Risk is that team doesn't adequately formulate for net benefits and the incorrect Total Net Benefits Plan is identified.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The City of Boston is overwhelmingly EJ by definition of the CEJST (1.0). Reasons include linguistic isolation, traffic density and volume, and workforce development related vulnerabilities. Additionally, there are several intangible risks, impacts, and benefits that need to be considered in Boston that fall under the Comprehensive Benefits Strategy. There is no clear guidance or acceptable methodology for measuring and evaluating comprehensive benefits. It is a study-by-study process.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Without risk management, the impacts of incomplete comprehensive benefits analysis could be reformulation.  The impacts of incomplete Comp Benefits analysis is a non-policy compliant incomplete formulation and a NEPA Document that require rework, reformulation, and a re-release of the draft document.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If rework is necessary and a second release is necessary, the impact could be as great as 6 months.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Resource Availability to Support CHS Model Refinement
RISK_STATEMENT:
Partnering with ERDC for refining CHS creates a risk due to timing.  We are making the request for support at the end of the FY 2nd Quarter when Workload is at its peak for resources.  If ERDC can't support the scope and refinement of the CHS model, it could delay the ability to accurately model the existing and future without project conditions.
Further, updated modeling will require computational resources.  The HPCs are known to have issues or go offline occasionally and could lead to schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is very likely that ERDC's workload for 3rd and 4th Quarter FY23 is already planned out and full. NAE is requesting to add additional requirements to the ERDC staff to support refinement of CHS.  HPC computing resources are in high demand and could be unavailable.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If ERDC's capacity is already reached and OT is necessary to meet the needs of the District, there could be an additional cost beyond burdened labor rates.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The Team factored full workload when developing the schedule for the ERDC work.  30 days would likely be as a result of already scheduled leave of absence, or an issue with the model itself.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: G2CRM is the preferred model in conjunction with CHS for economic analysis of Coastal Studies.  The risk is under or overestimating damages in the future with project conditions which could impact formulation and alternative selection due to simplifying assumptions in the model inputs and outputs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without risk identification and risk management, it is likely that the study would underestimate or overestimate damages impacting the economic justification for alternatives; i.e. BCR and Net Benefits Analysis (NED).
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is a minor problem that would require additional formulation.  As long as the issue is identified prior to TSP and release of the draft report, there would only be minor problems associated with reformulation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: On the highest end, the estimate includes re-running the economic model after targeted ATR of the draft.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If targeted ATR identifies significant issues in the FWP, there would be need to re-run the FWP Condition.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Decision was made to include Langone Park, Fort Point Channel, Ryan Playground, and Moakley Park in the CHS FWOP Model. Other projects between constructed or far enough along in the design and permitting process will be added through modifying the G2CRM. The risk is if these projects are not fully constructed as designed, or, if USACE isn't included in the review of the NF Projects to ensure compliance with USACE Design policies and guidelines.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is unlikely that this will occur because of the Risk Management Measures agreed to at the October 17th Partnering Session between USACE and City of Boston.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This would be a major problem for reputational risk with the sponsor and the community.  We would essentially be designing around, or recommending modifications to projects that were specifically constructed for resilience purposes.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If it is determined post TSP during the Potential Failure Mode Analysis that non-project segments are unsuitable for tie in, USACE could be forced to reformulate and design around these features. The estimated cost is Planning: $25,000; En. Lead: $25,000; Geotech: $25,000; Structural: $25,000; Cost: $10,000; Review and Supervision: $10,000; Real Estate: $5,000; Environmental and Cultural: $25,000
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It would likely take 4 months from start to finish post TSP to reformulate, re-design and update the plan. It would likely require another release of the draft because of the significant change in affected area and impacts. However, depending on the significance of reformulation, could result significant changes in scope, schedule and budget.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: The Central Artery Tunnel project is among the most complicated infrastructure projects ever completed in the U.S. The project contains three tunnels within the study area: the Central Artery (I-93) tunnel through Downtown Boston, the Fort Point Channel (I-90) tunnel, and the Ted Williams Tunnel (I-90). MassDOT was unable to provide a concise summary of the longitudinal profile and cross sections of the tunnels, though record drawings are available for the 39 relevant contracts of the CA/T project. Each set of record drawings consists of several hundreds of pages of drawings. While this information is included within the contract drawings, it would take a significant amount of time and effort to read, process, interpret, and extract the relevant data from each of the 38 record drawing sets. As such, longitudinal profiles and tunnel cross sections are inferred based on a subset of record drawings and additional public data sources. These inferred profiles are likely to differ from the actual profiles. This has a chance of materially impacting the depth-damage curves and subsequent damage estimates for these tunnels. This has an equal chance of resulting in an under- or over-estimation of flood damages.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Absent refinement of longitudinal profiles, it is possible (unlikely) that the resulting depth-damage functions may not accurately reflect the flood risk profile of the tunnels. The PDT has employed a revised approach to developing tunnel specific depth-damage functions that adequately specifies the (lower and upper) bounds this uncertainty. There remains a risk that the most likely depth-damage function may be over- or under-estimating damages at shallow (<3 ft) flood depths. Prior analyses suggest that this inaccuracy would have a minimal to moderate impact on estimated damages.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk could result in a minor to moderate impact on overall estimated project benefits. Inaccurate depth-damage functions yield inaccurate damage estimates, which directly inform project benefits.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: These assumptions spare significant effort of processing the 38 sets of contract drawings. It is estimated that this effort would take approximately 175 hours (approx. $25,000 of additional study funds).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This effort would also likely delay the completion of future without project condition modeling, or require amendment of the structure inventory at a later date.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: The need for potential mitigation is unknown due to lack of design specifics. Mitigation may be warranted if unavoidable impacts to habitat are incurred.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Surveys and investigations to date (25 April) indicate mitigation is unlikely. However, as the final array is developed the likelihood will be adjusted.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If mitigation is required, the site/action would need to be identified and designed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost of modeling and resources could be as high as $50K.  This does not include the total project cost implementation of mitigation measures.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: 90 days for modeling effort to support mitigation modeling effort.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Utilities in Project Area Found in Construction
RISK_STATEMENT: Encountering unknown and abandoned utilities and man-made buried obstructions (e.g., bulkheads, piles, or foundations) found during Construction would likely lead to a Request for Equitable Adjustment (REA) or Post-Construction Claim.  The Claim would most likely be for a Type II Materially Differing Site Condition.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Encountering unknown obstructions is common in urban construction projects.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: REAs and Claims would increase Construction costs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: REAs and Claims would result in construction delays, impacting schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Underseepage of CSRM structure or existing structures
RISK_STATEMENT: Surface materials may allow underseepage during sustained high water events. Variability of surface fill within the city of Boston will make it difficult to predict and quantify the potential for seepage. In extreme cases this could destabilize a CSRM structure. Designs will need to evaluate this risk. Site conditions identified during PED or construction may necessitate design changes.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that unanticipated soil conditions will arise during a project of this scope. Design changes may not be required and will be evaluated during construction.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional costs will likely be during construction phase.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT:
There are several interconnected highway and transit tunnels that will traverse multiple model areas within the G2CRM model. There is a risk that these tunnels may serve as a potential hydraulic interconnection between model areas. This hydraulic interconnection cannot be captured within G2CRM. Such interconnection may render some alternatives at least partially ineffective. Further, there is a risk that flood waters may flow from one tunnel into another. This underground flow is not possible to characterize in G2CRM. 

Consequently, highway and transit tunnels are not well characterized by a single point, as is required within G2CRM. For the purposes of economic modeling tunnel assets will be placed at the lowest tunnel opening. When incrementally analyzing different sub-areas within the large study area, tunnel assets will be selectively included in the without- and with-project conditions only when all tunnel openings (even those located in a different ?sub-area? than the one currently being analyzed) are expected to receive a risk reduction benefit. 

Due to these modeling limitations, there is a risk that damages and benefits to highway and transit tunnels will be inadequately characterized. Given the high value of these critical infrastructure assets, this may have consequential impacts on plan formulation. Should this risk be realized and identified by the PDT, additional modeling work may be required to better characterize impacts to road and transit tunnels.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that some degree of model refinement will be required to ensure that damages, benefits, and residual risk to road and transit tunnels are adequately characterized within the economic modeling. This refinement work may be rather small, though may also be significant and consequential.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Should this risk be realized, it would pose a minor problem to the development of a tentatively selected plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on current information, should this modeling risk be realized, it will most likely require additional coordination meetings for refinement of the G2CRM model. Additional post-processing of results may also be required. This may result in approximately 100 hours of additional work, totaling approximately $15,000. In a worst-case scenario, the PDT may determine that additional hydraulic modeling may be required, in addition to G2CRM post processing. This would require a more substantive effort with engineering involvement (up to an estimated $150,000)
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the required model refinement is marginal, there may not be any schedule impact. It is more likely that a more substantive model refinement would take approximately 2 weeks of additional time. In the worst case, if engineering involvement is required, the additional effort may take several months.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: The life loss module in G2CRM will be used to estimate life loss as part of the planning phase/feasibility study.  G2CRM does not include velocity in estimating life loss, which could lead to underestimation of life loss in cases where velocity is contributing significantly to the occurrence of life loss. (See ERR item OTH-16.) To better gauge the level of risk associated with the use of G2CRM in the estimate of life loss for the Boston CSRM study, the team is receiving assistance from a Consequences SME in set up of LST (Levee Screening Tool) for the FWOP condition. However, the LST 2 is still relatively new and not designed for this specific application (life cycle life loss estimates in the context of a CSRM planning study), so there is risk that this tool will ultimately not provide the information the team needs to better understand the risk associated with using G2CRM to estimate life loss and/or that there will be issues in set up and results interpretation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that there will be challenges associated with the use of the LST 2 based on the fact that it is relatively new and the fact that Risk Cadre members familiar with the tool have reported some issues and the need to better understand what the tool is doing. Also, the coastal engineering inputs used in the feasibility study may not be translatable to the LST, which would further contribute to difficulties in comparison of the LST 2 outputs to G2CRM.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost includes a relatively small amount of time spent troubleshooting/understanding the LST 2.0 and making tweaks to the model inputs if needed. Note that a much greater cost would be incurred if the current life loss estimation approach (G2CRM focus with LST to gauge life loss estimates with velocity) leads to plan selection that must be reassessed (see ERR entry OTH-16)

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Incorrect incorporation of basements into damage estimates
RISK_STATEMENT: Basement data available to the study team for the Boston CSRM study area is limited/incomplete.  Thus, sampling using available imagery was used to draw generalized conclusions about basements across the study area. Because the damage functions used for residential structures with basements assume damages begin below the first floor of the structure, over or understating the presence of basements can impact damage estimates. It is anticipated that realization of this risk would be most impactful in areas where structure-level measures (flood-proofing, etc.) are recommended since basement assumptions directly impact damage incurred to an individual structure.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sampling indicated that residential structures overwhelmingly have basements. The sample was randomly selected. However, G2CRM results that indicate justification of certain measures are driven in large part by damages prevented to residential structures with basements may require additional, area-specific sampling to confirm/support this result.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Damage estimates impact damages prevented, so large changes in damages have the potential to impact plan selection.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Funding needed to support additional, area-specific sampling of structures to confirm presence of basement; adjustments to starting point of damages within damage function (how far below first floor does damage begin?); and rerunning of G2CRM to test updated inputs.

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Missouri River Jefferson City L-142
RISK_NAME: Underseepage - Borings not adequate to capture Piping Risk A
RISK_STATEMENT: Borings not adequate to capture areas where underseepage/piping failure risk areas not captured. Underestimating the size and number of seepage berms and/or relief wells in feasibility that have to be added in final design. This leads to underestimating construction and real estate costs in feasibility.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: If we capture an adequate sampling of soils across the site we are like to get size and number of required relief wells correct. In final design it will be likely that locations shift.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The number and size of seepage berms will be captured in final design
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Large.  Number of relief wells is underestimated they are $150,000.00 per relief wells with collector.  Seepage berms require real estate and material and are typically 200 feet or so from levee and typically extend multiple stations. Past construction and current trends used to estimate.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If seepage berms are underestimated they will require that Sponsor aquire additional real estate for construction. Minor.  Final design will have more borings and number and size of relief wells and underseepage berms will be captured in final.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: ECONOMIC DAMAGES IN THE FUTURE WITHOUT PROJECT CONDITION
RISK_STATEMENT: Post Targeted ATR of FWOP may demonstrate significant flaws in the outputs that require additional economic investigation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Likely. With implementation of the Risk Management Measure of Targeted ATR; will reduce risk to unlikely.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Point estimate post-Targeted ATR with additional work required.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: In a dense urban environment with significant tide swings (+9 feet) differences between water surface elevations and floodplains within each curve are significant.  Over a 50-year period of economic analysis and a 100-year planning horizon, the impacts of SLC in the study area are also significantly different. The impacts can influence comprehensive benefits analysis; critical resource impacts; as well as impacts to natural resources.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a significant difference in preliminary curves at the low/intermediate/ and High SLC scenarios.  It is likely that the formulation will change depending on the accuracy of the FWOP floodplain at both the 50-year and 100-year horizons.  50-year for quantitative analysis and 100-year for qualitative analysis.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Depending on the model setup conditions and input criteria, the floodplains could understate the risk while still being policy compliant. This would lead to a project being constructed that overstates risk management in the project area.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PDT and CPR CoP have developed methodology to update SLC Curves using SLAT; 1992 mid-point; and 40-year trend.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Depending on the alternatives selected, the entire study area is full of historic properties and potential archeological artifacts as well as National Historic Landmarks and significant historic and cultural landscapes.  Historic, architectural and archaeological assessments and surveys will likely be required as the study progresses.  If areas such as the Naval Shipyard and historic wharfs are identified for significant construction, significant surveys, i.e. in-water surveys may be required prior to the PA being signed.  Offshore work would also require remote sensing archaeological surveys depending upon the location and the proposed alternative.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a study cost increase risk if in-water surveys are required prior to executing the PA.  Even without in-water survey requirements, there may be additional survey requirements after the initial surveys are complete, depending on our alignments inthe final array. Additionally, historic properties assessments and archaeological surveys, both on shore or in water, may be required for specific alternatives identified leading to the TSP.  Depending the upon the significance of the historic property or landscape, this could result in additional costs and possible scope modifications either during the FS or PED.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If invasive or detailed surveys become required to complete a PA on the Study it will create potential cost and schedule delays.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An initial historic and archaeological assessment of the project study area will be required during the FS to identify historic properties.  This assessment will help inform development of the Section 106 PA which will need to be coordinated and executed once the TSP is identified and by the end of the FS.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If additional surveys; would require AE Contracting and remote sensing equipment.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: The number of stakeholders and property owners in the study area footprint is significant.  Many areas that will require structural measures are not publicly owned by the City of Boston.  Other areas may be identified for managed retreat or buyout as the recommended plan. They are either private or under the control of a different public entity.  In order to construct or implement, there may be a significant real estate undertaking; any real estate that can't be acquired could impact the effectiveness of the plan, potentially causing a redesign.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A redesign post authorization will potentially impact the authorized project, the cost, or the environmental impacts.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If a redesign is necessary due to real estate acquisition issues it will require both Engineering and NEPA work.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: To develop an EDR and potentially a Supplemental NEPA Document post authorization.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: USACE CSRM Studies incorporate sea level change into formulation. Policy directs formulation to USACE Curves, the high, intermediate and low scenarios. Teams traditionally formulate to all three curves, or they formulate to the intermediate curve and run sensitivity on the other two. Formulating to the low curve in a study area such as Boston could significantly understate risk; formulating to the high curve could overstate risk and remove opportunities for softer, adaptable solutions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Formulating for SLC is not an exact science and it is driven by the conditions of the study area, outputs of the model, as well as critical thresholds. Without risk management, it is very likely the team will formulate to the intermediate curve, because it's often been confused as the accepted practice and risk would be understated in the study area.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the study team, inlcuding the sponsor, recommends a plan based on the High SLC scenario, but the PL&C team recommends the Intermediate SLC scenario based on uncertainty it could be a major problem.  The result could be either reformulation, or a need for an LPP/NED exception to go with the High SLC scenario.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is likely there will be some discussion with the ATR and PL&C Team as to which curve is proper, why, and what is driving the decision. When considering the number and level of reviews, it is anticipated and built into the study schedule for 60 days.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: Delays associated with development numerical coastal models.  Regardless of NACCS or MC-FRM, there are significant changes necessary to develop an accurate existing and future without project model. Delays to coastal modeling could cascade and affect Economics and Cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The study area is very complex and there are several projects and actions by others that need to be developed for the numerical modeling.  As large as the study area, it is likely that there will be challenges in developing the FWOP picture. The team is employing ERDC to conduct modeling efforts. They are experienced and well progressed through the FWOP Modeling as of 25 April 2024.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There could be delays in releasing the draft report.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Study team is already using the Enterprise SME.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If there are delays it will likely impact economics and cost disciplines and prolong the schedule. Reduced to 30-days based on current model progression of ERDC.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Impacts due to Logan International Airport
RISK_STATEMENT: Logan International Airport and its airspace and flyways are in the study area. Based on needed elevation for structural solutions, flyway, runway end safety zones, and obstruction clearance rules may be impacted.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without risk management and cooperating with the FAA, it is likely that an NNBF planned for Belle Isle Marsh, or Wood Isle Marsh would impact study completion.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The FAA could require additional bird hazard studies or other studies to demonstrate the performance impacts on Logan International Airport.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Significant bird studies or surveys could cost a lot of money. However, there is extensive information and studies available for the areas in question.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_STATEMENT: There are several elevated roadways that serve as non-project segment barriers.  These segments are not designed or constructed to serve that purpose. If USACE formulates around these segments, they could become risk items later in a risk analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without risk management, it is likely that the study team will formulate without consideration of the non-project segments and only formulate to tie in closure structures for the underpasses of these segments.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If it is determined that closure structures are not compliant or too great of a risk, reformulation could be necessary.  Reformulation could also increase the study budget due to NEPA impacts and engineering survey needs depending on the recommendation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The greatest impact of this risk is reformulation where it is determined that the risk is too great for a simple closure structure tied into an existing non-project segment.  The more likely impact is additional study and analysis to ensure tie in is structurally sound and does not exacerbate risk.

PROJECT_NAME: City of Boston Coastal Storm Risk
RISK_NAME: Life Safety Risk of the Alternatives
RISK_STATEMENT: Life Safety analysis in feasibility is a different level of analysis than PED. In feasibility economic models are used for analysis and the team will use a Potential Failure Mode Analysis of the TSP; however, the team will not conduct an SQRA in feasibility. The team must understand current condition risk and how the project would transform that life safety risk. The project schedule and budget risk is selecting a plan in feasibility for which the team cannot describe the systematic flood risk transformation or potential for flood risk transference. The team would then be required to go through reformulation, or a different plan in Design after a full SQRA is done.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Life Safety analysis in the study phase can be qualitative or semi-quantitative depending on the degree of risk determined by the PDT. Without risk management and involvement of risk cadre, it is very likely that the risk would be realized. However, implementing risk management lowers the risk to unlikely.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If life safety analysis changes significantly from feasibility to design, it would require reformulation and potentially a return to the Planning phase.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If it is determined that Life Safety is not sufficient, could require additional analysis, or potentially reformulation. This has Planning, NEPA, and Engineering impacts. The implementation of risk management could range from a low end of performing an SQRA and updating the vertical chain with the results of the information if the TSP were still acceptable relative to the Tolerable Risk Guidelines , or on the high end the TSP is not supported by the Tolerable Risk Guidelines and the team will be required to go through reformulation, which would have a massive schedule and budget impact.

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Mississippi River Comprehensive Management Study

Studies show that MS River geomorphology is constantly changing from a complex set of natural and anthropogenic causes, many of which are outside of the study area.
The State of Louisiana continues to permit diversions which may alter the management of the Lower Mississippi River, so the future-with and future-without project conditions may not be accurately modeled.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
MR&T system unknowns risk inaccurate modeling FWOP and future-with project conditions. 
 Inaccurate modeling risks an inaccurate Recommended Plan and flawed designs.

Scoping, data collection, and the modeling schedule depend on factors such as the number of alternatives, the model types (for example 1D, 2D, or 3D H&H models), if existing models are available or if models need to be built.

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Mississippi River Comprehensive Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
Risk: Risk of 9 months lost time and decreased efforts that can be invested in the study if the study start date is based on the Implementation Guidance, which specified a study start date upon receipt of funds (May 2022 date) instead of at an originally anticipated October 2023 FCSA signing. This could result in study delays, outcome risk, poor planning decision
Consequence: Regional system may not be considered thoroughly enough to "reverse" adverse effects from existing efforts, and may cause new adverse effects. Miscalculating risks and consequences across the whole Lower Mississippi River system could result in new adverse impacts.
Evidence: Mega studies typically require 5years. Coastal Texas Study, the largest mega study to date, required 120 active PDT members for only one state (Texas) . The study already had a 2-year Master Plan that preceded the study start and still took 5 years. If LMR Comp only has 4 years total due to lost time, the need to serve 6 states across multiple districts with diverging interests, 4 years does not seem realistic to create a meaningful re-working of the entire Lower Mississippi River system. This opportunity to reenvision the river will likely  only once in a lifetime, so it is crucial to have sufficient time for meaningful work.
Risk Management: To reduce risk, P0 team will coordinate further. P0 Team will seek an Exemption to IG to identify a start date of right now, a start date at a future FCSA date, start date of when P0 PDT timeline ends, or have a Memorandum of Understanding (MOU)
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Mississippi River Comprehensive Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Counsel has concerns with the way IG is written. Date that 5-year schedule begins. IG says study begins "upon receipt of funds".  Sorting out the start date could cause schedule delays. Not delaying the schedule could result in delayed milestones.

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Mississippi River Comprehensive Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
Because the study is 100% Federally-funded, an FCSA may not be executed. The FCSA signing typically starts the 5-year timeline for a study. The IG states that the 5-year schedule begins upon receipt of funds. Too little working time negatively impacts capabilities within study effort. With a once -in-a-generation opportunity to reenvision the LMR, there is a risk of insufficient analysis if enough time is not granted to this effort.
Risk Reduction: Prepare Exemption packet.

RISK_STATEMENT: There is a risk that DSOG may or may not endorse all of the measures in the TSP. Refinements to the TSP could be costly and time consuming, putting the schedule at risk.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Reevaluation of Hydrology Based on Policy Changes
RISK_STATEMENT: The way the agency evaluates risk associated with the Probable Maximum Flood changed during development of the DSMS.  The PDT will perform an evaluation using this new methodology. The results have the potential to impact the identified TSP, potentially requiring a larger dam raise than what has been previously evaluated.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The degree of change is currently unknown. The PDT will re-evaluate the new proposed top of dam and evaluate risk under the new PMF condition.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This assumes this analysis does not impact plan formulation. (ie. the dam cannot be raised high enough)

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Actual sea level elevation change could be greater than existing forecast models' range and resulting plans may be under-engineered.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Due to increased recent storms nationwide and given the range of possible sea level rise scenarios, there remains a fair chance of true mean sea level rise falling outside of model expectations. 
#Note: Need additional feedback on this
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Risk that proposed, recommended plan, would be insufficient or overconstructed to solve the erosion problem.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Cost varies depending on the assumed risk incorporated in the construction phase, but cost will likely be unrealized until additional data increases accuracy of current models. If sea level rise is higher in real time than what was modeled, then the rate and volume of sand erosion could be much higher. That would necessitate more frequent and or larger volumes of sand replenishment. If sea level rise is lower than what was modeled, then we may be over engineering a solution and less material/frequent nourishment would be needed.

#Need further feedback to access risk cost
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
If the team is directed to conduct additional modeling under a different sea level change scenario it would lengthen the impact analysis and evaluation phase, this would postpone dates to reach TSP. 

#Need further feedback to access schedule impact

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Economic and hydraulic models are assumed to be approved for single use within the time constraints of the study. Deviation from our assumed times will increase duration of project and cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on our previous communication with CSRM-PCX, we have reason to believe that the approval of the model is unlikely to be rejected or delayed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Rejecting a model would result in setbacks for the project and increased costs, as using alternative models may require additional coordination and a learning curve.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Model approval delays would prolong the analysis phase of the project and increase cost while approval is pending. Model rejection would require alternative analysis methodology, significantly increasing labor costs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Either a delay or rejection of our models will result in schedule setbacks until we either receive approval, or under worst case scenario, find alternative methodology if required to do so.

RISK_STATEMENT: Study authorization allows for study area of entire coast of Delaware.  NFS focus for coastal storm risk is on Inland Bays.  NFS has related that multiple studies are ongoing in Wilmington Area for flood risk management.  NAP has recently completed the Dredged Material Utilization study, which has been authorized in WRDA 2020 and amended in WRDA 2022.  This would provide coastal storm risk reduction for communities on Delaware Bay Coast.  Inland Bays area has had very little attention for back-bay flood risk reduction.  Study risk is  including additional areas beyond the Inland Bays post-AMM.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Early planning decision made in concert with NFS and relayed and agreed to by NFS leadership.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If larger study area is carried through, project could run out of funding and be terminated.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional EN modeling and economic modeling and data collection.  If inclusion of DE Bay coast and residual risk of DMU communities, cost would be lower.  If inclusion of Wilmington Area, cost would be high.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If inclusion of DE Bay coast and residual risk of DMU communities, time would be lower.  If inclusion of Wilmington Area, time would be high.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Pushback from the communities could cause the plans to be stymied and additional funding spent.

A realization of the risk might be that finding additional or alternative material for use would require additional time and would likely be much more costly than using materials found close to the site.

RISK_STATEMENT: There are two Superfund sites within the study area. Both are located in Millsboro, one at 199 Mitchell Street and one at 225 W Dupont Boulevard. One of the alternative includes small barriers on tributaries that are adjacent to the Superfund Site located at 199 Mitchell Street.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Given current conditions, the Alternative to put small barriers on a few tributaries in Millsboro may be directly next to or impacted by a Superfund site.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If we were to determine that the barrier for Alternative 3 at the tributary needs to cross the Superfund site at Mitchell avenue, it would impact the performance of the protection given and might cause more issues in that area.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT is currently uncertain how much H&H modeling will be required to identify the TSP. H&H modeling may be required to resize the pump stations and to  develop NED benefits. However, the PDT is uncertain if resizing the equipment in the pump stations is necessary. And we are uncertain about how much modeling will be required to complete the benefits analysis. Too much modeling will result in wasted time and funding. While too little modeling would result in not enough information to understand the future conditions, risk reduction and benefits gained by the future TSP.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT has spend significant time discussing this topic and we are still uncertain.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is estimated that additionally funding would be required if the PDT needs to develop an H&H model for both Hartford and East Hartford that would model interior drainage. There are other potential options that would reduce this cost. For example, the MDC has storm water modeling for Hartford. We need to make contact with the agency to see if they would be willing to share their modeling with the USACE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Developing an H&H model for both Hartford and East Hartford would require a significant amount of time, however an estimate of that duration has not been developed to date. Before spending time on this estimate, the PDT will attempt other alternative. We will also discuss this question with the FRM-PCX to determine exactly what is needed, so that extraneous work isn't completed.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: The latest implementation guidance on Environmental Justice leave many questions unanswered and there the USACE doesn't have much experience implementing the new guidance. There is a risk that the PDT will incorrectly interpret the new guidance. This will result in wasted effort and loss of time if the PDT is asked to do additional work to satisfy the requirement.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The risk of not full understanding the new EJ guidance is non-compliance with USACE policy and the EO.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Although this risk could lead to additional work, it's not believed that it would impact the $3mil study cost.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_NAME: Elevation of the levee embankment and/or floodwalls.
RISK_STATEMENT: If the PDT recommends the elevation of the levee embankments and/or floodwall, this measure will significantly impact the viewshed. This would result in a more broad NEPA/Section 106 analysis in addition to potential mitigation requirements. This risk would result in increased project costs, feasibility study costs and time.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT doesn't fully understand the concerns of the NFSs so does not know if there is a need to increase the height of the floodwalls and levee embankments.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk would result in the need to balance compliance with NEPA and other environmental laws with the need to rehabilitate the levee systems. As a result, additional time and money would be required to complete the impacts analysis of the view shed and to determine potential mitigation strategies. Additionally, mitigation could impact the project costs.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_NAME: Protection of historic structures vs protection of community
RISK_STATEMENT: Structures that are part of the levee systems may be historic and should be added to the National Register of Historic Places. If the PDT recommends that these structures should be replaced, the PDT will have to coordinate with the CT SHPO. This would result in the need for additional time and funding to complete coordination with the CT SHPO and to develop/implement mitigation plans. Additionally historic documentation, if required, would need to be completed during the PED Phase and prior to construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Many structures that make up the levee systems are over 50 years old and could be added to the National List of Historic Structures. The protection of these historic assets will have to be balanced against the needs of rehabilitation the levees and protection of the communities behind the FRM systems.

With the information currently available to the PDT, most historic structures (other then those related directly to the levee systems) are locate away from the rivers. The PDT believes that this risk will relate only to the structures associated with the levee system (e.g., pump stations).
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk balances the needs of the levee systems and the communities that they protect with the requirements to protect historic resources.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the levee system is found to be eligible for the National Register of Historic Places and the tentatively selected plan results in an "adverse effect" upon significant historic properties, then a Memorandum of Agreement is required along with appropriate mitigation measures, most likely historic documentation.  Cost is TBD and an estimate only.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Staffing shortages and turnover at the resource agencies may impact coordination efforts. This risk could result in needing additional time to complete NEPA coordination or incomplete coordination.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Concern about this risk was high at the beginning of the feasibility study. But the resources agencies have been responsive to the PDTs coordination efforts. We hope that this will continue to be the case.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk could result in incomplete compliance with NEPA and other environmental laws or additional time to complete require compliance.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
There is a concern that there is insufficient data to describe the study area and to  adequately describe the existing, future without and change condition. USACE guidance requires that the existing and FWOP conditions are described in the feasibility report. The PDT is concerned that this isn't enough available data to allow the adequate description of the existing and FWOP conditions. 

 Additionally, the Section 216 authority requires that elements included in the RP be a result of a changed physical or economic condition. The PDT has heard lots of anecdotal descriptions of the changed conditions that are experiences that the FRM systems. The risk is that there isn't sufficient existing data to support the anecdotal evidence to prove a changed condition. If sufficient data is not found to support anecdotal evidence, then some measures might not be included in the plan and an incomplete solution would be recommended.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: At this point in the study, we are uncertain of the likelihood of this risk.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk impacts the compliance with USACE guidance and the Section 216 authority. It could result in the completeness of the feasibility report and environmental compliance. It could also result in an incomplete solution being recommended.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_NAME: Data describing penetrations through the systems
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT is concerned that there isn't adequate data that describes the penetrations through the two levee systems. Inadequate data would result in incorrect identification of needed measures necessary for the rehabilitation of the levee system and/or incorrect design to address the seepage due to penetrations through the levee embankments.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The NFSs have stated that they don't have complete information describing the penetrations through the levee embankments.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk could impact both time and cost of the feasibility phase. It could also impact the quality of the designs that are developed to address the weaknesses of the levee caused by the penetrations through the levees.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk might impact the budget of the feasibility phase by requiring additional funding to compete the designs/methods to address the seepage concerns due to embankment penetrations. This risk could also impact the PED and construction phase, if the actual conditions turn out to be different from those that were used to develop designs/methods. However, at this time, the exact cost impact is not known.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There could be impacts to the schedule of the Feasibility phase as described previously in the Cost Impact Section. However, at this time, the exact cost impact is not known.
