PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_NAME: Assume Availability of Compatible Sediment Material
RISK_STATEMENT: Beach nourishment may be ineffective with incompatible sediment material currently available. A realization of said risk would require additional time to seek out alternative sediment sources, likely a time draining and costly process.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
The site has been nourished prior with available sediment, so it is likely that the available sediment is compatible. 

# Need more feedback - on amount of sediment available and if it will be sufficient. While prior efforts for nourishment have been done, I believe the scale of our project would be larger and so the amount of sediment needed may not be met.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Seeking out alternative sediment sources and determining an appropriate method of deliver would be time consuming and therefore increase labor cost for the planning phase.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time to find alternative sediment and conduct further analysis to ensure it meets project requirements will increase labor costs, in addition to planning the sediment alternative delivery method. The total project cost would increase, as alternative sediment sources will be more expensive.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Finding alternative sediment will take time, alongside any further analysis required to ensure meets NEPA compliance and required sediment composition. Additionally, the sediment will need to be delivered, and the delivery method will also need additional time.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Assuming that there is a hydraulic cutterhead dredge, a vessel used to mix dredged sediment to ensure it is uniform. If the alternative hopper type dredge vessel was used, it could result in an incompatible sediment borrow material rendering the nourishment ineffective. We would need to source an appropriate dredge vehicle elsewhere.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Given that this area has previously been nourished regularly, appropriate equipment is expected to have been used and should still be available.

#Need feedback on communications with Oceanside or relevant agency on vehicle availability.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
Risk may have small impacts on cost for the planning phase in terms of labor time. 

#Are there any other potential impacts?
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Missing the appropriate dredge vessel could increase cost through additional labor cost due to time invested locate an appropriate vessel.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Locating an appropriate vessel, and could take time depending on proximity to providers.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: The budget allocated was based on the 2016 labor rates, and so the current funding is out of step with current needs. Due to limited budget, planners time commitment will be limited on project to approximately 25% of weekly available hours, below the suggested amount.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Prior planning experience suggests a higher time preferred than budget allows; additional funding is unlikely, and we will need to adjust accordingly.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: With limited planning time availability, the report will need to have significantly higher involvement from other team members.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: No cost change as there are no additional funds available.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_NAME: Project Implementation Impact on Threatened Species
RISK_STATEMENT: Assumption that timing and duration of project implementation will avoid and/or minimize impacts to endangered and threatened species in the project area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Endangered and threatened species in the area could be placed at unintended risk, potentially violating Endangered Species Act and increase costs if remediation is necessary. The project is narrow in scope and much of the work (dredging) has been ongoing before, leading to the view that the project will have a controlled and limited impact. It would require a very unlikely introduction of
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Under the unlikely scenario of schedule setbacks, depending on the scale of the issue team may have issues with budget a limited budget if significant labor needs to be invested to mitigate negative externalities.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The introduction of new unaccounted for threatened species or unanticipated expansion of project scope during the planning phase would increase time and labor for the teams to plan and mitigate around concerns.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The introduction of new unaccounted for threatened species or unanticipated expansion of project scope during the planning phase would increase time and introduce schedule setbacks depending on the scale of the problem.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Shoreline change modeling not accurately describing existing conditions. Projection of with and without harbor conditions may be incorrect due to the long simulation time with limited calibration or validation data. Incomplete knowledge of coastal processes may lead to incorrect prediction of future conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past modeling experience.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Risk that proposed, recommended plan, would be insufficient or overconstructed to achieve the target shoreline and reduce erosion.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost of inaccurately defining without harbor conditions may be unrealized. If the selected plan does not achieve the target shoreline width and the shoreline becomes sand deficient, more frequent or larger volumes of replenishment would be needed. Construction of groins may cause more impact south of the project area than predicted.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If a risk-based analysis to determine, among other requirements, the sensitivity of input conditions and potential changes to the FWOP, FWP, and effects from harbor construction were performed, the impact analysis and evaluation phase would be extended. TSP selection would be postponed.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_NAME: Availability of Sufficient Quantity from Borrow Source
RISK_STATEMENT: Insufficient quantity of sediment may be available at the borrow source location. Other federal and non-federal projects in the region currently scope or utilize the borrow source.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Studies being performed by local entities (city and county) include the borrow area as a feasible source of sediment for potential beach nourishment projects, as it has been previously identified for similar projects. At least one active USACE beach nourishment project is scheduled to utilize the borrow area for renourishment events within 20 years.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: A new or expanded borrow source may need to be identified for re-nourishment cycles. Seeking out alternative sediment sources and determining an appropriate method of delivery would be time consuming and therefore potentially impact renourishment timing.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time to find alternative sediment and conduct further analysis to ensure it meets project requirements will increase labor costs, in addition to planning the sediment alternative delivery method. The total project cost would increase, as alternative sediment sources will be more expensive.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Finding alternative sediment sources with the quantity and composition required will take time. Additionally, the sediment will need to be delivered, and the delivery method will require additional time during construction.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Storms may increase in intensity and/or frequency over the 50-year project duration, influencing wave conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on increased recent storms nationwide and past experience with other projects, model expectations using historical data may under-predict wave conditions. No consensus in scientific community on the site-specific changes in storms resulting from climate change.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Risk that recommended plan would be insufficient to solve erosion concerns.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost varies depending on the assumed risk incorporated in the construction phase, but will likely be unrealized until additional data increases accuracy of models. If wave climate is greater in real time than what was modeled, then the rate and volume of sand erosion could be higher, necessitating more frequent and/or larger volume sand replenishments.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional study unlikely to improve certainty.

PROJECT_NAME: San Diego County Shoreline - Oceanside, CA, Mitigation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Resolution of runup and overtopping in USACE approved cross-shore models is limited. Storm effects, such as short-term erosion, wave runup, and overtopping (wave overwash), may be misrepresented in the numerical modeling.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past modeling experience. Model applications on the West Coast give poor agreeance with actual runup and overtopping conditions.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Risk that proposed, recommended plan, would be insufficient to reduce erosion.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Rate and volume of sand erosion could be higher, and more frequent or larger volumes of replenishment would be needed. Additional modeling to determine storm effects would increase labor needed prior to TSP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If high-fidelity wave modeling is directed, it would lengthen the impact analysis and evaluation phase, then postpone dates to reach TSP.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_STATEMENT: This feasibility study investigates two entirely separate FRM systems with two NFSs. This is essentially two separate studies rolled into one with the study limitations (3 years and $3 million).  The study may require additional time and funding. And it is uncertain if the NFSs will support an extension. However, at this time, it is not clear if the study will need an 3X3X3 exemption.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Due to the complexity of the FRM systems and the measures that may be included in the Recommended plan, it is likely that additional time and/or funds will be needed or we will need to rescope the study if the NFSs are not interested in a larger effort. However, at this time it's not know if an exemption will be required.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If this risk occurs, there may be an impact to the study budget. However, at this time an estimate is not available.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If this risk is occurs, then it may impact the study schedule. However, at this time its too early to determine the impact.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_NAME: Study with two separate Non-Federal Sponsors
RISK_STATEMENT: This feasibility study investigates two entirely separate FRM systems with two NFSs. The NFSs each have different needs, concerns and objectives. While the systems, though share some characteristics, have different problems. Additionally, the two NFSs have no tolerance for expending funds on the others system. The NFSs may not agree with elements of planning process (e.g. fund allocation, 3X3X3 exemption) even though they must move together through the feasibility phase.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Through weekly continued coordination, the PDT understands the NFSs concerns and what they are willing to support.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If this risk occurs and the NFSs do not agree on a way forward, this may impact the completion of the study.

PROJECT_NAME: Hartford and East Hartford, CT Section 216 Levee Rehabilitation Study
RISK_NAME: Correct Interpretation of the Section 216 authority
RISK_STATEMENT: The Section 216 implementation guidance and 2005 Memo in Reconstruction are vague, which could lead to incorrect interpretation. Incorrect interpretation of the authority could result in not included elements that should be considered or inclusion of elements that are not appropriate to the study authority. This could lead to confusion during the planning process and coordination with the NFS. It could also lead to delays in the the implementing the planning process
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT is working with a Planning mentor and are coordinating with the FRM-PCX to ensure that the authority is correctly interpreted.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: By not interpreting the authority correctly, the PDT could develop an incomplete plan, leaving out essential elements of the plan to rehabilitate the levee systems. Conversely, if element not supported by the authority are included in the recommended plan, then this could lead to the PDT having to reformulate the RP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the authority is misinterpreted, then the PDT could waste time by analyzing elements not supported by the authority. Or could leave out elements that should be included, which are identified later in the study. This would also lead to study delays.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Within SBEACH and Beach-fx, for each planning reach, the PDT must specify a uniform upland elevation. This upland elevation directly informs the ground surface elevation and first floor elevation (FFE) of structures. Event-specific damages are directly dependent upon FFE. The PDT specified an upland elevation based on the average elevation of a set of sample points within a planning reach. This neglects variability in ground surface elevation within a planning reach. 

Under a significant storm event, it is likely that damages will be underestimated for a subset of structures, though it is also likely that damages will be overestimated for a separate subset of structures. The PDT has agreed to assume that, in aggregate, these potential over/underestimations are likely to cancel each other out. Consequently, the PDT has made the risk-informed decision that additional the work needed to increase the model fidelity is unlikely to provide any meaningful change to estimated economic performance or plan formulation outcomes.

There remains a risk that at a future point in time, this additional model fidelity may be required to differentiate between alternatives. Should this risk be realized, additional work would be required to specify ground surface elevations on a per-structure basis. This was anticipated to require a substantive amount of additional work for the lead economist. Additional additional changes to the SBEACH modeling may also be required, which would require significant time and effort from the coastal engineering team.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The risk owner estimates that it is very unlikely (~10% probability) that this additional model fidelity will be required to differentiate between alternatives. It is likely that this additional fidelity would be required to optimize a nonstructural alternative, though the PDT has assessed that it is unlikely that we would advance a nonstructural alternative beyond the TSP milestone.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Rough estimate of additional labor required to develop structure-specific ground surface elevation estimates and to re-run SBEACH, beach-fx, and any additional work. Estimate assumes 8-30 weeks of additional effort by an economist and coastal engineer working at 25% utilization.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate assumes 8-30 weeks of additional effort by an economist and coastal engineer working at 25% utilization.

RISK_NAME: Resilience study assumes wrong FWOP condition.
RISK_STATEMENT: The study area of the Comite River Diversion authorized project is being used for the Comite Resiliency Feasibility Study. Generally, a new FRM model is not necessary in this case. However, due to design changes of the Comite authorized project, as well as site condition changes since project authorization in 1991, H&H and Economic modeling will need to be updated in order to establish updated and FWOP conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is difficult to go forward with plan formulation without knowing the FWOP condition.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Anticipated costs for the Economic Update are $180,000. Costs are referenced in the PMP estimate but are not incorporated into the total project cost estimate. It is expected that the authorized Comite project will undertake this effort as a part of the HQ Change Control Board (CCB) process. If the CCB determines that an Economic Update is not required for the construction project, the updated costs will need to be included in the Comite Resiliency Feasibility Study PMP estimate.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An Economic Update of the Comite Diversion authorized project will take approximately 5 months to establish FWOP conditions.

RISK_STATEMENT: There is a substantial likelihood that a non-structural measure could be part of the TSP, resulting in the need for Real Estate to have sufficient time to determine needs and assess non-standard estates (NSE).  If a non-standard estate is needed as part of the TSP, additional time and funding will be needed to coordinate these with the vertical team leading up to the Agency Decision Milestone (ADM).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The team has identified the need for up to $40,000 of additional contingency to cover the potential for extended NSE coordination as well as ROE work.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The team has identified the need for an additional 2 months in the schedule to get to the ADM and anticipates this time will be sufficient to accomplish any additional real estate coordination. Moreover, additional time is also necessary for Real Estate to obtain rights-of-entry (ROE) for U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) to perform necessary environmental surveys, which should be able to be accomplished within the additional 6 months to get to the TSP.

RISK_STATEMENT: The project is expected to have significant involvement from USFWS throughout the study. To develop a Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act Report, and act as a cooperating agency under NEPA, USFWS will be responsible for a significant body of work, including habitat surveying and habitat modelling to determine impacts.  These efforts will be contingent upon receiving rights of entry in a timely fashion. At this time, an EIS is anticipated to be needed to provide a sufficient analysis of potential environmental impacts to significant resources in the Parishes. The PDT has incorporated sufficient time and funding in the proposed schedule to account for environmental assessments, review, coordination, and permitting that may be needed as a result of a proposed project. The PDT is prepared to transition to a lesser effort involved with an Environmental Assessment (EA), if warranted, after additional screening of measures and alternatives. The schedule is anticipated to remain similar under both EIS and EA scenarios due to the complexities of analysis for H&H modeling and Economics.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The total additional cost for addressing these risk is $180,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: In total the team has also identified the need for an additional 6 months in the schedule to get to the TSP milestone

RISK_STATEMENT: The suitability of sediments for beach nourishment will not be confirmed until additional sampling and analysis compliant with federal and state law is completed during the design phase, although the proposed areas are considered very likely to contain suitable beach quality sand based on prior sampling efforts in the harbor by USACE and by the State in the offshore borrow area. There are no known or recent contamination events within Haleiwa Small Boat Harbor that would indicate potential concerns.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: No known spills, discharges or known sources of contamination at the harbor and no change to the use of the harbor since 2008.  Haleiwa Harbor primarily supports commercial and recreational fisherman and does not support any industrial or fueling activities at the SBH. Based on 2008 sediment analysis, there were no known contaminants and approximately 50% of the material was beach quality material. The results of the PED sampling and analysis of the borrow areas will range from all unsuitable, to areas that are suitable and areas that are not suitable, to all suitable for beach nourishment.  In the unlikely event that all the sampled material in the offshore borrow area and State breakwater settling basin is unsuitable for beach nourishment, then those areas will not be dredged.  In the more likely event that some of the sediments within the offshore borrow area and State breakwater settling basin are not suitable, then only those areas where the sediment will be beneficially used will be dredged.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If material from the federal channel is unsuitable for ocean dumping, this may delay dragging within the harbor. There is budding safety concerns with certain locations in the channel, where sediment has accumulated, that are a safety concern.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If non beach quality material is found in any of the areas, this will result in a cost savings as there areas won't be dredged. The findings during PED sediment analysis will inform the construction scope. Along the same lines, if material is found within the federal channel that does not qualify for ocean dumping, the project may be terminated as it would be too expensive to haul material upland (it is estimated that construction cost would at least double).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This time is identified more as time nece4ssary for the project team to reassess after sediment sampling is complete. If any unexpected findings occur, this will likely result in a time savings as there would be fewer dredge locations and/or the project team would recommend to terminate the effort.

RISK_STATEMENT: Bedrock or other debris may be encountered during dredging of the barge access zone.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sediment sampling will be completed in PED. Based on field inspections it as assumed and unlikely event.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Beach placement method would be adjusted based on site conditions finding
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based off feasibility cost estimate for truck hauling material to bHaleiwa Beach Park
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time needed for truck hauling trips

RISK_STATEMENT: Environmental windows related to shorebirds and other biological resources may constrain construction period; however, actual dredging and placement should be able to be completed during the summer months (April to September). Dredging outside of these months is difficult due to wave and weather conditions.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Nov - Apr is the range where dredging work likely could not occur due to weather/environmental issues.

RISK_STATEMENT: In the project schedule, Real Estate Notice to Acquire is "linked" to 100% design  per ER-405-1-12, and this amounts to 1 year+ between when AE completes 100% design and Design approval. Risk is it takes longer than the estimated time.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There will likely be sufficient information to issue the NTA earlier in the design process (somewhere between 65% and 90% design). Current schedule reflects worst case scenario.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Linking NTA to the 100% design is the major schedule driver (critical path, drives schedule) which results in construction contract award estimated Aug 2027. Regional leadership may not support this, viewing the amount of time as unacceptable.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: currently estimating maximum of 222 work days for NFS to acquire real estate requirements.

RISK_NAME: Risk of changes to the SEA caused by PACR Changes
RISK_STATEMENT: The PACR is evaluating if the changes made in PED reflect the original NED plan and Congressional Authority for the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that the SEA will need to be modified due to significant changes.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The PACR has a low risk for impacting the NEPA process because the largest change to the project has come from PAV05A which is under SEA #2. SEA #2 has not undergone public or agency draft review. Therefore, the draft SEA can be edited to reflect the PACR if needed. The changes described in SEA #1 are minimal compared to the changes in PAV05A, there is low risk that the PACR will change the conclusions of the SEA and its FONSI. However, the risk will increase if planning does not communicate regularly to the lead biologist of any conclusions or thoughts of the PACR.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate 1 year total worth of impacts due to cleanup processes and timelines accross all 10 contract areas.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Air Force concerned about increased bird activity in flight paths.

RISK_STATEMENT:
If sea level rise projects are realized, project benefits could be reduced.

CSRA RE-5
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: As sea level rise is implemented in the design life of all ACOE projects this could affect the project cost. This risk could be mitigated for during the design phase taking into account projected levels in the design elevations. In the case of this project there is concern that sea level rise would cause the project to lose some of its benefits over time. This could be accounted for in the economic analysis. Within the risk model, considering the projects location along the bay, that sea level rise could in the out years have a significant impact to the project. This could result in major rehab of structures at a higher elevation or replacement of culverts with pumps. Even then the project may not function as initially intended due to saltwater infiltration and gated structures not opening due to higher downstream water levels.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Will additional NEPA be required?

This wouldn't be a negative effect, only a question of whether benefits were left on the table.  Because most of the actions are simple, assume "unlikely" for cost and "likely" for schedule any changes that would result in design changes that affect the degree of environmental impact estimated in the original NEPA document.  If there were changes, it would be an EA in the Marginal to significant time frame for USACE construction.

Change orders are likely during construction.

Mods would also occur in best and most likely cases, even that we do not anticipate anything different on these construction projects. CSRA was modeled based upon 5% against the contract cost as a conservative amount.

RISK_NAME: Implementation of new policy since project authorization
RISK_STATEMENT: Since the authorization of the project in 2014, new guidance on the analysis of comprehensive benefits has been implemented, to include all of the four accounts for all civil works projects, not just NED/NER (for AER).  This includes other social effects (OSE), regional economic development (RED), and environmental quality (EQ) benefit analyses that did not exist when the project was formulated.  As the formulation and modeling of this project are dated and the project is 51% constructed and contracts are 95% awarded, it is likely any comprehensive benefit analysis will be qualitative in nature.  This will need to be addressed in the 902 Validation Report before the 902 limit increase can be authorized, which creates a risk to the completion of project construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: We know an analysis will be required in the 902 Validation Report.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Most Validation Reports take approximately a year to a year and a half.

The current schedule calls to wait on the Coastal Hazard Modeling to identify the last two alternatives for plan formulation. 
If PDT didn't have to wait on the Coastal Hazards Modeling to identify the last two alternatives for plan formulation (expected December 2024), the schedule wouldn't be pushed approximately 9 months to the right.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
This won't have negative impacts to the project to be constructed.
It could be that the information provided to the PDT from the Coastal Hazards Modeling improves the evaluation and comparison of the alternatives. PDT will be able to better define the alternatives (project heights).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Adds approximately 9 months to the PACR schedule.
Engineering Technical Lead needs to verify.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
The current schedule calls to wait on the Coastal Hazard Modeling to identify the last two alternatives for plan formulation. 
If PDT didn't have to wait on the Coastal Hazards Modeling to identify the last two alternatives for plan formulation (expected December 2024), the schedule wouldn't be pushed approximately 9 months to the right.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT has delayed identifying 2 of the project alternatives until after the update of the Coastal Hazards Modeling. If the PDT decides to include a scenario that was not covered by the update in the modeling, rework and another round of modeling will be required. This outcome would delay the identification of these alternatives for up to 6 months.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT has had detailed discussions on the assumptions and limitations of this Coastal Hazards Modeling update. But cost limitations and other project considerations may lead to a scenario that is not included in the modeling limits of this update.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A Coastal Hazards Modeling effort requires about $100k.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A Coastal Hazards Effort requires about 180 days.

RISK_STATEMENT: Mitigation options may be limited due to lack of adequate acreage of suitable habitat to perform compensatory mitigation for the loss of wetland habitat as a result of project implementation. This could lead to a requirement to seek a policy waiver and / or out-of-kind or uncommon mitigation to be able to fully compensate for unavoidable impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Impacts have significantly increased from feasibility. The feasibility study already used unconventional compensatory mitigation for impacts to Bottomland Hardwood Forest with preservation, which is atypical for civil works. With the additional impacts and need for more compensatory mitigation over feasibility, the need for out-of-kind mitigation is very likely.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Difficult to estimate costs, but out-of-kind mitigation can be very expensive if we have to acquire real estate outside of the watershed or develop a program in lieu of restoration/mitigation banks.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Seeking out-of-kind mitigation could require a waiver from SWD or HQ that could take up to a year to acquire. Developing a plan with either out-of-kind or unconventional mitigation would add time beyond what it takes to develop a normal mitigation plan.

RISK_NAME: BCR < 1; at least shrinking from previous analysis
RISK_STATEMENT: Construction cost inflation typically outpaces inflation in benefits categories, so the BCR could fall below 1.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Overall US inflation has been significantly higher than historical averages since 2021. While both PPI (producer price index) and CPI (consumer price index) both have been rising, in general cost inflation typically outpaces benefits inflation.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If NED analysis falls below a BCR >= 1, then Comprehensive Benefits Analysis would be needed to recommend any project. Or, the project/study could halt.

RISK_STATEMENT: Excessive slope identified during PED phase for Atlantic Road Drive Way entrances flood side.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Coastal Hazards Data Inaccurate affecting Design Elevations
RISK_STATEMENT: There are significant differences in the wave height results between the 2022 and 2023 data and these differences vary across the system. The wave height differences are causing impacts on the required 1% AEP design elevations in some areas of the Port Arthur system. The impacts range from 1.5ft decreases up to 6ft increases to project feature elevations in some areas using the 2023 data.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Most of the 1% AEP still water levels (SWL) for the system appear to be very similar, at this point in the review. The largest differences are about 1ft higher from the 2023 model, occurring on the furthest inland extents of the system alignment.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Continued errors found in the H&H data far in the design process continue to erode at USACE's Engineering capabilities and Quality Assurance Review Process.

RISK_NAME: H&H May Impact Final ROW Footprint
RISK_STATEMENT: REP is already in development with existing PACR footprints. If final ROW changes as result of updated H&H analysis, RE may need to rework costs, footprints and narrative.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: At this time it is unknown if H&H will change the ROW footprint but, it appears likely there will be small modifications.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If risk is actualized, potential impacts will cause a delay of RE appendix for PACR.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate $20k for cost reworking, $10k for mapping and $10k for narrative.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: 30 days for appraisal, 15 days for mapping, 15 days for narrative.

RISK_STATEMENT: Authorization Requires comparable progress of both navigation improvements and ecosystem restoration.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Risk exists if only one component of the two is funded.  Currently some 25 ecosystem projects have been designed and are awaiting funding.

If funding is imbalanced, outside litigation could force USACE to continue comparable progress and the implementation strategy  laid out in the authorization guidance.

This is an avoidable risk through congressional education; ecosystem funding will require continued funding; some $60M / year (about double the current $30M / year required for steady state ecosystem investment).  The potential for litigation carries possible significant schedule impacts. 

Risk modeled in REF 27 which factors in a longer implementation schedule due to several risk factors.

RISK_STATEMENT: The modified plan includes structural measures that have significant impacts to Wildlife Management Areas (WMAs) managed and owned by the Texas Parks and Wildlife Department. Currently, there is discussion and disagreement with Texas Parks and Wildlife Department regarding with the level of impact to the WMAs, as well as loss of public-owned lands that would result from project implementation. Construction of the Federal project on state lands has triggered the requirement to adhere to Chapter 26 of the Texas Parks and Wildlife Code.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: More WMA is being impacted by the modified alignment than the feasibility alignment. Discussions with TPWD have occurred, but resolution has not been met. Additional coordination with TPWD is necessary.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional coordination requirements; attending meetings in Austin, TX; attend legislative meetings; modify alignment; modify engineering design of levees
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Negotiations with TPWD and working through the Chapter 26 process is likely to take 6 months to a year if resolution cannot be reached on alignment and impacts.

RISK_STATEMENT: Differences of opinion amongst resource agencies on level of indirect impacts associated with project construction. Lack of detail, data, and information regarding the ability to sufficiently analyze the indirect impacts of this system to the adjacent habitats of the proposed system. Indirect impacts may include impacting natural sheet flow and hydrology for all adjacent marsh systems, leading to an increase in significant habitat loss after project construction, and subsequently additional mitigation requirements.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Disagreement of impact assessment between resource agencies is common on major construction projects, such as this one. It is likely there will be disagreement between state and federal agencies on the assumptions needed to be used to calculate indirect impacts in the WVA modelling.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact could be minimal, such as additional time needed to complete the analysis and work out an agreement amongst agencies. However, overall cost impact could be high if indirect impacts are estimated higher to be conservative which would drive mitigation costs up.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Could add a few months to the analysis time and mitigation plan development.

RISK_STATEMENT: Archaeological Data Recovery is subject to a 1% limit of the project costs. The Texas State Historic Preservation Office has already requested mitigation of 41OR125 via data recovery and there is the potential for several additional sites to be mitigated via data recovery, which would require a policy waiver. It is unclear at this time if the 1% limitation is limited to the Orange project or would include Port Arthur and Freeport costs as well.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: With the current alignment, it is likely cultural resource mitigation will be necessary.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Archaeological Data Recovery is dependent on level of effort, damage, location, etc. However, it can be up to $1,000,000 per site.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Archaeological data recovery can easily take 6 months to a year or more dependent on the level of effort and resources available.

RISK_STATEMENT: The presence and extent of Hazardous, Toxic, and Radioactive Waste (HTRW) needs to be identified along the current proposed alignment. The historical industrial nature of the Project Area has the potential for HTRW impacts along the current proposed alignment. USACE policy prohibits the use of federal funds for environmental remediation on Civil Works projects; additionally, the GCPD has indicated that state funds cannot be used for remediation. Any HTRW identified might require an alignment change and additional environmental site assessments.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A subset of Phase II Environmental Site Assessments has been completed by the NFS which are showing concentrations above TCEQ regulatory levels. This is likely to occur for additional areas that have yet to be sampled given the industrial presence in the vicinity.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May require additional work for alignment review of alignment; alignment modifications; additional SOW development for follow up testing; additional soil testing; USACE review of sampling reports
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Could add a few months if additional testing and analysis is required

RISK_NAME: Now Middle Peninsula Unit of Machicomoco State Park
RISK_STATEMENT: DCRs original plan was for MPSP to be its own formal state park. Master planning began in 2010 and was renewed in 2015. This was the assumption and information the PDT has been using since the start of feasibility. In Dec 2023, DCR informed the PDT that the decision has been made to take a new direction; with MPSP being merged with the nearby Machicomoco State Park. Now referred to as Middle Peninsula Unit at Machicomoco State Park. 10-year Master Plan development for Machicomoco, including the integration of the Middle Peninsula Unit, is underway and will coincide with the feasibility study. Risk includes additional confusion due to the concurrent DCR Master Planning process and USACE Feasibility study, the name of the study (Middle Peninsula State Park), and potential changes in the use/planned infrastructure in the study, or the larger park as a whole.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Confusion due to the concurrent DCR Master Planning process and USACE Feasibility study, the name of the study (Middle Peninsula State Park), and potential changes in the use/planned infrastructure in or around the study area, is unlikely, but possible. Particularly with public input being requested during the same time period for both processes.

While confusion may occur, direct impacts to the project cost, schedule, and performance are not anticipated. Much of the existing Master Plan for Middle Peninsula is expected to be carried forward into the new Machicomoco Master Plan. It is very unlikely that the overall use (conservation and recreation) of the park will change and the goals of the USACE feasibility study (shoreline protection and ecosystem restoration) remain unchanged.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: While it's not anticipated that much would change in terms of the park's planned use and infrastructure, any significant changes could affect the proposed alternatives. For instance, DCR has stated that while both conservation and recreation are goals, conservation is a greater priority than recreation. If during the Master Planning process, these priorities reverse, it could impact the preferred plan as some potential measures for shoreline protection and ecosystem restoration directly limit recreation opportunities that may be important to the public and the sponsor.

PROJECT_NAME: Sabine Pass to Galveston Bay Freeport
RISK_NAME: Additional Levee instead of Gate at DOW Barge Canal
RISK_STATEMENT:
To keep the PACR moving forward, the PDT will retain the DOW Barge Canal 
gate project feature from the authorized project in the modified project for evaluation in 
the PACR and SEA. This scope could change pending the outcome of NFS and USACE leadership decision on whether to include additional levee length along the canal in lieu of the gate. Due to the considerable uncertainty around the decision to incorporate this proposed levee feature the MSC will strategize with the District to address this change with a document separate from the Validation Report such as an EDR or MFR if possible. It is 
possible that improvement of these levee features would likely be considered a locally preferred plan to the DOW Barge Canal gate. If the NFS elects to pursue the levee 
system, the team will strategize how to best complete that engineering, economic and 
environmental work concurrent to the work defined in the current PACR scope to inform 
that EDR or MFR. It is possible the environmental work will need to be included in the 
PACR if the levee system option is pursued.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The NFS would like to see the analysis for both the levee and gate for the DOW Barge Canal. The additional costs and risks were communicated. NFS is showing differing data regarding levee and seepage analysis.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could affect time surrounding completion of SEA; environmental impacts and compliance.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional SOW and budget would revolve around not pursuing gate option for that area of the project.

RISK_STATEMENT: External cost estimates suggest that Boone Siphon will cost over 300% more than the project was programmed for back in 2019 when the PPA was signed. Current funding of $8.6m is inadequate and WRDA funding at this time cannot support the total cost of this project and adjacent projects
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: WRDA funding CAP is currently fixed at $70m. This project sits at $30m alone along with 5 other WRDA projects. A WRDA increase to $150m would support this project as is under a phased approach assuming HQ USACE secures funding from congress. Current phased approach allows more time for WRDA change while staying under the CAP. Even with the WRDA cap increased there is no guarantee a phased funding approach will be approved for USACE.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Performance will not be impacted. The risk is all schedule based depending on when funds are released for the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There is no ability to descope the project further. The impact is how much work will get done/approved by higher, not how much more expensive the project could get as of OCT 2023
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assuming that USACE will lose 5 months waiting for additional funds to be approved for this project or up to 1 year if funds are denied until next cycle of funds request before next phases of the project can be started.

RISK_STATEMENT: Formal consultation with U.S. Fish and Wildlife Services (USFWS) is a risk to the PACR / SEIS . Limited resource staffing at USFWS and / or differences of opinion in determinations or extent of take could delay issuance of a Biological Opinion (BO). Implementation of conservation measures, reasonable and prudent measures, etc. designated in the BO will contribute to cost increases due to requirements for biological monitors, possibility of additional mitigation measures, and / or seasonal timing restrictions to reduce or avoid take and a jeopardy determination.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: USFWS resource availability is low, which may contribute to schedule delays. Given the suitable habitat for Eastern BLRA in the project area, it is likely FWS will disagree with impacts to this species and may require a lot of coordination to develop conservation measures and an ITS that is reasonable for the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May require additional coordination efforts and or field work to come to an agreement with FWS.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May add a few months of additional coordination time before can receive a BO from FWS.

RISK_STATEMENT:
EPA does not agree with FUSRAP's plans for areas to remediate at FS-6 and Line 1.
Specifically, EPA does not accept that some DU contamination (FS-6) will remain after remediation in those areas used by IAAAP/AO for weapons testing.
Similarly, EPA does not accept that some Explosives/SVOCs (Line 1) will remain after remediation is complete becuase the sites are inaccessible or because the contamination is attributed to a continuting source.
The event that will trigger the identified risk is EPA review of the FS-6 PDIR or the PDT's recommendations following review of the Inaccessible and Continuing Sources DSR.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
It is very unlikely that EPA will not accept FUSRAP's position to forego remediation in areas of FS-6 in use for weapons testing because the DU contamination is isolated by a layer of soil.  Thus, a Land Use Control (LUC) forbidding disturbing or removing the soil from the site will maintain protectiveness.
It is unlikely that EPA will not accept FUSRAP's position to forego remediation in areas where the contaminant of concern (COC) is attributed to continuing sources becuase instituing a LUC forbidding disturbing or removing the soil will maintain protectiveness.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Removing additional DU-contaminated soil from FS-6 or additional SVOC-contaminated soil from Line 1 would have a minor improvement to the performance of the project as there will remain some areas where contamination is present that will remain inaccessible until buildings or other structures have been demolished and removed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
SWAG.  
Estimate to remediate many areas at Line 1 or FS-6 have been in the ballpark of $5M.
The work required to remediate additional areas at FS-6 or Line 1 would be similar.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An estimated 18 months of additional time would be necessary to complete the required remediation at Line 1 and FS-6.

As knowledge gaps are identified or new information becomes available, the proposed measures and alternatives could need to be revised. If this happens after the CEICA, additional schedule time may be necessary to revise the plan formulation and conduct the analysis again.

Exact schedule impacts are unknown, but 90 days is estimated to cover potential additional labor efforts.

RISK_NAME: Removal of Existing Structures - Timber Groins
RISK_STATEMENT:
The existing wooden timber groins are deteriorating and no longer effective. They are also a safety hazard if the present condition, which will increase as they continue to deteriorate.

There are two options for removal of the existing structures: 1) Pull the pylons out completely or 2) Cut the pylons at the surface. The type of removal method that is selected may impact the cost and schedule, including permitting of the proposed project. The method would also have potential environmental and future safety impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is very likely that this risk will impact the project in some way.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Performance impact is unknown at this time and is dependent on the method selected. If the pylons are completely removed, this may have environmental impacts. If the pylons are cut off at the surface level, there is a potential for future safety issues.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impact is unknown at this time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact is unknown at this time.

RISK_STATEMENT: As MPSP will be open to the public in the future, it is important to consider public access to the York River in this area. While DCR has indicated that conservation is the priority over recreation, the intent is to provide public access to the water, for uses such as kayaking. The public has also expressed a desire for more public access and recreational beaches along the York River
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The intent is to provide a living shoreline, which balances both the ecosystem restoration and shoreline protection objectives of the study. There are many more nature-based solutions that may accomplish this, without the use of harder structures that may cause barriers, so it is very unlikely that the proposed plan will prevent public access.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Public concern that FUSRAP activities at IAAAP are causing harm to the public.
IAAAP (Army staff) concern that FUSRAP activities at IAAAP are causing harm to the public.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
It's very unlikely that contamination from the FSA, in the form of DU fragments in soil, water, dust, or sediment is exiting the site.
Dust contamination is monitored using air monitors.
Water and sediment contamination is sampled twice yearly and reported in a CY EMDAR.
Contamination in soil is removed from vehicles and the vehicles are scanned before they depart the site.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If contamination in any form (other than Above RG material actually being shipped to a disposal site) were determined to be leaving IAAAP, the policies and procedures for monitoring would be reviewed and addressed accordingly.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost for air monitoring, etc., is already captured in the remediation and FUSRAP support services contracts.  There is zero additional cost.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Key Assumptions:  
1) RAD contamination in soil and structures is a result of DU used in testing.
2) Long-term use of the IAAAP (the FSA and Line 1 in particular) is industrial/military.
3) The FSA is an active munitions testing site; therefore, munitions are not a waste.
4) IAAAP/AO has completed the demolition of buildings no longer in use.  Another phase of buildling demo's is not planned.
Limitations:
1) Water table at Line 1 can be as shallow as 10 feet BGS.
2) Munitions testing (and AO operations in general) take precedence over remediation activities.  Consequently, RA contractors may have to depart the site when munitions testing is taking place.
3) Weather.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Key Assumptions:  
1) It's extremely unlikely that RAD contamination in soil or water at IAAAP is from other than testing conducted by the Atomic Energy Commission.
2) It's extremely unlikely that the long-term use of the IAAAP will be other than industrial/military.
3) It's extremely unlikely that the FSA will discontinue active munitions testing at the site.
4) It's likely thatIAAAP/AO will plan/fund/execute another phase of building demolitions at IAAAP that may impact the FUSRAP areas.
Limitations:
1) The Water table at Line 1 being as shallow as 10 feet BGS will make it very unlikely that some contamination in soil that has reached groundwater will be impossible to remediate.
2) Munitions testing (and AO operations in general) take precedence over remediation activities.  Consequently, RA contractors may have to depart the site when munitions testing is taking place.  This is extremely unlikely to change ever.
3) Weather at IAAAP will make remediation work during the winter months very difficult.  This is very unlikely to change.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The described assumptions and limitations are currently accounted for in future planning and contract cost estimates.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Weather and test firing delays can add as much as 30 days worth of delays to each field season.

PROJECT_NAME: Lee County Conservation Board CAP Sec 204
RISK_NAME: Impacts due to Uncertain Bathymetric Data
RISK_STATEMENT: Limited Bathymetric data for this area and any information is several years old. Lack of adequate bathymetric data will cause uncertainty with quantities which will affect quantities and costs for selected features. This will also affect the H&H analysis
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The data that the team currently has is several years old.  The PDT is collecting limited updated data.  Knowingly using the older data is extremely likely to negatively impact the design analysis. The collection of additional data will help refine the likelihood of impacts.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential to add 2-3 months to the schedule to collect and process survey.

PROJECT_NAME: Lee County Conservation Board CAP Sec 204

RISK_STATEMENT: There are three major components of BCWPA, and we are at > 90% design for the C-11 Impoundment. There is some risk associated with the cost for construction. For the other two, C-9 and WCA 3A/3B SMA, we have < 30% design established. Maturity of design increasing the risk of needing to do more than one PACR.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: More design is needed to reduce the cost risk, or that cost may increase and we will need another PACR.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: We will have to wait to construct the SMA if we do the designs first and do not proceed with incremental PACRs. This would be a major concern because it impacts the functionality of other larger projects like CEPP.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is $775,000 for the cost of the PACR. The risk is that we will have to do another one in the future for each component, doubling or tripling this amount.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If we choose to wait to complete the PACR until the other two components are designed, the project could be delayed 4-5 years.

RISK_STATEMENT: Because the design is not currently developed for the C-9 Impoundment or the SMA, there may be another request for a 902 limit increase.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The design is < 30% developed for the C-9 Impoundment and SMA. Because of this, there may be additional 902 limit requests. As well, it is likely that if we do not complete this PACR, we will not have enough funding to complete the C-9 Impoundment or the SMA.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: A delay in this project will have major implications for other large projects, such as CEPP. The water will not be able to flow through this critical pathway.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost can double or triple if more PACRs are needed without approving this one.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The timeline of this project will increase to five more years if this PACR request is denied.

RISK_STATEMENT: Based on previous investigations related to cultural and ecologic resources, there is a potential for upstream impacts to these sensitive resources; however, the PDT believes most of these impacts can be addressed with mitigation. The cost for potential mitigation does not appear to be a deterrent (for USACE and/or the NFS) and this issue can be further studied in feasibility.  Tribal conflicts with rock shelter assets may exist and will need further consultation moving forward.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Work done to date by PDT have identified impacts to water quality and terrestrial resources which may require mitigation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Instream habitats include those in lake and stream habitats upstream of the reservoir and those riverine habitats downstream of the reservoir. Physical lake habitat enhancements measures may be needed to mitigate increased lake elevation if not considered a temporary impact. If pool elevation returns to lower existing elevations this may be considered temporary and similar to current operations. If manipulation of in lake and downstream water quality is not viable (operationally with/without new tower), significant impacts to downstream and in lake aquatic habitats would be expected and realized with no viable way to mitigate for them.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Adjustment in pool elevation can impact water quality within the reservoir as previously observed. Downstream impact from reservoir water quality occurred and could happen under future events.

RISK_STATEMENT: Based on existing authorized use of the project for recreational flow releases and the significant regional economy supported by the flow releases there is the potential for impact to recreation during construction. However, the PDT believes there are options for construction methods, if needed based on the alternative selected, which can mitigate impacts to recreation. The cost for potential mitigation does not appear to be a deterrent (for USACE and/or the NFS) and this issue can be further studied in feasibility.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: H&H modeling and operational constraints include the purpose of recreation within the parameters of the model at all times.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: Dredged material placement at Hampton Roads Beneficial Use
RISK_STATEMENT: Assessment of dredged material placement options for Anchorage F is needed. Capacity at the CIDMMA is limited and alternative placement sites must be identified; these include the NODS and the Hampton Roads Beneficial Use Project (Bird Island) . Risk type is implementation risk. If the Hampton Roads Beneficial Use is not approved, designed, and available for construction within a schedule that aligns with Anchorage F dredging, then it cannot be used for dredged material placement for the initial construction. Dependent on location of material placement/disposal, material in Anchorage F footprint must undergo sediment testing to assess if suitable for ocean disposal, beneficial use, or upland placement.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Both Anchorage F modification and Section 204, Hampton Roads Beneficial Use projects are advancing through the Study process at different phase and have certain risks.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The federal standard is to use Craney Island Dredged Material Management Area. Therefore, should not result in a performance impact.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The federal standard is to use Craney Island Dredged Material Management Area. Therefore, should not result in a cost impact.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The federal standard is to use Craney Island Dredged Material Management Area. Therefore, should not result in a schedule impact.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: Dredge material placement at Norfolk Ocean Disposal (NODS)
RISK_STATEMENT: Assuming dredged material placement at CIDMMA (primary placement site) or Hampton Roads Beneficial Use (secondary placement site) is not viable, the Anchorage F material may be placed at the Norfolk Ocean Disposal site (NODS). NODS placement will result in increased overall dredging costs, increased construction schedule, reduced advertisement competition, due to requiring bucket dredge and ocean-going scow plants. If NODS placement is required, sediment testing will be required to determine suitability for placement at NODS.  Testing would take place during PED phase.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The Anchorage F dredged material is planned to be placed at the CIDMMA, assuming there is capacity.  Beneficial use of the material is highly desired.  Therefore, the need for placement of materials at NODS is unlikely.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: NODS placement will not affect Anchorage F performance but may impact schedule and construction costs.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: DNODS placement will have cost impact; however, the costs are not known at this time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: NODS placement will have schedule impacts; however, the schedule impacts are not known at this time.

RISK_STATEMENT: By removing the degraded, existing shoreline protection measures (wooden bulkhead, timber groins, revetment, and gabion cages), the project has the opportunity to improve public access to the water and increase public safety.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: By removing the degraded, existing shoreline protection measures (wooden bulkhead, timber groins, revetment, and gabion cages), the project has the opportunity to improve public access to the water and increase public safety. The PDT determined early in plan formulation that all alternative plans would include removal of the existing protection measures, many of which are dilapidated and dangerous.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Removing the existing structures is necessary to ensure the proposed project is most effective, to mitigate safety hazards, and to provide a better opportunity for future public access.

RISK_STATEMENT: The existing wooden bulkhead and timber groins, likely installed in the '50s, are degrading and no longer effective. Not only are the structures failing, they also create a public safety hazard.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The public safety hazards currently exist and will only increase as the structures continue to deteriorate and the park opens to the public. This study/recommended plan provides an opportunity to remove these hazards, replace them with more effective, environmentally and public friendly measures, and significantly reduce the risk to life safety. This risk is an opportunity for improvement, rather than a problem
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: All alternatives will include removal of the existing structures. This risk is an opportunity for improvement, rather than a problem.

RISK_STATEMENT: While the land was purchased and designated as a State Park, it has not been opened to the public to date. A large portion of the land is currently leased for agricultural purposes. This includes a large area of land directly behind the study area, which has to be traversed to access the site. The agricultural leases may be impacted by the proposed project as a result of construction/access requirements.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
There is an existing gravel road that bisects the agricultural land. This road will need to be improved to handle large material transport and earth moving equipment. This access road leads to Area 2, but additional temporary access routes will need to be constructed to reach both Area 1 and Area 3, the marsh habitat on either end of the study boundary. To minimize tree clearing required, these new access roads and a laydown area, will need to be constructed in an area currently leased for agriculture. 

 Info provided by DCR as of May 2024:
1.) Current lease is set to expire on Dec 31, 2024.
2.) Typically, five-year lease agreements.
3.) Master Plan process is underway, unknown if intent is to continue the ag leases until the park opens to the public (date still TBD).
4.) If necessary, a discussion with the ag leaseholder about removing any portions required for the project from the lease can be conducted.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Should the project be authorized, the land must be unencumbered by conflicting agreements. As such, USACE will need to address what VDCR's plan is to provide the fully accessible land for the project. Failure to address the risk of a conflicting agricultural lease in the area needed for access and storage of materials/equipment during construction could negatively impact the cost, schedule, and ability to construct the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Should the project be authorized, the land must be unencumbered by conflicting agreements. As such, USACE will need to address what VDCR's plan is to provide the fully accessible land for the project. Failure to address the risk of a conflicting agricultural lease in the area needed for access and storage of materials/equipment during construction could negatively impact the cost, schedule, and ability to construct the project.

Estimated cost impact unknown at this time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Should the project be authorized, the land must be unencumbered by conflicting agreements. As such, USACE will need to address what VDCR's plan is to provide the fully accessible land for the project. Failure to address the risk of a conflicting agricultural lease in the area needed for access and storage of materials/equipment during construction could negatively impact the cost, schedule, and ability to construct the project.

Estimated schedule impact unknown at this time.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: Underkeel Clearance Impacts on Anchorage F Vessels`
RISK_STATEMENT: Per policy, the economic analysis takes into account actual operating practice.  The sailing draft of vessels calling on the harbor today is evaluated to determine the UKC requirement for the harbor.  The economic analysis assumes that the pilots will continue to operate in a similar manner with a channel modification as they do in the empirical data set.  So, if empirical data demonstrates that the pilots require a class of vessel to have a UKC of, say, 3 feet, then for a 55' channel/anchorage, the maximum draft allowed would be 52'. Tides are also included in the analysis and can be used by pilots if the timing is right. But the bottom line is that UKC requirements restrict maximum sailing drafts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Assess underkeel clearance (UKC) impacts on vessels moored or transiting through Anchorage F. Underkeel clearance (UKC) impacts on vessels moored or transiting through Anchorage F.

RISK_STATEMENT:
As of 9/14/2023, the USACE received data from the two largest users in terms of volume. The analysis can move forward to partially complete the commodity forecast, fleet forecast, and transportation cost modeling using the provided information. However, without additional information on other users, the study lacks justification for including additional cargo volumes and, potentially, additional project benefits.

To date, the study team has not received data and plans related to port operations. Specifically, the study relies on crude exports for economic justification. This commodity is not currently exported via deep draft vessels from Matagorda Ship Channel. Landside and facility improvements will be required prior to the project base year to claim these benefits. The study team cannot select the NED plan or TSP with a high degree of certainty without higher level of detail related to anticipated commodity movements through the period of analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Lack of data is a current issue.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is significant public interest in the project and project economics. Without defensible and verified data, the Agency is exposed to reputational risk.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Data availability was expected by early August 2023. As of 08 September, data has not been provided. Significant coordination will be required to clarify data and expectations after initial data and info requests are fulfilled.

RISK_NAME: Uncertainty in Commodity Forecast for Crude Exports
RISK_STATEMENT: Crude exports via deep draft vessels was anticipated to begin in the 2018 Feasibility Report. To date, no significant volume of crude exports via deep draft vessels is taking place. Significant facility updates are required to accommodate this new trade and the market is highly volatile and difficult to predict. Overestimating this commodity type creates significant risk to project justification and plan selection.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This is an existing issue.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Significant under or over estimation of benefits creates reputational risk.

RISK_NAME: Pending TCEQ Permit for Primary Project User
RISK_STATEMENT:
The primary project user requires an air quality permit from the Texas Commission on Environmental Quality (TCEQ) to operate and to fully realize the benefits of the project. The project is unlikely to be justified under any scenario without the benefits attributed to this user. 
The project user?s permit (Permit No. 162941) approval was ?reversed and remanded? back to the TCEQ for a contested case hearing on 30 November 2023. The timeline for this contested case is unknown, but similar contested cases can take as long as 3 years. The MSC LRR may need to make a final plan selection and approval without knowing the outcome of this case.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This event likelihood reflects the probability the team will need to make plan selection and approval without knowing the outcome of the case, which adds significant uncertainty to the decision. It does not attempt to estimate the probability that the case will be approved or denied.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the permit is not approved, the project is very unlikely to be economically justified and will not operate as intended.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Any change in the anticipated export capacity of the user in question would significantly change study assumptions, likely requiring rework for economics, environmental, planning, and other disciplines.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Any change in the anticipated export capacity of the user in question would significantly change study assumptions, likely requiring rework for economics, environmental, planning, and other disciplines.

We also plan to hold another public meeting after the Public Review period begins with one meeting in English and another in Spanish. We will need a registered translator and a court reporter. There is no standard process for completing/obtaining these services, which could cause delays.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PM is actively looking into obtaining these services, but it is not very straightforward. PM believes they have a path forward for the translation of the Executive Summary, but still needs to figure out the needs for the Public Meeting.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: RPEC has noted that by not providing these services, certain groups may choose to say SWG did not provide sufficient communication as required by law.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: As this is not typically done, there is no basis for how long this could take and no checklist for completion. The translation will need to be completed and verified internally. PM believes the translator and court recorder will need to be official/certified and unclear how to proceed with that at the moment.

RISK_STATEMENT: IEPR could take 60 days after the public review period of the draft report.  Right now, the schedule includes 30 days.  This can probably be negotiated with the panel to deliver within 30.  Risk seems manageable.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PM discussed with the Deep Draft IEPR lead - Kim Otto. In discussing the schedule, she specifically said IEPR could be completed within 30 days post-public review period even though they technically could take up to 60 days.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently have 30 days for IEPR completion post-public review. Technically, they could have up to 60 days.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: Contaminated material and required real estate interests
RISK_STATEMENT: Dredged material could have contaminants and require disposal at a private facility. Sediment sampling will occur in PED phase. There is potential for impacts to project costs and schedule due to the requirement to obtain a real estate interest to dispose of contaminated material in a state licensed private facility.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on the supplemental EA, there is potential for contamination in the vicinity of this project. There is currently no record of contamination within the project footprint, however, alternatives will include areas that have not been been tested and will not be tested until PED phase.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If contamination above the allowable limits is found, then acquisition of a real interest to dispose of material at a state licensed facility will be required.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the contamination is identified early in PED, there is potential that the schedule might not be impacted, however, if there is no planning of real estate acquisition of an easement, the schedule could be delayed by several months.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_STATEMENT: If utilities or facilities are located within the proposed project footprint, there would likely be a requirement to relocate those utilities or facilities.  In implementation, utility/facility relocations require extensive coordination, development of drawings, cost estimates, and the potential need to enter into a relocation agreement with the impacted utility owner. There is potential for significant impacts to both cost and schedule.  Given the narrow scope of this study, and its location relative to the federal channel and other anchorages, it is unlikely utility or facility relocations will be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A majority of the area being considered for this project is already in use as a federal anchorage or approach to the anchorage, however, the approach would be over the Hampton Roads Bridge Tunnel which may have a varying depth.  There are also at least two utility lines that may be impacted by the approach as well.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is potential for this to be a major problem if the tunnel needs to be relocated but the potential for tunnel relocation is low.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If both known utilities in the approach are impacted and require relocation, the cost would be approximately 1,000,000 each.  If the tunnel needs to be relocated the cost would likely be near the higher end of this range, based on the relocation of the Chesapeake Bay Bridge Tunnel that was recently completed.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The lower end of this estimate would be for linear utility relocation only with the higher end of this range for tunnel relocation.

PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This could result in study delays to coordinate, evaluate a Sponsor focused plan.

RISK_NAME: Harbor Sediment Unsuitable for Offshore Disposal
RISK_STATEMENT: Fine material from the federal channel will NOT be suitable for offshore disposal (per sediment sampling results).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: State confirmed no spills in recent history, per 2008 sediment sampling material had no contaminates.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Upland disposal would be a major impact to current planned execution of the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If material is not suitable for ocean disposal, this would be a significant cost impact as the material would need to be dewatered, tested, and then disposed of upland. Upland disposal has not been factored into current budget.

RISK_STATEMENT: Despite feasibility phase public outreach, closer to construction, public opposition could surface and hold up progress,
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There has been no public opposition expressed during two rounds of solicited input (associated with release and re-release of IFR/EA). Other beach restoration efforts around the state have had controversy - Waikiki and Kaanapali. Largely concerns were directed at the tourism industry being the main beneficiary, rather than the public.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Opposition could spin the narrative to reflect poorly on USACE. With a solid outreach and engagement plan, this could be overcome.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Will need to coordinate a public outreach engagement component of the PED phase
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If opposition raised to the serious level, likely would need a series of public meetings to discuss and address issues, and there would be a schedule impact

This review is not required for a Director's Report.
