RISK_STATEMENT: Environmental impacts to approximately 850 acres of Seagrass were identified at Placement Area (PA) NP-2. The team, with leadership support and direction, decided to not use NP-2. Instead, the SEIS will assume that the new work dredge material (that was originally expected to go to NP-2) will be disposed of at the ODMDS and future O&M material will be placed at the existing O&M PAs. Utilizing the ODMDS will require additional material sampling and EPA approval. While RPEC believes EPA and state agencies will support this path forward, we will not know for certain until we initiate the approval process.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While RPEC believes EPA and state agencies will support this path forward, we will not know for certain until we initiate the approval process. Previously, there has been opposition by EPA to this project in particular. RPEC still believes that the reason for increasing material disposal at the ODMDS, which is to eliminate the direct/indirect impacts to a large quantify of seagrass, will be supported by EPA and state agencies.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the ODMDS expansion is not approved, the DMMP will need to be revised and a supplemental EA will need to be completed, which could delay construction.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Obtaining the sampling results will take approximately 1 year.

RISK_STATEMENT: Environmental impacts to approximately 850 acres of Seagrass were identified at Placement Area (PA) NP-2. The team, with leadership support and direction, decided to not use NP-2. Instead, the SEIS will assume that the new work dredge material (that was originally expected to go to NP-2) will be disposed of at the ODMDS and future O&M material will be placed at the existing O&M PAs. The Matagorda Pilots have expressed concern about utilizing the ODMDS for material from the inner channel. Originally, the DMMP only assumed material from the Entrance Channel would be disposed of via the ODMDS. The pilots are concerned about traffic in the channel during dredge operations as well as the safety of crew and ships in the gulf due to unfavorable ocean conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: E&C is aware of the concerns and working to address them.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_STATEMENT: Identification of an Anchorage diameter of 3,840 feet reflects best practices and recommendations for conditions in Hampton Roads. Harbor pilots noted that the MSC Daniela would require a minimum of 8 shots of chain during high wind/current conditions, the minimum required swing radius would be 1,920ft, for an anchorage diameter of 3,840ft.  Current authorization calls for a 3,620ft diameter anchorage.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The EDR process could be used to address the difference in the currently authorized diameter and the best practices needs of the fleet.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The economic analysis will be affected if this changes.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Engineering Technical Lead has experience in drafting EDRs.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: FWOP definition and cost for alternatives
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT discussed defining the FWOP for Anchorage F as 3840ft diameter in order to evaluate the possibility that the anchorage diameter dimension could be increased under the authority of an EDR.  The Agency has determined that the project dimensions as identified in the 2018 WRDA will serve as the FWOP (3620ft).  As such, the overall cost of all of the alternatives will increase over what was estimated for an anchorage width of 3840ft.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: cost increase is unknown at this time

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_NAME: Economic benefits of expansion of Anchorage F as authorized
RISK_STATEMENT: A critical issue for this study is the economic benefits.  Dredging costs have increased considerably since the 2018 reevaluation report.  The authorized 3,620 foot diameter and -51 foot MLLW depth for Anchorage F dimension may no longer be justified.  These authorized dimensions were identified as the Future Without Project Condition at the Alternatives Milestone Meeting.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The identified Future Without Project (3620 foot diameter, -51 feet MLLW depth) was authorized by? Section 1403 of America's Infrastructure Act of 2018?.  Although the cost of dredging operations has increased since 2018, we will not know whether these dimensions remain economically justified  until the economic analysis ordered under Section 8223 of WRDS 2022 is completed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Calculations of cost and cubic yards of materials to be both dredged and placed have been baselined using the authorized 3,620 foot diameter and -51 foot MLLW depth for Anchorage F as FWOP.  If the authorized dimensions are no longer the FWOP, staff will likely have to reevaluate placement options for the dredged materials.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Calculations of cost and cubic yards of materials to be both dredged and placed have been baselined using the authorized 3,620 foot diameter and -51 foot MLLW depth for Anchorage F as FWOP.  If the authorized dimensions are no longer the FWOP, the cost of dredging and materials placement will increase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the Anchorage F authorized dimensions of 3620 foot diameter and -51 feet MLLW are determined to no longer be economically justified, Planning staff can adopt the existing maintained dimensions of Anchorage F (3000 foot diameter, -50 feet? MLLW depth) as the Future Without Project condition.

PROJECT_NAME: Norfolk Harbor, VA, Anchorage F Limited Reevaluation Report
RISK_STATEMENT:
National Environmental Policy Act Implementing Regulations Revisions Phase 2, effective date July 1, 2024; updates to CEQ guidance include Section 1501.10(b)(1), which states, "Environmental assessments [shall be complete] within 1 year, unless the lead agency extends the deadline in writing and, as applicable, in consultation with any applicant, and establishes a new deadline that provides only so much additional time as is necessary to complete the environmental assessment."

Based on current study timeline, it is anticipated that the integrated IFR/SEA will take approximately 2 years to complete.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: If the study area is more sensitive to SLC than the PDT estimates, when the PDT evaluates the recommended plan using all three scenarios, there could be issues with the plan's performance and/or adaptability in the USACE high SLC scenario.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The area is highly sensitive to SLC and many of the measures in the initial array of alternatives are not easily adaptable. Utilizing the USACE high SLC scenario and the optimizing the Recommended Plan significantly reduces the likelihood that the risk event will occur.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Utilizing the USACE high SLC scenario in the early stages of plan formulation and alternative development reduces both the risk of the event occurring and the potential impacts if the SLC sensitivity is underestimated.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential schedule impact is mitigated by taking a conservative approach to initial plan formulation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Project requires the successful integration of multiple different systems for success. THe most crucial is the operation and production of the pumps after installation. Without validation pumps may underperform or fail to altogether
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Without testing there is no way to guarantee the facility will function as intended. Fault is less likely to reside with manufacturer and more likely to sit with the contractor installing and hooking up the system.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The purpose of this facility is to ensure that it can handle increased rain coming from a 100 year storm. An inability to confirm the pumps can function as intended would mean this fault would only be realized when this catastrophic event occurs.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: At a minimum any failure to perform would likely result in a visit by a specialist to identify and correct an issue or potentially warrant a more deliberate teardown and replacement.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It could take 3 months to locate a replacement part or maybe one week to get a tech out to assess the situation.

RISK_STATEMENT: NFS does not own the land that the facility currently sits on. The proposed project expands to new areas also not owned by NFS and potentially imposes on an adjacent stakeholder's property.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NFS and adjacent land owners will likely come to an agreement on what land can be used, but it may impact the design and require some re-work.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Relocation and edits would only impact cost and schedule
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Project design may need rework to compensate for real estate oversights or land might need to be acquired to facilitate project progress.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Project coordination for RE limits is ongoing. Any rework required could set back the design stage of the project by 3 months.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Use of both Beach-FX & G2CRM - Overlap
RISK_STATEMENT: Use of both Beach-FX and G2CRM which will require appropriate accounting for areas of overlap. Beach-FX will be used for structures adjacent to the beach and G2CRM will be used for the rest of the back bay study area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is not standard procedure to use two models for one study, so there is not a lot of prior experience in this method to help inform how it works in practice.  However, other studies have used Beach-FX and HEC-FDA so lessons learned from these studies can be applied to evaluation of alternatives.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is possible that some benefits may be lost where the models meet, however, compared to the total number of structures in the entire study area, the number of structures along the model boundaries is relatively small, so if some benefits are not captured, it would not be expected to significantly alter the outcome of the economic analysis.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Parametric level costs used to inform AMM
RISK_STATEMENT: Cost estimates were ROM and did not include costs such as real estate, PED, construction management, etc.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Cost was not used to screen measures before the AMM.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Low consequence because measures were not screened before AMM on the basis of cost efficiency.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Costs are expected to increase after AMM when level of detail is increased.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: The construction and material market are both currently fluctuating from day to day.  Recent factors include COVID-related spikes and inflation.  Fuel will play a major factor in the beach replenishment.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Markets have been unpredictable in the last couple of years with Covid and inflation affecting costs.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Fluctuations in the construction and material market have the potential to greatly impact cost estimates. Depending on how the market behaves moving forward, total project costs could increase causing the project to be overbudget. The market has been fluctuating heavily in recent years due to COVID-related spikes and inflation. Fuel costs and availability of sand will play major roles in proposed beach replenishment measures.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost estimates completed during the feasibility study are a snapshot in time and the market conditions may be different once the project enters the PED and construction phase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost estimates completed during the feasibility study are a snapshot in time and the market conditions may be different once the project enters the PED and construction phase.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Numerical modeling studies limited to NACCS
RISK_STATEMENT: Numerical modeling studies are limited to the NACCS, which does not provide detailed analysis on wind, waves, & hydrodynamics on the local level.  Additional modeling may be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Lack of site-specific data. Other similar studies have utilized the NACCS data with no issues -- ex. Virginia Beach CSRM.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: NACCS data may not have granularity needed and then additional modeling would be needed. Which would add time and cost to the study.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: NACCS data may not have granularity needed and then additional modeling would be needed. Which would add time and cost to the study.

PROJECT_NAME: Buchanan Co Sec 202 Flood Risk Management
RISK_STATEMENT: Owners' contractor poor performance resulting in quality issues or schedule delays.  There is a lack of qualified contractors performing this type of work in the County.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Contractor used by several Owners has performed well but costs have been higher than anticipated.  Because there is currently only one contractor performing Floodproofing in several Sec 202 projects, he is only able to perform construction on 1 structure at a time.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Delays in implementing and completing Floodproofing may cause lack of trust in the program and Owners to withdraw from the voluntary program.  This could result in life/ property damages to those eligible during future flood events.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: On average the cost to Floodproof structures is approximately $50k above what was estimated in 2019 when project received DRA 19 funding.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Base schedule assumed multiple Floodproof construction activities simultaneously while current lack of available contractors requires construction one structure at a time.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

PROJECT_NAME: Buchanan Co Sec 202 Flood Risk Management
RISK_NAME: LRD requirement for Floodproof vs Acq cost comparison
RISK_STATEMENT: Eligibility to Floodproof or Acquire/ Demolish structures was performed during the Detailed Project Report (DPR) feasibility level study decades before current supplemental funded projects were implemented. DPRs identified the most cost-effective implementable plan for flood damage reduction in accordance with the Section 202 legislation and requires a comprehensive level of study and analysis to meet the planning objectives. Because of the DPR?s extensive level of consideration and analysis it is the District?s policy not to revisit the Floodproofing and Acquisition eligibility.  LRD Real Estate is requesting the District to perform a cost comparison analysis between the Floodproofing IGEs and the Appraised value of the structure and subsequent cost to demolish the structure.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: LRD is holding approval of Floodproof Agreements until cost comparisons are performed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This is having a major impact to the voluntary Floodproofing program and will likely result in numerous Owners withdrawing from the program and raising concerns with the NFS and Congressional delegation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Assume ~$30,000 in additional labor for 10 Floodproof vs Acq cost analysis. Additional labor for tasks includes: 
?	Survey and complete a Legal Description
?	Contract for appraisals
?	Government Appraiser reviews for each appraisal
?	Planning studies which include reducing financial loss to owners, maintaining Cultural Resources, minimizing social/ economic disruption, and most Socially and Environmentally acceptable plan for selection of most cost-effective plan.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Required new activities and durations added for Floodproofing:
NEW WBS    Tract Survey and Legal Description    160 work days                   Avg time to complete for Buchanan ACQ tracts
NEW WBS   Appraisal Ordered -> Received            90 work days                      Avg time to complete for Buchanan ACQ tracts
NEW WBS   FP vs ACQ Cost Comparison                  15 work days                     Est for LRH/ LRD cost comparison analysis/ decision
Planning Studies performed concurrently include: reducing financial loss to owners, maintaining Cultural Resources, minimizing social/ economic disruption, and most Socially and Environmentally acceptable plan for selection of most cost-effective plan
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: The risk is the potential to identify additional resources. The project will be formulated to avoid adverse impacts to historic properties within the Study Area. Determining the effects of the project on significant resources will require consultation, surveys, and the development of treatment or mitigation plans if necessary. Preliminary coordination with the NJ SHPO may identify the need for additional work as plans are further developed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: We have looked at the area before and know that is it unlikely that we will identify significant cultural resources that require additional work. Overall, there is low risk associated with cultural resource compliance for this project.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Additional Cultural Resource Investigations - This project is not expected to have more than negligible adverse impacts on historic properties. We have looked at the area before and know that it is low risk based on previous USACE studies. There is limited data at this stage, so we don't have all the information we need to make a definitive conclusion.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If historic properties are identified, the District shall determine their eligibility for listing on the National Register of Historic Places. Additional work may involve phased archaeological survey, intensive level architectural survey, sample field investigation, background research, or consultation. $1M potential mitigation cost reflects estimates developed for similar projects for cultural resources mitigation (i.e., data recovery, monitoring) that may potentially be necessary during PED and construction phases of the project.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If historic properties are identified, the District shall determine their eligibility for listing on the National Register of Historic Places. Additional work may involve phased archaeological survey, intensive level architectural survey, sample field investigation, background research, or consultation.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: Due to the scope, size, and complexity of the study area, there is a risk to the study schedule and budget remaining within the USEACE 3x3x3 guidelines.  The study may not reach a Chief's Report within 3-years x $3M of signing of the FCSA.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Study schedule and budget have surpassed the 3x3x3 guidelines. Waiver requested based on addition of two new study area (Keyport and Belford) following public meetings in May 2023; budget and schedule amended based on reaffirmed guidance of Class 3 CE and 80% confidence; and completion of environmental, economic, and engineering modeling efforts to achieve environmental compliance consultations, coordination with multiple townships, and development of a Recommended Plan for a large, fragmented, and complex study area.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Request to increase project budget by $2.7M underway.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Request to increase project schedule from signed Chief's Report original date of 18 Feb 2026 to proposed date of 11 Sep 2028 has been initiated.

PROJECT_NAME: Lower Rio Grande Valley Watershed Assessment, TX
RISK_NAME: Lack of time for agency coordination to get to SVM
RISK_STATEMENT: Not having enough time to coordinate with current schedule to get to the Shared Vision Milestone. Agencies in the LRGV and throughout the State have significant workloads that require prioritization of where they should spend their time, money, and effort. It is unreasonable to expect quick turnarounds and significant participation in a very short period of time
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on previous and current project work, agencies have been unable to commit significant time or resources particularly with very short notice or schedules
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
Resource agencies have extremely limited staff and funding and tend to focus on projects that will have significant impacts and are requiring permitting. Experience from other studies in SWG (e.g., significant focus on S2G but no involvement with CAP even when asked)

Lack of time to coordinate will contribute to poor participation and input by resource agencies and likely an incomplete picture of the problems and opportunities and poor recommendations (e.g., conceptual model may lack linkages to other resource concerns or areas of the watershed if the right people are not able to participate; recommendations end up not being priority of resource agencies and can not be pursued or funded)
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: No cost impact has been identified at this time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: No schedule impact has been identified at this time.

PROJECT_NAME: Raritan Bay and Sandy Hook Bay, NJ Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: New interim guidance received for Nonstructural Project Planning and Implementation. requires Feasibility Reports with nonstructural components to include a Nonstructural Implementation Plan. Interim guidance is in draft form and specific requirements for this study are TBD. This brand-new requirement would be crafted by planning, real estate, and engineering. Not having enough study resources (people, time, and funding) could impact completion of this for the final report.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Study schedule and budget have surpassed the 3x3x3 guidelines. Waiver requested based on addition of two new study areas (Keyport and Belford) following public meetings in May 2023; budget and schedule amended based on reaffirmed guidance of Class 3 CE and 80% confidence; and completion of environmental, economic, and engineering modeling efforts to achieve environmental compliance consultations, coordination with multiple townships, and development of a Recommended Plan for a large, fragmented, and complex study area. Due to the emergence of this new guidance, it is very likely that associated risks will occur.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential impacts and limitations to study designs and recommended plan. Additional time and money required to complete the effort. Estimated cost impact unknown at this time.

Consultation documentation for ESA and EFH can be deemed incomplete if insufficient information regarding impacts is submitted with consultation packages. This could cause a delay in completing consultations which are required to achieve environmental compliance during feasibility.  (What species are currently there, how will a new island impact them and their resources, what impacts will it have to water hydrodynamics within the harbor?)

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT is aware that there is evidence of Choctaw villages in the Parish going back to 1730s.  There are traditional sacred places in the Parish.  There are many Choctaw place names potentially indicating areas of importance to the tribe in the Parish.  The Choctaw have concerns with River Can being sparce and noted that indigenous knowledge indicates that cane was helpful in reducing flooding in the past.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Choctaw has already provided communications to be used for alternative development.  They have not provided specific areas to avoid though.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Unknown at this time.  Will be dependent upon structural measures and alternatives that are developed to mitigate impacts and whether those are located in areas that are of concern to the Choctaw Nation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  Will be dependent upon structural measures and alternatives that are developed to mitigate impacts and whether those are located in areas that are of concern to the Choctaw Nation.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  Will be dependent upon structural measures and alternatives that are developed to mitigate impacts and whether those are located in areas that are of concern to the Choctaw Nation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Identified that currently available models limited for pine savanna/woodland. Looking into approval of a species-based HSI model to evaluate pine resources.  Use of model is dependent on approval.  Underestimate impacts and quality of pine savanna/woodland in study area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Should have adequate coverage for main landcover types potentially impacted and if pine forest is going to be impacted then a model should be approved summer 2023
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could affect estimates of mitigation impacts analysis which could result in skewed costs for alternatives if a more representative model of study area pine habitats is not approved (Brown-headed Nuthatch)
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Have continued to coordinate with ECO-PCX, communicated the project timeline, and discussed use of model spreadsheets. If the model is not approved, exploration of multi-species models that have been approved will be considered and coordinated with USFWS and ECO-PCX.   Funds provided to get model approved.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Other studies have had delays as a result of model approval challenges; however should have adequate coverage for main landcover types potentially impacted and if pine forest is going to be impacted then a model should be approved summer 2023

RISK_STATEMENT: Assessment of effects to wetlands, hardwood forests incomplete.  Impacts if and how much mitigation is required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Rough estimates of acreages have been identified to date.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could affect impact estimates and mitigation requirements for the various considered alternatives.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Habitat assessment surveys planned to occur on direct-impacts fall 2023. If H&H modeling is completed at that time then we plan to incorporate indirect impact analysis and mitigation habitat analysis as well. If the latter two assessments cannot be completed yet, the team will use the direct impact surveys and analysis to inform estimates of direct and mitigation impacts. Due to on the ground surveys being required and funds being MIPR'ed to FWS, cost impacts estimated at $100,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimates of impacts could impact alternative selection and costs of mitigation associated with each alternative.  We continue to coordinate with USFWS, and coordination with state agencies related to impacts and mitigation requirements will increase through fall/winter 2023 to reduce risk and uncertainty related to impact identification and analyses. The current potential risk has been communicated with agencies and we are in agreement on risk management options.

RISK_STATEMENT: Environmental Justice Outreach, Analysis, and Compliance with Evolving Guidance.  A number of disadvantaged communities occur within the study area and it has been unclear up to this point what level of engagement was needed.  The team has become more aware of the level of engagment that should have been conducted around the time of the AMM (at the time we thought we were at an acceptable level of engagement given the stage of the project) and are working with MVN EJ specialists to better engage with disadvantaged communities. At this time there is still uncertainty on the number of meetings with the communities that will be needed throughout the feasbility study and therefore it is difficult to adequately scope budget and time for outreach and analysis pieces. At this point the team thinks the majority of the uncertainty falls in the budget portion to cover additional meetings that were not initially included in project budget; therefore, as part of the VTAM the PDT is requrest an additional $50k to conduct proper outreach to affected EJ communities.  No significant schedule impacts are expected and will align with existing schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The guidance is evolving and the team is relatively new to this component of the project.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time, but expected to have a minimal impact and within the contingencies of the scheduled.

At a minimum, I anticipate significant differences between canopy nesting, canopy feeding, and non-native bird species populations between WSC and the reference reaches.

RISK_NAME: Community Based Pine Forest Habitat Model
RISK_STATEMENT: Potential that development of a community-based model for pine forest habitats may be required by USFWS to assess potential mitigation requirements. There is time and budget risks associated with this. Development of a model could take a couple years and the cost is currently anticipated to be approximately $80K for development of the model. Additional funding would be needed to review the developed model and get it approved for use within USACE. In addition, there is a risk that mitigation costs could be underestimated during the early phases of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Coordination with USFWS has continued. Currently, USFWS is on board with the strategy we are taking for assessing pine habitat impacts. The community model is starting development so it would likely be available later in the study if needed to assess mitigation requirements.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could impact costs associated with alternatives. If pine habitat impacts are not distributed proportionally across the alternatives, then there is a possibility that the full costs of mitigation is not captured (if it is determined that the BHNU model is not sufficient). If that occurs it is possible that the recommended alternative might be different if alternatives were assessed with a pine community model earlier in the planning process.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently we have a path ahead with use of species model that is being reviewed for approval in pine habitats. However there is a risk that we will later be required by USFWS to seek development and approval of a community-based model if the species model is not thought to adequately estimate potential mitigation impacts associated with project measures.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently we have a path ahead with use of species model that is being reviewed for approval in pine habitats. However there is a risk that we will later be required by USFWS to seek development and approval of a community-based model if the species model is not thought to adequately estimate potential mitigation impacts associated with project measures; however, if a community model is pursued it would add upwards of 2-years in order to develop, evaluate, and obtain approval on new model.

RISK_STATEMENT: Development of the Draft Fish and Wildlife Coordination Act Report is a lengthy process that relies upon another federal agency and should be completed prior to the Tentatively Selected Plan.  Additional funds are required to be provided to USFWS for their involvement in the study including completing habitat surveys and completing necessary modelling evaluations.  Additionally, we must rely upon USFWS to be an active partner in communication leading to a draft FWCAR.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This is a necessary part of the planning process and USFWS is an active member of the PDT.  This is identical to other planning studies completed in Southeast Louisiana.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This is a necessary part of the planning process and USFWS is an active member of the PDT.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Signficant resources are necessary to ensure appropriate FWS involvement in the study and will impact overall schedule and budget.  Current SOW requests $120,000 for USFWS involvement.  Additional funds are required to be provided to USFWS for their involvement in the study including completing habitat surveys and completing necessary modelling evaluations.  Additionally, we must rely upon USFWS to be an active partner in communication leading to a draft FWCAR.  An additional $80k is being requested through the VTAM to ensure appropriate coordination can occur.  Additionally, an additional 6 months is requested leading up to the Tentatively Selected Plan milestone to ensure full coordination can occur.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An additional $80k is being requested through the VTAM to ensure appropriate coordination can occur.  Additionally, an additional 6 months is requested leading up to the Tentatively Selected Plan milestone to ensure full coordination can occur.

RISK_NAME: Completing the internal survey request for up. and mid. lake
RISK_STATEMENT: Data will accurately reflect the most current topographic, utility, etc.  Data necessary to produce quantities and cost estimates may be missing or inadequate.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past experience using GIS and other sponsor provided data.  On past projects, while walking project sites comparing available data with what is actually at the project sites, discrepancies are typically found.  Topographic data is usually provided for studies by means of LIDAR and flight data.   These methods do not adequately depict ground elevations beneath water surfaces or in heavily wooded areas.  Specific to this study, there are sanitary sewer invert elevations that are clearly incorrect within the GIS data provided.

RISK_NAME: Using no provided data from sponsor or city
RISK_STATEMENT: Using no sponsor and/or city provided topographic, utility, property boundary, road, bridge, as-built, and structures data. (No topographic/planimetric survey will be performed.)
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past experience using GIS and other sponsor provided data.  On past projects, while walking project sites comparing available data with what is actually at the project sites, discrepancies are typically found.  Topographic data is usually provided for studies by means of LIDAR and flight data.   These methods do not adequately depict ground elevations beneath water surfaces or in heavily wooded areas.  Specific to this study, there are sanitary sewer invert elevations that are clearly incorrect within the GIS data provided.

RISK_NAME: Site visit to meet schedule and budget constraints
RISK_STATEMENT: Site visits are valuable for designing and estimating quantities for utility relocations.  Not all existing data will be accurate and usually site visits help identify incorrect data.  Site visits also help identify items to be demolished that are not illustrated within existing data provided to the Corps for this study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past experience using GIS data.  When walking the sites, comparing available data with what is actually at the project sites, typically additional structures/pavement/utilities are found.

RISK_NAME: Relying on H&H for channel footprint and cut/fill quantities
RISK_STATEMENT: Accuracy of the cut/fill quantities is typically better when laid out in Microstation and using the Opernroads software.  Channel footprints are typically better defined using Microstation and Inroads rather than HEC-RAS.  Curves and channel alignment vary from what is typically laid out in HEC-RAS.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Past experience laying out channels and comparing HEC-RAS outputs to Microstation and Inroads outputs.

RISK_STATEMENT: Some of the areas where the  channel is being excavated out is already deep, going deeper could result in more utility relocations

RISK_STATEMENT: The purpose of the Wind/Wave Analysis was to determine whether winds were a major cause of sediment resuspension/shoreline erosion and if building new islands could disrupt wind fetches enough to prevent those damages. Factors not included in the Wind/Wave Analysis may impact sediment resuspension/shoreline erosion. These factors include fish activity, boat operation/recreation, and sediment loads from the creek entering the lake. Construction/placement of new islands will not prevent sediment resuspension/shoreline erosion from the listed causes.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sediment resuspension/shoreline erosion from fish activity, boat operation/recreation, and sediment loads from the creek entering the lake will happen regardless of project measures implemented or not.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Sediment resuspension/shoreline erosion from fish activity, boat operation/recreation, and sediment loads from the creek entering the lake are currently taking place in the existing condition. Project measures will not prevent or worsen this process.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Wind wave analysis was completed for Sabula project area. For most frequently experienced wind conditions (5-10 mph), the Lakes are not vulnerable. Lake depths control in Upper Lake ? vulnerability is likely due to shallow depths ? not wind speed/fetch lengths.


Reducing wind fetch/wave height through island creation/rock mounds should not be a driver of project design because it provides no additional benefit.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There could be a cost impact if additional rock/shoreline protection was needed to. Current design (in early planning phases) does not include rock for islands or along existing shorelines.

RISK_STATEMENT: The scoping choice is that to account for Econ uncertainties, the team has decided to request additional $50K for Comprehensive Benefits analysis and coordination with PCX.The economic analyses required for this study will be a significant level of effort, especially with newer guidance on comprehensive benefits.  The PDT has identified uncertainties with estimating the required level of effort for evaluating comprehensive benefits due to the lack of established methods and metrics. As a result, the PDT has identified the need for up to $50,000 of additional contingency funding to cover the potential for additional coordination with the vertical team and other subject matter experts as well as the potential for additional analyses. The team expects any additional work associated with this coordination and analyses to be able to be accomplished within the additional 6 months to get to the TSP milestone.  Flood Risk reduction alternatives that could prove to be beneficial through Comprehensive Benefits may otherwise be screened.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The team is aware of the new guidance and scoping to best of ability, but there are uncertainties
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The team is aware of the new guidance and scoping to best of ability, but there are uncertainties.  Ongoing coordination with the FRM and CSRM PCX throughout the life of the study has shown to increase need for additional information by the team.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The economic analyses required for this study will be a significant level of effort, especially with newer guidance on comprehensive benefits.  The PDT has identified uncertainties with estimating the required level of effort for evaluating comprehensive benefits due to the lack of established methods and metrics. As a result, the PDT has identified the need for up to $50,000 of additional contingency funding to cover the potential for additional coordination with the vertical team and other subject matter experts as well as the potential for additional analyses. The team expects any additional work associated with this coordination and analyses to be able to be accomplished within the additional 6 months to get to the TSP milestone.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The economic analyses required for this study will be a significant level of effort, especially with newer guidance on comprehensive benefits.  The PDT has identified uncertainties with estimating the required level of effort for evaluating comprehensive benefits due to the lack of established methods and metrics. As a result, the PDT has identified the need for up to $50,000 of additional contingency funding to cover the potential for additional coordination with the vertical team and other subject matter experts as well as the potential for additional analyses. The team expects any additional work associated with this coordination and analyses to be able to be accomplished within the additional 6 months to get to the TSP milestone.

RISK_STATEMENT: Endangered Species Act (ESA) / Marine Mammal Protection Act (MMPA) Policy Compliance - an incidental take authorization from National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) / US Fish and Wildlife Service (USFWS) will likely be required due to potential piledriving activities relating to Local Service Facilities (LSF), and the details required to submit a complete ITA application/request will not be available until the Preconstruction, Engineering, and Design (PED). Thus, a policy waiver will be required for ESA/MMPA Compliance extending into PED.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A float system being implemented as an LSF should an Action Alternative be implemented is very likely. Float system construction will include pile driving activities. Due to the abundance of MMPA species, the likelihood that construction would shutdown to avoid Level A/B Take of such species would be high. The Incidental Take Authorization (ITA) is required to continue work in such cases to the extent requested and approved by NMFS/USFWS. This will be mitigated by the risk response implementation.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Without an ITA, no take of any MMPA species would be allowed. Should take occur without an ITA, the project will not be within compliant with the MMPA.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If a policy waiver is not attained for ESA/MMPA compliance extension into PED, there is a high likelihood of rework and additional labor that would result in impacts to the budget due to when critical information will become available. Without such information that would not be developed until PED, the other Federal Agencies (USFWS and NMFS) may not consider the application package for an Incidental Take Authorization or consider formal consultation to have begun and lead to non-compliance regardless of USACE policy at the end of the study.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If a policy waiver is not attained for ESA/MMPA compliance extension into PED, there is a high likelihood of rework and or delay that would result in impacts to the schedule due to when critical information will become available. Without such information that would not be developed until PED, the other Federal Agencies (USFWS and NMFS) may not consider the application package for an ITA or consider formal consultation to have begun and lead to non-compliance regardless of USACE policy by the end of the study.

RISK_STATEMENT: The Environmental Stakeholder Working Group (ESWG) was established to create a platform for community members with environmental background (e.g., self-interest, experience, roles, education) to share data/research with USACE as well as be more involved in the Integrated Feasibility Report and National Environmental Policy Act Document (IFR/NEPA Document) development prior to release of the draft report for public/agency comment. This group includes representatives from Tribes and local, State, and Federal organizations as well as individuals from Homer, Alaska, and communities near Kachemak Bay. Group's focus is environmental resources. This risk can range from a highly beneficial risk to extremely detrimental risk for the project depending on management of ESWG communities and activities as well as recordkeeping. Being inconsistent and/or not being prudent with information shared can lead to issues later on and should be managed to avoid negative risks from being triggered. Proper management and recording keeping will maintain this group as a positive risk as it should (1) inform the environmental background/impacts (2) alleviate potential comments during public /agency review and comment period for the draft report, and (3) mitigate adverse opinions/perspectives of the environmental member of the community through active engagement.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This group will have either be a positive or negative risk upon the completion of the planning phase and wholly is dependent on how the group is managed and how the individual members take part.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the group works as it was intended: this group could allow US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) to gain valuable environmental information from the community as it relates to experience, data, and research from individuals; local, State, and Federal agencies; and Tribes; furthermore, it could alleviate aversion in the community to the study/potential project.  If the group does not work as intended: aversion to the study/project could increase and the community may loss trust in the City of Homer and USACE.

RISK_STATEMENT: Potential for backwater during seasonal flood into excavation area.  Once channel plug is breached, flood events could wash out treatments, leading to rework.  Potential for deposition of silt during flood events.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Could impact in work stoppages while waiting for water to recede. Potential for excavation for cleaning sediment deposits from flood events. Potential for rework of some treatments. Any excavated slope without treatment could have failures after a flood event. Few days per event. Maybe month per year. Likelihood probably once per year. TPR assumed 50% likely per year for binomial distribution. Assumed $100k/1 mo. per event.

DEC-2022 Update:  The base estimate/schedule does not include cost or time for this event if it were to occur.  Absolute worst case could be before the pump station is completed and it could damage equipment which is costly and has long lead times.
BC:  1-event per construction season with 1-WK delay + $10k cleanup costs + additional standby time + FOOH + EDC + CM
WC:  3-event per construction season with 2-WK delay + $50k cleanup costs + additional standby time + FOOH + EDC + CM = 6-MO heavy burn-rate impact + 6-MO impact to schedule at smaller burn-rate
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Medium risk level on impact of the cost.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: High risk level for the project schedule between -3.0 months and 2.0 months.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_NAME: Fill Volume Exceeds Available Borrow / On-Site vs. Off-Site
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT's primary concern is that variances might be observed between the estimated quantities for fill requirements and/or available borrow material.  Should either of these come to fruition, impacts to the project cost and time would include additional borrow site acquisition and development, greater hauling distances, additional temporary structures such as river crossings, etc.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Current plan is to acquire land need to generate 200% of estimated fill. Unlikely for quantities to exceed 200% of estimated. As contingency areas are used, further contingency areas will be identified. Negligible impact to cost and schedule.

DEC-2022 Update: Current quantity estimates only show 5% contingency on available borrow quantities (random & impervious).  PDT is concerned that available fill/borrow will not be enough to meet project needs specifically for the impervious coming from channel excavation.  Plan moving forward is to identify an additional borrow source as a "backup" source, or to use fill from lagoon to supplement total borrow/fill material.  Current bid schedule is showing 571,900 total cubic yards fill needed, however this might not leave much "excess" in the borrow site, leaving concern that fill will run out before project is complete. Moving forward, PDT will work towards identifying an alternate borrow site as a backup source.  Bid items 60-66 currently capture borrow/fill costs, and total approximately $8M.  Primary concern with identifying an alternate source is haul distance, resulting in greater costs associated with fill/borrow.  PDT does not have any schedule concern related to this item.  Could also try to find a local supplier.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Medium risk level on project costs.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Kachemak Bay is an estuary with important, diverse habitat and a wide range of species, many of which are protected under Endangered Species Act (ESA), Marine Mammal Protection Act (MMPA), Migratory Bird Treaty Act (MBTA), Magnuson-Stevens Fishery Conservation and Management Act (MSA), etc. It is a State Critical Habitat Area, Cook Inlet Beluga Whale Critical Habitat, and Important Bird Areas with essential fish habitat, special aquatic sites, floodplains, and connections to anadromous waters. Impacts to these important areas and processes (i.e., sediment circulation) should be avoidance and/or minimized to the extent practicable for any alternative selected or there is risk of public aversion.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is risk to the schedule should the alternatives extend into the Kachemak Bay State Critical Habitat Area as this would entail additional coordination with State agencies.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Any environmental impact beyond what is necessary will be highly controversial to the environmental community impacted/concerned with this study/project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The location, type of construction activities, materials, size of the alternatives and more will lead to impacts to various resources. The extent and what resources are impacted will vary, but if mitigations are not properly managed, this could add cost to the study due to compliance requirements for certain resources (e.g., floodplain impacts lead to a Floodplain Development Permit being required). This will take more money. Thus, anything extending outside of current direct impact Region of Influence (ROI) of the study, may lead to additional costs. With the current ROI, the larger alternatives will create additional work (Special Area Permit) if they extend outside the area excluded from State Critical Habitat.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There is risk to the schedule should the alternatives extend into the Kachemak Bay State Critical Habitat Area as this would entail additional coordination with State agencies. Depending on what alternative is implemented for design/construction, it will vary in requirements for compliance. Extending outside the current ROI would likely lead to additional requirements and/or modifications/rework of completed documents/tasks.

RISK_NAME: Impacts to Kachemak Bay Circulation / Mud Bay
RISK_STATEMENT: Circulation within Kachemak Bay and the potential impacts to Mud Bay were of great concern for the community and resources agencies (US Fish and Wildlife Service - FWS / Alaska Department of Fish and Game - ADF&G). Thus, impacts to the circulation and/or Mud Bay will carry significant weight and need to be considered a critical factor in determining the Preferred Alternative.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Circulation of sediment transport in Kachemak Bay is an important physical feature that impacts various biological features with the Kachemak Bay State Critical Habitat Area. Impacts to this would cause public discontent and likely involved additional coordination with ADF&G.

RISK_NAME: Rejection of dredged material placement site
RISK_STATEMENT: A dredge material management plan will be required for the alternates. It is important to identify the most cost effective and environmentally acceptable management method of the dredged material, and this will occur after TSP. Management of the dredged material will include consideration of beneficial use. Construction and dredging operations may impact marine mammals that reside in the area. Standard protocol will be followed to mitigate any potential adverse effects, and placement/disposal site will require coordination/consultation with the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Alaska Department of Environmental Conservation (ADEC) for approval and subsequent Clean Water Act (CWA) Section 401 Water Quality Certificate (WQC).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Rejection will wholly depend on supporting data/site characteristics to determine suitability of dredge material with the proposed dredged material placement/disposal site(s) and when the Clean Water Act (CWA) 404(b)(1) report and 401 Water Quality Certificate are required by policy. Tier 1 analysis will need to be conducted in order to determine likelihood of contamination and type of sediment at the site to inform if and to what extent chemical and sediment sampling and analysis will be required. The placement/disposal site will also need to be characterized in order to determine compatibility of dredged material placement/disposal. EPA/ADEC could reject placement/disposal until US Army Corps of Engineers (USACE) gains enough data on material and sites to confirm suitability, which informs the CWA Section 404(b)(1) Report and subsequent 401 WQC application. If a policy waiver was attained to push CWA 404(b)(1) and 401 WQC into PED, this risk would be 0% probability.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the dredging of the dredge prism and/or placement/disposal site are not approved by ADEC/EPA, then ADEC is unlikely to issue a CWA Section 401 WQC for the project. This would make the project not compliant with CWA and prevent dredging which is essential for a large vessel harbor as the area needs to be deepened. If extended into PED, this would just delay Section 401 WQC issuance until later, but still be before construction.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If coordinated with geotechnical work, the chemical/sediment sampling required for dredge placement/disposal and extent of required analysis can vary in impacts to budget. If z-layer data is required, combining chemical/sediment analysis with geotechnical will reduce contracting, mobilization, and demobilization costs. If only require grab sample data due to new dredge work, there is potential only grab sample will be required and can be done in-house.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Insufficient analysis would likely lead to additional testing requirements and subsequent issuance of CWA 401 WQC would be extended into Preconstruction Engineering & Design (PED). If coring or z-layer is needed, will need to coordinate work during geotechnical analysis and that will take time.

RISK_NAME: Potential ESA listing of Sunflower Sea Star
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a possibility that the Sunflower Sea Star will be listed under Endangered Species Act (ESA). The risk associated with this would relate to the difficulty to avoid/mitigate/monitor take of this species and the high potential of delay that could be posed should this species be listed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Public comments were requested by National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) no later than May 15, 2023, for the proposed listing of the Sunflower Sea Star. No additional information known at this time and not sure what the likelihood is of it being listed, so being conservative, selected likely. Risk response will circumvent risk by inclusion as situation remians unknown.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If we do not include the Sunflower Sea Star in our ESA Section 7 consultations with NMFS, there is a risk that we will be noncompliant should the Sunflower Sea Star become listed as an ESA-listed threatened species.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If not included in necessary permitting/consultation processes in case it is listed, then it could result in rework if it becomes listed later on.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If listed, depending on when it is listed, it will impact the schedule differently due to the progress in consultations at that point in time, and whether public comment requirements already took place.

RISK_STATEMENT: Without proper geotechnical information such as a geophysical survey and geotechnical investigation (test borings), the cost of construction margin of error grows substantially. The breakwater and dredging entrance channel and basin design would assume worst-case scenario conditions for the site material. This would lead to larger breakwater cross sections with greater offsets from the basin, and shallower dredging slopes, leading to inflated project cost estimates.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is anticipated that the geophysical survey and geotechnical investigation will occur in Feasibility to inform the harbor design.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The conservatively designed breakwaters and entrance channel and basin is estimated to cost an additional $38M.

COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Low risk level on cost being impacted.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Likely a zero month delay, between 8 months and 12 months on low and high variance ends, respectively. This means a medium risk level on impacting the schedule.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: The MIKE21 model suite (MIKE21 SW, HD FM, ST, BW) will be used by the City of Homer's engineering contractor, HDR, for spectral wave, tidal circulation, storm surge, harbor tranquility, and sediment transport analysis. It will build upon MIKE21 models already established in the Homer and Kachemak Bay area, resulting in a time- and cost-savings as opposed to beginning a new CoP preferred model such as STWAVE from scratch. The MIKE21 model suite was routed for approval through the Review Plan. Additionally, DQC and ATR reviewers will need familiarity with MIKE21.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: MIKE21 is on the HH&C Coastal SET list as approved model, but not a preferred model. Brad Bird was contacted by the Alaska District in February 2023 to verify that MIKE21 would be allowed for use for this project's wave modeling effort. He responded that the approval process of MIKE21 would be to put the model in the review plan, and approval of the review plan indicates approval of the model.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost estimate for producing an STWAVE model from scratch if MIKE21 is not approved is $200,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is estimated that it would take 1 month to build an STWAVE model from scratch.

RISK_STATEMENT: The Alaska District submitted a DOTS request to investigate whether ship simulation can be excluded from the Feasibility study. This would include sending a ship simulation team to visit Homer and provide their assessment. The existing Homer Harbor has an entrance channel maintained to -20'MLLW, but the project is a commercial small boat harbor. This new harbor will be designed for larger vessels ranging from 80' to 225' in length and drafts of 8' to 20'. These are Coast Guard, research, commercial fishing, tourism, oil spill response, marine construction, geophysical survey, and landing craft vessels. The study is not looking at accommodation containerships or tankers in the new harbor. If ship simulation can be waved it would provide a cost and time savings for the study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: At this time the DOTS request for a ship simulation team site visit to Homer and analysis of whether a ship simulation waiver is warranted has been made. DOTS has not yet responded to the request, so at this time it is deemed unlikely that a ship simualtion waiver will be granted.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the ship simulation waiver is granted, this would result in approximately $500,000 savings to the project.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Ship simulation is estimated to take 2 weeks to perform and 1 week to implement any changes inputted by the pilots.

RISK_STATEMENT: Lack of site-specific data/information about existing geotechnical site conditions introduces significant uncertainty and risk into the budget, schedule, and performance of the project. Failure to identify and use construction techniques such as preloading with wick drains to address settlement have the potential to add significant time to the schedule (up to the magnitude of multiple years). The potential for increased quantities needed as a result of failure to account for settlement under earthen structures may also have a significant impact on project schedule and construction budget.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on existing information in the area, this impact is likely to occur.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The magnitude of the cost impact of this risk is unknown due to lack of information on subsurface conditions.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts due to unanticipated settlement of embankments could result in extended construction time and shortage of available material, potentially resulting in need of an alternative/additional material source. Use of appropriate measures, including pre-loading and wick drains, can reduce the time needed for embankments to reach the majority of their settlement. Depending on soil conditions, settlement may continue to occur throughout construction and beyond the warranty period, resulting in long-term maintenance costs.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_NAME: Real Estate Requirements on Other Federal Lands
RISK_STATEMENT: Selecting a plan that requires real estate acquisition on other federal lands would complicate agency approval, potentially violate Corps policy, and impede authorization of a recommended plan by Congress.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a checkerboard pattern of land ownership under and around the Salton Sea, which makes formulating meaningful alternatives that avoid federal lands challenging. Alternatives that focus elsewhere in the watershed (i.e., along the tributaries) would not adequately address the scale of the problem or satisfy the objectives of the study.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Any recommended plan that requires real estate on other federal agency land would not be policy compliant, which would prevent that plan from being authorized, funded, and constructed. Ecosystem degradation at the Salton Sea would exacerbate and persist.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Issues at the Salton Sea are highly visible and controversial. Although different groups support different potential solutions, each group likely agrees that there have been too many studies with not enough action. A vocal group in the community strongly favors water importation solutions. This makes the transparency of the USACE study process and the robustness of a Recommended Plan important.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Lack of public support is likely if the decision document does not transparently show the planning process and/or include a robust set of final array alternatives that include solutions put forth and supported by community groups.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The consequences of losing public support could be high for both the Corps and our Partners. Consequences could include reputational damage to our respective agencies as well as a recommended plan not receiving funding because community and community leadership do not support it.

PROJECT_NAME: Atlantic Coast New York South Shore of Long Island Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Additional surveys and data will need to be collected
RISK_STATEMENT: Existing bathymetric, geotechnical, and ecological data is not sufficient. The team previously anticipated that no new sampling or surveys will be conducted. However, existing data is limited and it was determined that geotechnical borings will be necessary for nonstructural measures as well as structural. Due to the need for borings, we must also anticipate environmental and cultural resource surveys. Existing data where available will still be used. It is not yet clear how accurate the existing data is and the team must assume that some level of site work will be needed, however the team is unsure the time and effort needed for site work. A deeper inventory and analysis of existing data will be needed. Appropriate cost contingencies will be added. This may result in the need for additional time and/or money.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Not yet sure to what extent additional field work is needed. At the minimum, geotechnical borings and nonstructural surveys may be required.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Selenium is a naturally-occurring element, but because the Salton Sea is a terminal lake, selenium from the Colorado River concentrates in the Sea. At concentrated levels, selenium can be taken up in the tissues of plants and animals and bioaccumulates. It can impact the reproductive systems of birds and other animals. Selecting a plan that disturbs selenium deposits or could facilitate bioaccumulation in the food web would require sponsors to remediate prior to any Federal investment.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are known selenium sinks in the Sea.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Avoiding selenium deposits may impact plan selection.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is USACE policy that our sponsors would need to remediate properties before a project can be implemented, which poses a unique challenge because selenium will continue to enter the Sea through the CO River and its tributaries. Our risk management strategies include conducting environmental site assessments and avoiding known selenium deposits when possible.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Environmental site assessments may be needed to manage the risk.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Existing modeling for future inflow to the Salton Sea currently has a lot of uncertainty and low confidence. It will be difficult to predict future inflows with existing data given unknowns around local rainfall trends, climate change, policy changes, Colorado River management, and evaporation rates. This could lead to selecting a plan that does not perform well under future inflow scenarios.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current H&H modeling effort for the Salton Sea are too broad to confidently recommend a single plan. Models do not fully capture the changing hydrology landscape at the Sea with regards to climate change, water policy, and inflows.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Understanding H&H is foundational to selecting a plan that will perform as expected under future inflow scenarios. There is a risk that a plan may be recommended that will not perform well and possible reformulation will be needed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Selecting a plan that doesn't perform well under future inflow scenarios could result in needing to reformulate through a GRR. To mitigate this risk, the team proposes holding a water budget workshop with subject matter experts, collecting additional data, calibrating models, and modeling groundwater interactions.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: There are not suitable existing USACE ecological models that can effectively be used to assess the habitat in the study area. While several ecological models exist for similar bird types in the Eastern U.S., the models should be adapted to an arid southwestern environment, and additional models will be needed to cover all the habitat types identified for restoration. This could result in missing habitat types and inaccurate habitat unit calculations which in turn could impact identification of the NER plan and plan selection.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is high likelihood of potentially inaccurate measurement of ecosystem outputs since existing models are not adapted to the arid southwest. There also likely will be incomplete measurements of ecosystem outputs as only 2 of 5 identified habitats types are represented by existing modeling. Additionally, models do not account for water quality parameters such as salinity, dissolved oxygen, and other pollutants. This may only be managed by developing USACE models that are specific to the Salton Sea to develop habitat units.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is a risk that inaccurate measurement of ecosystem outputs could impact identification of the NER plan and plan selection.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There is a risk that inaccurate measurement of ecosystem outputs could impact identification of the NER plan and plan selection. To mitigation this risk, UACE could use a model created by the Audubon Society or develop new ecological models. Creation of new models is estimated to cost roughly $200,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There is a risk that inaccurate measurement of ecosystem outputs could impact identification of the NER plan and plan selection. To mitigation this risk, UACE could use a model created by the Audubon Society or develop new ecological models. Creation of new models is estimated to take roughly 18 months.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_NAME: Emissive Seabed and Public Health Concerns
RISK_STATEMENT: As the footprint Salton Sea shrinks, the exposed seabed, which has concentrated salts and pollutants, is picked up during frequent dust storms. The seabed particulates then are spread to the surrounding communities, which contributes to reduced air quality and human health & safety concerns such as asthma and other respiratory diseases. With existing data, there are uncertainties around how much alternative plans will reduce dust emissions and how much of the air quality related concerns in the study area are attributed to the emissive seabed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: With existing data, it is very likely that dust emissions will not be accurately reflected in analysis of alternative plans. The Coachella Valley is prone to dust storms, and particulates are picked up from agriculture fields as well as from commuter and freight traffic emissions. The Sea is not the sole source of air pollutions, so it is unknown how much an ecosystem restoration project will improve local air quality conditions.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Inaccurate modeling of dust emissions could impact identification and selection of a comprehensive benefits plan. Addressing public health concerns will be considered in the other social effects benefit category when evaluating alternatives.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk can be partially mitigated by modeling air quality. This could include measuring reductions in acres of exposed playa, measuring reductions of playa dust in the air, and augmenting understanding of the links between Sea dust emissions and public health in the area. Developing a dust emission/public health model is estimated to cost $200,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Developing a dust emission/public health model is estimated to take roughly 18 months.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_NAME: Alamo River pushes Early Implementation date past 3 years
RISK_STATEMENT: The intention of the Early Implementation study is to submit a Chief's Report recommending a restoration project for WRDA 2028, however complex site conditions such as: 1) additional consultation and cultural survey for Traditional Cultural Property, 2) competition for real estate and water supply with geothermal/lithium facilities, and 3) seismic risk posed by historic fault under project site may require more than three years to complete the feasibility study, thereby delaying the Chief's Report and missing the WRDA 2028 milestone.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
1) Traditional Cultural Properties may move due the dynamic nature of geothermal area; also tribes may not disclose the exact boundary of the property so that it may be avoided.  
2)There is likely more profit in selling real estate and water rights to lithium developers than providing lands for restoration.   
3) Assessing the likelihood and consequences of seismic risk on restoration measures may be timely and costly; developing mitigation measures or building rationale and consensus for low-seismic-risk alternatives may also be timely and costly
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The impact of this risk is that we would not achieve implementation of restoration projects that benefit the ecology of the Sea and the health of the local community on the timeframe that the ASA(CW) has asked us to achieve.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impact is dependent upon many factors including whether or not Alamo River sites are parsed out for an additional study or wrapped into COA 2.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Extent of study delay is a minimum of 1 year and is dependent on unknown factors. Further delays could be realized during the real estate acquisition during the Pre-construction Engineering Design phase

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: The Salton Sea is located in a seismically active area that could be impacted by earthquakes with epicenters located near project sites. The soils in this area have a high liquefaction and lateral spreading potential during seismic activity based on analyses performed on other projects in this region. Seismic hazards will need to be accurately identified and mitigated for as best possible to reduce the risk of structural damage during earthquakes. Seismic settlement and spectral acceleration may create design concerns when reviewing the alternatives listed in the State of California's 10 year plan. San Andreas fault originates in Salton Sea, starts where Brawley Seismic Zone ends, which is within the project area. High seismic hazard due to historical seismicity and abundance of active faults.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Faults and seismic activity in this region are well documented. Projects in this region have performed hazard analyses indicating that there is high probability of liquefaction and lateral spreading based on local soil properties. Foundation materials may be low shear strength and therefore be more susceptible to seismic loading. These conditions are expected to exist throughout the Salton Sea area.  There is regular seismic activity in the Salton Sea region. Construction requires careful design consideration.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Risk that structures could be impacted during seismic activities. This could be a huge impact to schedule, cost and public confidence to complete work. Ancillary risks include disposal issues for materials removed during seismic hazard mitigation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Incomplete project may need to be abandoned if soil investigation confirms liquefaction and lateral spreading based on local soil properties. Limited information increases risk of unknow seismic hazards discovered in feasibility and planning phase. If the desktop study indicated unfavorable conditions, USACE would need to reevaluate and determine if a subsurface investigation is required during the feasibility stage.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Incomplete project may need to be abandoned if soil investigation confirms liquefaction and lateral spreading based on local soil properties.  Risk that structures could be impacted during seismic activities.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Due to the high concentrations of salt in the sea, heavy metals and other chemicals, the soils adjacent to the sea and within the sea may be corrosive. Furthermore, the sea is currently estimated to have twice the salinity of the Pacific Ocean, therefore the sea water is considered corrosive. Project design needs to mitigate this risk to avoid failures after construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Information described by other projects in this region. Needs to be verified for this project but likely exists.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Corrosive material may reduce the ability of USACE to perform, maintain and operate any existing and future structures. Structural or environmental failures may also lead to a loss of reputation as well as public scrutiny.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: In the event the existing soil is found to be significantly corrosive, mitigation methods would not be sufficient for design purposes.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The entirety of the PDT would need to re-evaluate the selected designs and alternatives to account for corrosive materials. Significant delays may occure in the event the soil is too corrosive for normally available material and design.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Currently we are assuming Alamo site has the same Clayey soil as SCH to construct the sediment basins/ponds scoped for Alamo.  Without this condition export may be need, thus will definitely alter the cost estimate.  Currently we don't have enough data to support this assumption because soil investigation for Alamo site have not been completed. Soils may also have undesirable properties such as high dispersivity, compressibility, solubility, etc.   Riprap borrow sources need to be evaluated.  Location of nearest quarry with suitable stone is unknown at this time.  Distance of riprap quarry will affect construction cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: No soil investigation has been completed for the Alamo site. Salton Sea is an ancient seabed and therefore soil conditions are not expected to be consistent throughout. Variations within the alluvial layers may exist.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the assumption for soil type is not met, additional costs is needed to mitigate by importing soil to site during PED/CONSTRUCTION. In the event the desktop study indicates insufficient geotechnical data, soil investigation and laboratory testing may be required.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Increased costs will be reflected in PED, possible rescope during FS. In the event the desktop study indicates insufficient geotechnical data, soil investigation and laboratory testing may be required.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: In the event that the existing data is determined to be not sufficient, soil investigation services may be required, soil investigation services may add significant schedule impact.

Turkey Creek is very flashy. Pumps will not be effective. Cost for a second detention basin will be the same as the first detention basin.

RISK_STATEMENT: Critical Staff members leave at crucial points in the project. Turnover could happen during PED Phase.
