RISK_STATEMENT: The sponsor's water needs are greater than the Whitney reallocation study could provide. This can make for a challenging formulation as the PDT will need to conduct initial modelling in order to "book-end" the water needs analysis and determine acre-feet of storage conversion for the study.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact could be 0 to 90 days based on best professional knowledge.

RISK_STATEMENT: SWPA and USACE have different valuation methods to document hydropower benefits foregone. Reaching agreement on a serious effects determination will likely be difficult
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a high likelihood that SWPA will disagree with the process used to calculate hydropower benefits foregone. This is based on experience with other projects.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There may be additional costs with preparing white papers, re-doing analysis, and additional coordination related to the hydropower analysis.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There may be schedule delays due to additional reviews, producing white papers, and additional coordination with SWPA.

RISK_STATEMENT: Alternatives are assumed to release water through the turbines. It is possible for water to be released through the sluice gates.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Water releases are typically completed through the turbines. No recent example of water being released through the sluice gates.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Changes to this assumption could change the hydropower benefits foregone analysis.

RISK_STATEMENT: Whitney Dam is currently rated as a DSAC 4 as described in the 2016 Preliminary Assessment. Reevaluating the 2016 effort may result in a lower DSAC rating.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The 2016 PA effort did not adequately assess the overtopping risk. Currently, there is not enough freeboard to mitigate a high water event (1.6 ft available, 6.8 ft needed)
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: A lower DSAC rating could impact the schedule and cost of the study, if flood pool reallocation continues into the final array. A waiver from the Dam Safety Oversight Group would be required.

RISK_NAME: Flood Pool Reallocation as the recommended plan
RISK_STATEMENT: Flood pool reallocation is a viable alternative under analysis. An SQRA is underway currently to confirm the current DSAC 4 rating. If Whitney Dam is determined to have a DSAC 3 rating AND flood pool reallocation is the recommended plan then a waiver will need to be requested through the DSOG.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Flood pool reallocation is one of two reallocation alternatives under consideration at this point. Due to a DSAC 4 rating and large storage volume available in the flood pool there is a realistic chance that flood pool reallocation could end up as the recommended plan. Results from the SQRA are unknow at this point.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: additional coordination/analysis required for flood pool reallocation as the recommended plan if a waiver is required
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: best professional judgement as to the extent of additional time required for internal coordination. DSOG concurrence would be needed prior to the TSP.

RISK_STATEMENT: The USFWS has declined to participate as a cooperating agency under NEPA for the study. In their response letter, they acknowledged that declining  as a NEPA cooperating agency does not preclude their input in the public review process under NEPA or any other federal law.  In addition, they acknowledged their responsibility under ESA consultation. However, they made no mention of FWCA.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Discussions on the FWCA requirements have occurred with USFWS. USACE will draft the CAR with USFWS review. In addition, there have been discussions between USFWS and USACE on ESA consultation. USFWS verbally has acknowledge their responsibilities for FWCA and ESA.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: USFWS may miss out on additional coordination efforts, however, USACE and USFWS are actively coordinating under FWCA and ESA.

PROJECT_NAME: Atlantic Coast New York South Shore of Long Island Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_STATEMENT: ROE's will take both time and money to complete.  Nine months, minimum.  RE recommends additional five months to complete ROE's, prior to start of field investigations.  We have an estimated 130 ROE's for nonstructural.  at $5,000 each, estimated that totals to $650,000.  We will need four to five people pursuing this.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
Assuming the intent is 130 ROE's, the impacts to budget and time are significant.

Recommend additional five months to complete, before field investigations begin.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate $4,500 to $5,000 for each ROE.  That's $585,000 to $650,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Nine months minimum for 130 ROE's.  Recommend additional five months (150 days) to complete, before field investigations begin.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: The Salton Sea is a very large area covering approximately 350 square miles.  It will take a lot of equipment and man power to complete bathymetric survey in a timely manner.  Since the bathymetric is a critical path in the feasibility study schedule, project design needs to consider mitigating this risk to avoid delays in the schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: After consulting with outside Agencies and requesting quotes from Professional Survey firms in the surrounding area.  The average time frame to complete a bathymetric survey of the entire Salton Sea is said to be approximately one year.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Engineering disciplines (HH & Design especially) will be directly affected due to the delayed bathymetric survey data delivery.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Quotes have been obtained for cost to complete Bathymetric Survey for the Salton Sea watershed.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Site conditions of the Salton Sea may not be ideal for typical Hydrographic Survey.  Due to the size of the Salton Sea, Survey team will need multiple launch ramps for various sections of the sea.  The launch ramps must be suited enough for vessel launch and retrieval.  The shalowness of water near shoreline may not be suitable for vessels sonar and areas within sea itself may be too shallow for capturing data.  Project design needs to mitigate this risk to avoid delays to survey.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Nearshore data show evidence of shallow water where typical means of capturing data via vessel mounted sonar may not work.  There is no known report of any launch ramps that are suitable for vessel launch and retrieval.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: vessels, sonar heads and velocity probes used in highly saline environment is more susceptible to damages.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: specialized surveying equipment is difficult to procure.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT:
Site conditions of the Salton Sea may not be ideal for typical Hydrographic Survey.  Due to the size of the Salton Sea, Survey team will need multiple launch ramps for various sections of the sea.  The launch ramps must be suited enough for vessel launch and retrieval.  

Shallow water depth near shoreline may not be suitable for vessels sonar and areas within sea itself may be too shallow to capture accurate data using vessels.  Project design needs to mitigate this risk to avoid delays to survey.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Nearshore data show evidence of shallow water where typical means of capturing data via vessel mounted sonar may not work.  There is no known report of any launch ramps that are suitable for vessel launch and retrieval.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Survey data collection method has to deploy field crew personnel to gather data in areas where vessels can't reach.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Feasibility study schedule may be impacted because PDT requires survey data to initiate analysis.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: Project design needs to determine what Datum and survey control network will be used.  Trying to use existing control in a area of possible active subsidence may be problematic. Best practice would be to set and establish a new network, or at least verify any existing marks.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The sheer size of the Salton Sea and past surveys being performed used local control for their individual surveys.  Survey markers can be found with a little research of the surrounding areas.  However, the survey markers need to be all in the same Datum and new markers will need to be placed to create and establish a new survey network.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: To set up new survey control data requires field crew to complete utilizing USMART database.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: There is active geothermal activity within and surrounding the Salton Sea. There are active geothermal activities mapped around the Alamo area. The surficial expression of geothermal activity is expressed as mud volcanoes/mud pots which may need to be incorporated and evaluated within existing design. Mud volcanoes as well as their associated fracture systems will need to be avoided.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are existing documented mudpots within the provided Alamo project (provided 7/15/2024)
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: USACE will need to avoid designing and implementing alternatives on existing mud pots and areas of geothermal activity. Structures built on mud pots or areas of surface geothermal will create constructability and maintenance issues for USACE. Mud volcanoes as well as their associated fracture systems will need to be avoided.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional work will be required to avoid existing mud pots and areas of surficial geothermal activity. It is currently unknown if there are mitigation methods available to prevent or resolve mud pots.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional design would add impact to the existing schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: Imperial Streams and Salton Sea Ecosystem Restoration
RISK_STATEMENT: The active Salton Buttes Volcanic field is located within the project boundaries and is one of 7 potentially-hazardous volcanic fields within the State of California actively monitored by the USGS California Volcano Observatory (CalVO). The Salton Buttes volcanic hazard zone is a very-high to high hazard zone comprising roughly 190 square miles along the southern boundary of the Salton Sea.  Potential volcanic hazards are identified in the 2019 USGS Scientific Investigations Report 2018-5159 to include near-vent hazards such as pyroclastic flows, lava flows, ballistics, lahars and (or) floods.  Although available data are insufficient to establish the pattern of volcanic activity needed for long-term forecasting, high heat flow and relatively young age of the Salton Buttes attest to the potential for future eruptions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are volcanoes in the project area, they could erupt within the project lifetime.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Volcanic activity would cause unknown repercussions and performance is difficult to evaluate.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Volcanic activity would cause unknown repercussions and performance is difficult to evaluate.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional surveying and redesign will add additional impact to the schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: As additional guidance becomes available, the study may have to incorporate new analyses not previously determined necessary and expand beyond what's been scoped out already.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Previous experience with project studies.  Guidance is always coming out and depending upon the guidance how it is implemented could impact the likelihood of impacts.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Changing guidance usually leads to potentially substantial delays in the schedule and increases costs.  The Agency strategy could also become effected by the new standards of completing planning studies.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  If new guidance requires additional modelling, could increase costs for those models to be run.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  Unknown at this time.  If new guidance requires additional modelling, could increase timeframes for those models to be run.

RISK_NAME: Flood Reduction tie to Recreation Benefits
RISK_STATEMENT: How do we tie Stormwater mgt / Flood reduction to a recreation aspect that can help economic benefits?  Recreational aspects have been expressed as important from the Parish and incorporating those into FRM solutions will be challenging.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Request has already been made from Parish to evaluate recreation benefits associated with FRM measures and alternatives
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Must ensure that all measures and alternatives are focused on the approved authority to study flood risk management.  Additionally, aspects should be considered and even possibly included within comprehensive benefits evaluations.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  May increase time and subsequently costs for to evaluate measures and alternatives within the Parish that are not feasible.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time.  May increase time and subsequently costs for to evaluate measures and alternatives within the Parish that are not feasible.

RISK_STATEMENT: Per discussion with FRM PCX - If structural alternatives include LEVEE or DAM, we will need incremental risk to account for when a structure fails.  Incremental risk is the life risk when a structure fails.  Structural alternatives are expected to include levee and/or potentially dam measures.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Known measures and alternatives include levees as viable options for FRM solutions.  It is possible none of the measures and alternatives remain viable as shown in Amite that became a 100% non-structural study though.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The final product would have a small improvement on the human health and safety, life risk, by ensuring a proper risk analysis is completed prior to study completion and ensuring specific risks are identified and mitigated if a structure were to fail.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Minimal.  Similar PDT and review members would be necessary to completed incremental risk analyses and would not substantially add to the cost of the study.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Incremental Risk analyses are completed routinely, but do add additional time to complete.  Project study would need additional time to complete incremental risk analyses.

RISK_STATEMENT: Minimal information present for Tangipahoa Parish and likelihood of large non-structural plan will increase contingency on cost-estimates.  Additional time to complete and certify cost estimates and reduce contingencies in cost estimate.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Due to the limited available data and the high likelihood of a non-structural plan that is viable, it is very likely that this risk will occur, just as it did on similar studies such as Amite.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: TSP will not be able to be selected until a proper cost estimate is completed that includes analysis of the BCR for each of the alternatives to ensure appropriate cost contingencies are reduced and allow for a viable project to proceed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impacts are expected to be minimal and within range of contingencies.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A 30 day contingency is to be provided to ensure appropriate analyses can occur to reduce cost contingencies appropriately.

RISK_STATEMENT: Potential public health risk associated with utilizing abandoned quarries.  Potential measures include evaluating abandoned quarries for flood storage purposes and would require additional analyses to be completed if proven viable.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Early scoping efforts identified that the abandoned quarries are located within the floodplain already and would like flood under normal scenarios and would be screen early due to being ineffective as an FRM measure.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If deemed feasible, necessary evaluations and analyses would ensure health risks are mitigated appropriately.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time, but expected to be minimal.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time, but expected to be minimal.

PROJECT_NAME: FY24 Army Reserve Heavy Metal Mitigation

PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If LRL cannot keep the contractor on schedule, agency reputation is impacted.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact will most like be in schedule growth and not direct costs to the project. A fourth year can be included in a POP extension as a mitigation means to schedule growth.

PROJECT_NAME: Disposition Study Estelline Springs Experimental Project, Texas
RISK_NAME: Transfer of easement with no fee land process unknown
RISK_STATEMENT:
Process for transferring easement with no fee land is not fully understood by the PDT.  In addition, the easement specifies a perpetual easement to the Federal Government and it is unknown of the easement can be transferred to a non-Federal entity.
Additional new information:
CFR Title 41, Subtitle C, Chapter 102, Subchapter C, has reads ?DISPOSING OF EASEMENTS ?102?75.936 When can an agency dispose of an easement? When the use, occupancy or control of an easement is no longer needed, agencies may release the easement to the owner of the land subject to the easement (servient estate).?
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PDT is working to ascertain the correct process for transfer of easement with no fee land and to determine if the easement can be transferred to a non-Federal entity.

PROJECT_NAME: Disposition Study Estelline Springs Experimental Project, Texas
RISK_STATEMENT: Endemic crab species (Hemigrapsus estellinesis) was identified at Estelline Springs in 1964.  Species is thought to be extinct.  The species has not been observed since the initial collection despite an intensive sruvey of the spring in 1980.  However, species status is unknown.  Recent DNA analysis of preserved specimens indicated the crabs at Estelline Springs were likely a subpopulation of Hemgrapsus oregonensis a common crab of the North American Pacific Rim which likely was introduced to the area via rail.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: No specimens have been observed since initial collection in 1964.

RISK_STATEMENT: WRDA 2022 implemented a new cost share structure for disadvantaged communities in relation to the restoration and rehabilitation of Acequia's in New Mexico. With that we are in need of a new Project Partnership Agreement that includes the new structure if the community a project benefits qualifies as economically disadvantaged. The new agreement is currently being worked on and will be routed for ASA (CW) signature as soon as possible. Without this new agreement, current work on most acequia project is at the 75/25 cost share structure. With the implementation of the new agreement we could potentially award construction contracts at a 90/10 cost share as well as perform future works at this structure for those communities that qualify.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current PPA is routing for review and signature. If not complete, it's delay will impact contract award.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: NFS potentially would not have funding to cover contract award under current structure.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Cost difference estimated based off of current cost share structure vs. new structure.

Fed: 1,685,925.00 NFS: 561,975.00
90/10:
Fed: 2,023,110.00 NFS: 224,790.00
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Failure to execute this PPA will result in delay to contract award or potential miss.

RISK_STATEMENT: Available data may not include all wetlands within the study area.  Coastal Florida can have established wetlands within small areas (such as ditches) within even a densely urbanized area. After an initial site visit it was confirmed that the attributes needed to establish wetlands in the canals are present, even though none were present at the sites visited.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Small established wetlands have been found directly adjacent to development within the FL panhandle and other coastal areas. After an initial site visit it was confirmed that the attributes needed to establish wetlands in the canals are present, even though none were present at the sites visited.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The project will be adjusted to meet the environmental requirements and still achieve the project objective.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Cost impacts would be realized as part of the cost estimates, and uncertainty, of potential projects or during PED phase when site specific wetland surveys are done. This could result in cost increases from increased mitigation requirements.

10% of anticipated range of project costs at the time of the AMM have been applied and will be updated with the TSP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Schedule impacts would be realized as part of the estimates, and uncertainty, of potential projects or during PED phase when site specific wetland surveys are done, and additional mitigation and coordination would be required. The time represents potential need for changes or additional design and coordination with environmental agencies.

Rought duration provide but impacts will be updated at the TSP.

RISK_STATEMENT: Multiple Districts (SAM, SAJ, SAS) comprise the PDT. There is associated risk and opportunity with this. Opportunities include increased diversity in knowledge, coordination, collaboration, and shared experience.

PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: In this context, performance risk means choosing the wrong Plan. If data handoffs take extra time, it will likely impact the decision timing and not the decision itself, although it will likely exacerbate risks EHH-2, EHH-3, and PLE-1. Each of the risks listed could impact the decision Plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The majority of impacts will come from labor costs if the risk is realized, and more effort must be expended on tasks. Due to the multi-district approach, this may take longer than what is typical.

RISK_STATEMENT: Secondary site visit to be conducted to assess the existing sediment trap as currently it is not working as intended and to its best ability.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: During the first site visit it was pointed out that the sediment trap at the diversion is not working properly and that it may need to be replaced.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Design of a new sediment trap cost to include manhours as well as drawing preparation and execution.

RISK_NAME: Small structure inventory limits NED justification
RISK_STATEMENT: There are about 30 structures in the 500-year floodplain. Because of this, we could have a small number for damages in FWOP and benefits in the FWP. Combined with the high cost of construction in Guam, it is likely that the BCR will be below 1.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A site visit was conducted to build the structure inventory due to lack of assessor data. The planner and economist eliminated a large number of structures from the structure inventory after being onsite.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is likely that FRM alternatives will not be justified under NED. The PDT will have to develop and get alignment on OSE metrics related to life safety and community cohesiveness for an alternative plan to be recommended.

RISK_STATEMENT: A large amount of archaeological material was found during cultural resource surveying in March 2024. The area where the largest amount of material was found is the area in which the PDT has considered rerouting the Manell River. All alternatives will likely require extensive cultural mitigation. Cultural mitigation costs could lower the BCR and push to total project costs above the federal participation limit for a CAP 205 project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Failing to complete NHPA Section 106 compliance in advance of the next project phase could prevent the implementation of any project alternative. It is also likely that the PDT would need to submit a cost exceedance waiver.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The most effective means of dealing with flooding events (detention basin, channel, expanded culvert and berm) affect between one and four NRHP-eligible or potentially eligible sites. As a condition of concurrence on this project, Guam SHPO may request data recovery for all affected areas (potentially up to 7.2 acres). The documented sites have a very high density of artifacts, which considerably augments the pace of excavation, documentation, analysis, and curation. Archaeological documentation at this scale typically requires multiple years and millions of dollars to complete. Given our efforts to limit the project's footprint to only heavily disturbed portions of the site, it is unlikely that we will be asked to produce advance documentation and recovery of all archaeological materials impacted.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The most likely TSP will require the negotiation of an MOA to address impacts to NRHP-eligible sites. Additional time may be needed to negotiate the MOA. Furthermore, it is likely that some amount of data recovery in advance of or during construction will be a condition of the MOA. Depending on how many cultural materials are encountered, this could substantially impact the construction timeline.

RISK_STATEMENT: Risk is not having funds available to begin work when needed in order to meet milestones beyond the one that is currently funded. For example, building Future Without Project and With Project models.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Requesting sufficient funds for the study has been challenging thus far and is likely to continue throughout the study phase with varying impacts out of the PDT's control.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: N/A. Funding availability will not impact the final decision.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impacts will originate from stop/start schedule delays. In other words, if funding is not received and the team is delayed and waiting for a certain time period, it will impact costs (depending on the delay period).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts will originate from stop/start schedule delays. In other words, if the team is delayed and waiting for a certain time period, it will impact the overall schedule. For example, if the critical path is delayed by one day because a PDT member doesn't have funding to complete their task, it may impact other tasks and therefore the overall schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: Due to local laws and overall breadth of the problem both in and outside the current study area the need to keep the public informed and explain decisions to reduce the likelihood of controversy need to be balanced.  As the potential for controversy increases so will the need for public outreach.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on currently scoped outreach, found in the PMP, it is not anticipated that this will be more than likely to be realized.  Due to the Sunshine Law allowing the public access to potential meetings with the NFS it is more than unlikely that information shared in those forums would realize this risk.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Depending on the level of controversy this could increase the cost by requiring additional in person meetings with the public, which include additional preparation.

RISK_NAME: Lack of Sufficient Water Quality Data
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a lack of sufficient water quality data available to understand current conditions and therefore mischaracterize decision-making. This could impact our ability to compare current conditions of water quality to FWP conditions during monitoring. For example, water slowly drains into the Halifax river under current conditions, but if USACE implements pump stations, water may drain into the river faster which may lead to altered water quality that would be difficult to monitor and/or manage.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The Halifax River has natural variability and hydrologic conditions fluctuate depending on weather, natural disasters, natural tidal influences, etc. Based on this, it is unlikely that we will mischaracterize the level of impact from USACE action.

RISK_STATEMENT: The Non-federal Sponsor does not have existing bathymetry of the canal system within the area of concern. It is unknown at this point if the hydraulic model and resulting water surface elevations are sensitive to the depths within the area of concern.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact will depend on the amount of the canal system that needs to be surveyed.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact would depend if the survey is contracted to a survey firm or performed in-house using district resources.

RISK_NAME: Use Existing SWMM Model instead of Hydrologic Model Build
RISK_STATEMENT:
Cause that triggers risk: following the constrained budget that is policy compliant with moderate risk

Risk: Leverage existing SWMM model provided by the City of Daytona to account for drainage system and losses, and assume that no separate hydrologic model is to be built. If calibration is not aligning with observed storm events, additional tweaks may be necessary to the SWMM model.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
The study must be policy compliant but in order to save on costs the study must take on moderate risk. It is likely that the City of Daytona will be unable to provide funds to a study greater than $3M. To buy down the risk of lack of funds, the PDT will likely leverage the existing SWMM model and save costs on building a new model. 

The risk of using the existing SWMM model is the assumption that it is accurate and calibrated from previous development efforts of the AE firm(s) who developed it. This model will ultimately get imported into HEC-RAS V6.6 when it is released but no alterations to the SWMM model will be made.

RISK_STATEMENT: Implementation of a recommended plan including nonstructural elevation could be limited by the ability of structures to be elevated. Residences in the study area are general 30-45 years old and vary in their current condition. The ability of residences to be elevated has been a concern for other projects in the Pacific.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A structure inventory survey conducted in March 2024 included an assessment of which structures could be elevated based on the current condition of the structure.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The viability of nonstructural elevation will be crucial if a plan with a nonstructural component is proposed. Since there are a small number of structures in the study area, having even a small number of structures be ineligible for elevation could seriously effect the project performance.

RISK_STATEMENT: Elevations of structures is completely voluntary. There is not a way to know during feasibility what percentage of the homeowners whose residences are eligible for elevation will choose to partake in the elevation program. Since there are a small number of structures in the study area, relatively small changes in the number of participating households could drastically change the calculation of benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that there would be low participation based on the need for homeowners to temporarily relocate during construction. Many residents may not have the resources to secure temporary lodging.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the feasibility level analysis assumes 100% participation and participation is significantly lower, benefits may be overstated.

RISK_STATEMENT: Federal participation in CAP Section 205 is limited to $10M. The high cost of labor and construction in the Pacific makes implementation of many projects within the CAP particpation limit difficult. It is likely that the project would need to seek a cost exceedance waiver from the ASA(CW).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Many CAP projects in the POH AOR struggle to fit within the CAP participation limit and require cost exceedance waivers.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Significant time to coordinate and approve a CAP cost exceedance waiver.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It could take up to 6 months from submission to get approval.

MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_NAME: Leverage Existing SACS Data/No Coastal Modeling
RISK_STATEMENT:
Risk: Assume no separate coastal modeling analysis and instead leverage the South Atlantic Coastal Study Save Points to incorporate coastal aspects into HEC-RAS

Cause of Risk: Constraint budget forces PDT to explore cost saving measures and assume moderate risk
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Assuming the PDT moves forward with a constrained budget, leveraging SACS data is a likely cost saving measure.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Opportunity to save costs by not spending on a separate coastal modeling analysis.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Opportunity to save time by not conducting a separate coastal modeling analysis.

RISK_NAME: Conduct only Initial Modeling of Final Array
RISK_STATEMENT:
Risk: Save on cost by conducting only initial modeling of the Final Array, and conduct detailed modeling on the TSP only. The risk is that by conducting initial modeling of the Final Array, it may lead to the wrong TSP selection or low confidence in the TSP selection. If the wrong TSP is selected, the PDT will have to revert back and model/analyze the final array in more detail to build confidence, negatively affecting the schedule and budget. 

Cause of Risk: following a constrained budget to save costs allows moderate risk
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Unlikely that the risk will be realized because, in comparison to other areas to save on costs, modeling the final array is critical to building confidence in the potential TSP. It is likely that the PDT finds other areas to save costs.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Conducting initial modeling on the final array could lead to the wrong selection of the TSP or low confidence in the TSP, forcing the PDT to go back and model and analyze the final array again in more detail, which would negatively affect the schedule and budget and potentially blow the project's schedule and budget.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Only conducting initial modeling of the Final Array would save costs in the short run, but may result in choosing the wrong TSP or having less confidence in the TSP. If that is realized, team will have to revert back and model the final array in more detail, which will negatively impact the schedule and budget.

RISK_NAME: Conduct Sea Level Change Analysis on TSP Only
RISK_STATEMENT: Risk: Conduct SLC analysis on TSP only could raise concern around the lack of SLC analysis on the final array of alternatives.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Realizing the risk has potential to cause the wrong TSP to be chosen
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the risk is realized and SLC analysis is conducted for the TSP only, it may cause concern around the lack of analysis on other final alternatives and therefore a lack of confidence in the TSP. This could lead to the PDT going back to analyze SLC on the final array for better comparison and evaluation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Reduced survey (hydrology and topography) budgets may lead to further cross section spacing, meaning there would be more assumptions going into the model and less clarity in model results.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that the PDT will have to work within a constrained budget and assume moderate risk, however maintaining as much accuracy as possible in the H&H models is critical in a Flood Risk Management study and the PDT will likely find cost saving measures elsewhere to address this risk.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Using more assumptions in the model would result in less detailed or clear outputs. This could cause the models to be less accurate therefore putting the Agency Reputation at risk

RISK_NAME: Reduced Structural Feasibility Level Design on Final Array
RISK_STATEMENT: Risk: Reduce structural feasibility level of design on final array to save costs and focus structural design efforts on the TSP
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Likelihood is greater than 50%. Detailed structural design efforts are likely to be focused on the TSP, and the Final Array of Alternatives is likely to get less detailed structural design effort to save costs. It is also likely that the final array becomes a combination of overlapping measures (i.e. dry reservoir; dry reservoir + surge barrier), so the PDT will have a general idea of which Alternatives will likely need more structural design than others given the nature of the alternatives.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Realized risk could cause the PDT to have to go back and conduct structural feasibility on other Final Array Alternatives if the wrong TSP is chosen, but it is unlikely that the wrong TSP gets chosen because of this risk alone.

PROJECT_NAME: Sabine Pass to Galveston Bay - Orange PACR
RISK_STATEMENT:
Ongoing tech & policy reviews may not agree w/our IDA findings. What is minimal v what needs to be justified.
EM_1110_2_1413_Hydrologics_Interior_2018_08_24, Section 3-3. Hydrologic Engineering Requirements for Interior Area Planning Studies.
The hydrologic study strategy is formulated on the premise that interior facilities (that will be a component of the recommended plan) will be planned and evaluated separately (incrementally) from the line-of-protection project. The major project feature (levee/floodwall) is conceptually divided from the planned interior facilities by initially evaluating a "minimum" interior facility considered integral to the line-of-protection. If a levee/floodwall is in existence, the minimum interior facility is presently in place, and no special efforts are required to establish the separation. If a levee is being proposed (planned), the minimum facility must be formulated and the evaluation of the line-of-protection benefits performed with the facility in place. The residual interior flooding problem is the target of the interior facility planning efforts, and benefits attributable to the increased interior facilities will be the reduction in the residual damage. 
(2) The minimum facilities are intended to be the starting point from which additional interior facilities planning will begin. The criteria suggested below for determining the minimum facility are intended to yield facilities that can be quickly and easily determined. The facilities will, with rare exception, be found inadequate upon further interior facility planning; thus, increased facilities will be formulated, evaluated, and included as a component of the recommended line-of-protection plan that is, in turn, an incrementally justified component of the overall flood control project. It is expected that the interior facilities included in the final plan will provide interior area flood relief for residual flooding.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Actual risk likelihood is unknown but it is a possibility.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the IDA is deemed incorrect, the H&H will have to be reviewed for technical feasibility & the IDA rerun per technical review comments. Could have to reformulate measures / redesign for interior drainage / residual risk.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on how long it's taken to do the current IDA, including reviewing the SOW & the actual modeling, 6 months is a SWAG.

RISK_NAME: Lack of Cultural Resource Surveys and The Known Presence
RISK_STATEMENT: The presence of cultural resources may impact the planning and implementation of the project features and measures by reducing the actions in the area if resources are found upon survey. . No portion of Blackhawk Island has been surveyed, however; an unevaluated historic, abandoned railroad bridge runs east-west along the central portion of the island. Only small sections of Johnson Island have been surveyed, and contain a single documented archaeological site, 13DM1185, a remnant historic farm identified in 2009. The Iowa River Delta portion of the Project contains multiple historic properties.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely we will encounter cultural resources upon survey in areas we intend to implement habitat restoration measures.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If cultural resources are prevalent enough to prevent work from occurring across wide portions of the Study area the measures may not offer the same level of connectivity that are to be desired and could lead to sub-optimal performance of restoration efforts.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If we encounter cultural resources in areas we intend to do restoration measures the team would likely practice avoidance and therefore not impact cost of the Study/Project in a negative way.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The results of the surveys will not cause excessive schedule impacts to planning and feasibility phase due to the established programmatic agreement in place. If further surveys are required prior to construction another phase's schedule may be impacted.

RISK_STATEMENT: Until the project footprint and measures/features are finalized (including any dredging sites, borrow, disposal, staging, access, etc.), and all required land interest documentation is compared against project needs, there is a risk that we may need to re-draw/reconsider the project measures and/or their location(s) to stay within the available real estate rights.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: Many forest communities are mature and forest health may change from surveyed conditions. Forests aging as well as continued events (flood/drought) between now and when work is completed could change existing forestry conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Mass mortality events in recent history. Nontypical flood years followed by drought.

RISK_STATEMENT: High or low water during construction could increase the construction duration due to delays or reduced production. Areas assumed to be accessible during design may require access dredging, light loading barges, or holding off on work until conditions change if low water is experienced during construction. Similarly, if high water is experienced during construction, work may need to be delayed or performed in the wet which could reduce productivity.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: More frequent high and low water events may be experienced moving into the future due to climate change. The PDT will determine likely access routes based on typical water levels throughout the year. Additional time can be included in the contract duration to account for flooding/drought if the PDT determines that is necessary. The contract will include adverse weather days and the contractor will be required to develop a High Water Action Plan. While the likelihood of a flood/drought may be slightly higher, the measures described should mitigate the likelihood of these events impacting the construction contract.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This estimate assumes a slight delay during construction but that other mitigation measures could be used to avoid additional cost impacts.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This estimate assumes a slight delay during construction but that other mitigation measures could be used to avoid additional schedule impacts.

RISK_STATEMENT: Seasonal flooding can impact project implementation due to high water and lack of access.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: Survivability of vegetation based upon island design elevation. Too high of an elevation increases cost, whereas too low may not support the species due to frequency of high water events.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT:

Owner: Planning - Environmental Justice

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Realizing this risk would set back the schedule an estimated two weeks to prepare for a public meeting, conduct outreach, plan, and PDT travel.

PROJECT_NAME: Sabine Pass to Galveston Bay - Orange PACR
RISK_STATEMENT: Differences of opinion amongst resource agencies on level of indirect impacts associated with project construction. Lack of detail, data, and information regarding the ability to sufficiently analyze the indirect impacts of this system to the adjacent habitats of the proposed system. Indirect impacts may include impacting natural sheet flow and hydrology for all adjacent marsh systems, leading to an increase in significant habitat loss after project construction, and subsequently additional mitigation requirements.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Disagreement of impact assessment between resource agencies is common on major construction projects, such as this one. It is likely there will be disagreement between state and federal agencies on the assumptions needed to be used to calculate indirect impacts in the WVA modelling.
We are doing a high-level analysis such that we could either over- or under-estimate acres by habitat type & quality & therefore impacts & mitigation costs.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact could be minimal, such as additional time needed to complete the analysis and work out an agreement amongst agencies. However, overall cost impact could be high if indirect impacts are estimated higher to be conservative which would drive mitigation costs up.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Could add a few months to the analysis time and mitigation plan development.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Obtaining 401WQC/CZMA for any work in water
RISK_STATEMENT:
The risk is that WQC/CZMA compliance may not be granted for in-water features proposed offshore on the ocean side or in the back bay. This risk assumes that the FWOP decision point was reached and the decision was made to include in water features offshore on ocean side and in the back bay and request additional resources (which were granted).

Features placed in the water within the back bay or Atlantic shoreline could affect extensive areas of seagrass. Mitigation may be required or the feature placement could even be prohibited.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There would be high risk to the project in obtaining the CZMA concurrence if structures in the water are proposed.  The back bay is designated as the Biscayne Bay Aquatic Preserve.  Florida laws and regulations provide constraints for activities within aquatic preserves.  There is the potential that FDEP may not concur with the Corps CZMA determination. (18-18 FAC, 18-20 FAC, 18-21 FAC) The aquatic preserve is also an outstanding Florida water meaning turbidity is limited to 0 NTU beyond background for all in-water activities.  There are waivers which may be acquired but any activities like dredging or filling in waters will not meet the threshold without the waiver.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
If the features are prohibited, reformulation costs could be high because TSP specific modeling and Design work would need to be redone and report rewritten. In - water features removed.

Assumption is that risk is realized following public release of draft report and prior to ADM.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The in-water measures/alternative would need to be changes to a plan with no in water measure and the TSP specific work redone (HEC RAS, life sim, SLC analysis, design).  The report would need to be revised and re-released for public review (60 days).

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
Geotech Risk: Need sufficient geotechnical data to determine placement and design of recommended plan. There may be some existing data.

Time & Resource Risk: Time and resources to complete design.

Environmental Surveys needed for design (and environmental analysis/NEPA/mitigation) are covered under another risk.  Do not want to double count time/costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Current schedule and budget includes appropriate level of effort for the team to reach a ?Class 3? estimate.  If the schedule or budget is reduced in anyway the risk would be great that the cost estimate is not in compliance with USACE HQ Engineering and Construction. The risk is that HQ does not approve the study to move forward to a Chief's report.
Data collection and analysis to reach a "Class 3" cost estimate must be initiated well before TSP in order to have it ready at the appropriate time in the plan formation schedule.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If significant design changes are required in PED phase, there is a chance that a 902 exceedance could occur.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on current estimates, range is approximate

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Insufficient info to analyze effects to the environment
RISK_STATEMENT:
This risk is not having enough information to complete the analysis to determine the alternative effects Environmental Resources, threatened and endangered species, and essential fish habitat (ESA).

Lack of information on the condition of sensitive resources in the study area may impact acceptance of USACEs effects statement and risks not being able to complete ESA and EFH during planning.
T&E species will include in water and on land, although in water features effects determinations for measures (if proposed) in the back bay and off shore on the Atlantic Ocean side.
Surveys would also be needed in the nearshore for sand placement on the beach.

Environmental surveys would also be utilized for Class III cost estimate. ESD-2
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Surveys would likely be needed on lands for the FL bonneted bat and tri-colored bat, mangrove impacts along shorelines, and in water features would need additional benthic surveys. Since it is unlikely that in water features will be retained and if so, additional resources will be needed to complete surveys, it is likely that ESA consultation will be completed with sufficient information. It is also possible that additional benthic surveys could be required for placement of sand on the beach.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If NMFS/FWS ask for additional surveys the cost range could be broad depending on the area and scope.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This survey time could range from 6 months to a year depending on requested scope.

RISK_STATEMENT: After researching and coordinating with other environmental agencies it was determined that the NEPA document would be and Environmental Assessment and not and Environmental Impact Statement. If impacts from the proposed alternative are greater than an EA is able to legally cover than addition time for reviews would be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on extensive coordination on potential alternatives with agencies it is unlikely that the NEPA documentation would change to an EIS.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An EIS requires 45 days of public comment on the draft and final documents, whereas an EA only requires 30.  That is a total of 30 additional days.

RISK_STATEMENT: HEC-RAS Version 6.6 is expected to be released by the end of the calendar year 2024. Version 6.6 is imperative to the study because it allows for incorporation of subsurface stormwater systems. The scope and schedule were constructed with the assumption that HEC-RAS Version 6.6 will be released by the end of the calendar year 2024. If the release is delayed, the modeling team will either have to reassess modeling techniques to pair boundary conditions between the existing SWMM Model and HEC-RAS V6.5 or delay the modeling effort until Version 6.6 is released. Pairing stormwater boundary conditions between SWMM and HEC-RAS is not only very laborious and introduces many opportunities for human error but will also take longer than modeling stormwater directly in HEC-RAS.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The ETL has been in constant contact with the software developers at HEC and they continue to reassure that the release of Version 6.6 is on track for release in "late 2024".
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional modeling labor will be necessary to transpose lots of data between the existing SWMM and the HEC-RAS model if Version 6.6 is not accessible.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimated approximately 30 additional days of modeling effort if HEC-RAS V6.6 is not released in time.

RISK_STATEMENT: There is significant public/stakeholder interest in this project. USACE has solicited input from various stakeholders within the watershed to assist in the development of proposed operating scenarios that will meet both the intended uses of the reservoirs as well as meet the needs of the entire watershed. Stakeholder engagement events have and will be conducted at various points throughout the life of the project. This project may impact the District?s reputation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is unlikely the USACE reputation will be negatively affected because the PDT has communicated the process and the findings of the study.

PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is unlikely that the design vessel would get smaller with the implementation of the project, however there are some larger container ships that call within the Columbia system, but not currently at the ports under consideration.

RISK_NAME: Changes to Future Projected Fleet Mix
RISK_STATEMENT: The projected fleet mix is based on historical vessel call, but if it is inaccurate would result in inefficiencies or under counted benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The projected future fleet mix is based on historical data and comparison to other ports on the Columbia.  The most likely realization of this of this risk would result in a fleet risk weighted towards larger, deeper drafting vessels.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The most likely outcome on this risk would result on a fleet mix that is more heavily weighted in the Bulk 8 and 9 categories that benefit most from implementation of the recommended plan.

PROJECT_NAME: Sabine Pass to Galveston Bay - Orange PACR
RISK_STATEMENT:
We've ID interior drainage features, but final design needs to be firmed up prior to design confirmation. The Validation Report & Appendices (draft due March/April 2025) may include overdesigned minimal facilities. Costs would be too high & the Government/NFS cost share wrong. 902 Analysis wrong. 
Added 2024-08-09 per Andrea, "the NFS hasn't been able to clearly identify what is minimum facilities vs what is additional; anything associated with additional must be justified with damages/costs. in the absence of that work and to keep the validation schedule, if IDA doesn't pass minimum faciliies muster all those costs are going to be put on NFS." Incremental Analysis "brings into question are there better ways to do it."
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Prior experience has shown that designs, and therefore associated costs & cost shares, change during technical reviews.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This isn't a construction cost issue but a PACR cost issue due to reanalysis.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This is tied to the prior IDA risk & shares the same estimated cost & time delay.

RISK_STATEMENT: Action & funding by The Nature Conservancy, NFWF, USFWS & NJDEP have led to plans to remove downstream barriers at Dams 1, 2, 3, & 4. USACE assumes these will be removed or modified for aquatic community restoration. The impacts of any of these barriers not being removed would be moderate to significant.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NJDEP, NFWF & USFWS funding for Dams 1 & 2 are designated for Engineering, Permitting & Construction.  Funding to date: $1.8M of estimated $6M needed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The removal of Dams 1 & 2 would dramatically increase opportunity for native habitat to migrate upstream.

RISK_STATEMENT: Dams along the Pequest River have varied ownership, with a number having multiple owners (from both banks). Barrier removal feasibility depends on engaging these dam owners and finding mutually acceptable solutions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Previous communications and interactions with the property owners has resulted in varying levels of interest expressed in the removal or alteration of the dams. A number of the dams have overlapping property owners or the state of NJ.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Without access to the dam by the property owners any removal or modification activities cannot be designed and completed. Easements would be needed potentially permanent and temporary for each of the dam locations.

RISK_STATEMENT: Any limitations on barrier removal/modification for historic purposes could limit the number of viable solutions for barrier removal. Historic considerations are key across these dams as a number are registered as historic via NJSHPO.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Currently, Dam 6 is the only dam under consideration and carries significant risk.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Given that Dam 6 is registered with the NJSHPO, there's a high likelihood of schedule impacts.

RISK_STATEMENT: Dam 5, USGS Monitor has received sampling results for potential HTRW.  A cursory review indicates there are analytes that exceed the ecological screening criteria.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Given that results have returned with indicators of HTRW it's extremely likely this location will not be considered and will continue to prohibit habitat migration upstream of the Pequest River.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The NFS has the final decision on whether or not this risk cancels the CAP project.  The NFS is currently assessing its availability to handle both the HTRW and CAP project in parallel.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Retaining in water measures in Back Bay past FWOP DP
RISK_STATEMENT:
This risk defines the plan formulation risk if in water measures are retained in the back bay past the FWOP. If the in water features in the back bay are not screened from the initial round of screening based on conceptual criteria below, the study will need to request additional resources and and will likely need to pause like waiting for approval of time/funding to complete the additional work (fy25). (DP = decision point)

Screening: (ROM costs do not exceed damages), additional resources (time and funding) would be needed to further evaluate those alternatives since the hydrodynamic modeling and surveys are not included in the study scope at this time.  Modeling and surveys would be expensive (for reference back bay and oceanside add an additional approximate 2 years and $3.5M, for back bay only, estimate would likely be approximately $2M, 2 years)
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: FWOP damages are likely to be high based on first floor elevations and ROM costs for in water features are likely high.  There are other criteria when screening the conceptual array of alternatives, like acceptability, constructability, environmental compliance, etc.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Study estimates to include in water measures were approximately $3.5M for the Atlantic Coastline and Back Bay.  The majority of the cost was for the back bay.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The original study scope that includes in water work estimate an additional 2 years to complete the modeling and surveys.

Risk is defined as plan formulation risk if features are retained past FWOP DP (decision point).  If retained, additional modeling (hydrodynamic) and surveys are needed that are not included in the schedule and budget.  This risk covers the hydrodynamic modeling on the ocean side.

study delays and legal fees could be highly variable

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Potential health and life safety risk in the study area
RISK_STATEMENT:
Key Biscayne has one ingress/egress route which can create concerns during evacuations for a storm event.  During public meetings with the community, the causeway was a major concern that was repeated by residents.  In order to address the concern and reduce the risks to the community, LifeSim will be used to help quantify the potential life loss and ensure that the TSP will assist in meeting the life safety objective of the study. It can simulate population redistribution during an evacuation.

The main reason we are using life sim is that if we build any structural measures for the TSP (raising roads, tie back walls etc.) we need to know that we aren't increasing the life safety risk to anyone. If from the modeling it turns out that the life safety risk is unacceptable, we may need to go back to the TSP drawing board.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
Key Biscayne is highly susceptible to hurricanes, high winds, and other storm/rain-induced inundation.  Health and life safety will continue to be a risk to Key Biscayne without this study and will be improved with use of Life Sim as part of this effort.
Unlikely that we would develop and pick a TSP that increases life safety risk.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: $77000 labor to complete FWOP and FWP lifesim modeling
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimated 90 to complete FWOP LifeSim and 90 days to complete FWP LifeSim

RISK_STATEMENT: FWOP assumes that the project sponsors will continue to maintain areas under consideration at a similar level into the future.  Both NFSs have indicated concerns about future resource availability to meet needs with the growth in private dredge costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The ports have a financial interest in maintain berthing areas and locally managed turning areas so will likely maintain these areas into the future, however this will have increasing impacts to ongoing development and reinvestment as a part of the Port masterplans
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Reduced O&M beyond what was described in the FWOP would result in significant economic impacts at the Ports and potentially result in the TEMCO and EGT terminals to be non-competitive or economically unviable towards of the end of the 50 year period of analysis.

RISK_STATEMENT: FWOP conditions assumed a continuation of dredge work through a USACE contract (optional line item) which would not be available under a more restrictive IWWW.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Port of Longview is currently able to accomplish their maintenance dredging in front of EGT as an add on to the USACE dredge contract.  This is only possible due to the presence of dredgers at Port of Longview during their IWWW.  Any further restriction of the IWWW would mean that Longview would need to let their own contract at a significantly higher per unit cost.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If Port of Longview needs to let its own contract it will be in competition with all other Columbia River ports and may result in reduced future maintenance due to capacity, cost, and timing issues.

RISK_STATEMENT: FWOP assumes that private dredge contractors would be available to meet quantity requirements for the Port of Kalama.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The costs associated with dredging on the Columbia have been increasing rapidly over the last 10 years due to a decrease in available private dredgers.  If trends continue with a declining dredge fleet capacity to meet dredge requirements are likely be impacted.  Any change to the IWWW which is anticipated in the future would result in an overall decrease in seasonal dredge capacity for the system and would impact PoK's ability to fully maintain their local turning area.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is a risk that under FWOP transportation delays, light loading and transporation inefficiency would be worse than anticipated.

RISK_STATEMENT: Completion of USFWS and NFMS consultation and receiving regulatory compliance documents could impact the teams ability to meet study schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The primary concern is NMFS ability review BA and issue BO and compliance documentation within the study schedule.  Current timelines for review may take up to a year.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential delay or rework to meet NMFS compliance requirements
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Inability to meet NFMS statutory review timelines would result in a multi-month delay to completion of NEPA compliance and approval of the final report.

RISK_STATEMENT: The LMB turning basin is economically justified under NED analysis, however the majority of the realized benefits fall in the RED and OSE categories.  A change to the NED analysis or FWOP assumptions would require additional focus on comprehensive benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: LMB is expected to be economically justified under the NED account.  If changes to modelling or review comments result in reduced benefits, comprehensive benefits analysis would be required to justify implementation of the recommended plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Some impact associated with additional effort to fully quantify RED benefits.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Fully quantifying RED benefits would likely require additional effort beyond what has already been completed and may result in a minor schedule delay.

RISK_STATEMENT: The climate change assessment hydrologic projects pointed to an increasing number and longer duration of periods below 80kcfs, which would adversely impact navigation especially under FWOP conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Future low flow conditions have been included in the development of the FWOP, and potentially under count impacts associated with future low flow conditions and impacts without a federal project.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Implementation of the recommended project would likely result in higher benefits under future flow conditions assumed in the climate change analysis.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Identifying FWOP Condition on Ocean-facing Shoreline
RISK_STATEMENT:
Beach FX was used during MD CSRM but it needs to be redone with the update version that corrects bugs and uses the new CHS storm suite.  This is necessary to accurately represent the FWOP conditions and be consistent with the other economic tools being used in this study.

Due to the complexity of the modeling effort, there is a small chance that the model could produce unreasonable or unusable results. If we fail to model the damages correctly, we will have to redo the analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Beach FX use in the FWOP and FWP to evaluate plans
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current study scope includes an approximate labor estimate to run beach fx for FWOP and FWP
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current study scope includes an approximate time estimate to run beach fx for FWOP and FWP.  Beach Fx modeling occurs concurrent with G2CRM in the FWOP and FWP.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Identifying FWOP Inundation Risk in Study Area
RISK_STATEMENT: If G2CRM is not used, the study cannot assess inundation damage from the back bay or ocean side of Key Biscayne.  Significant project benefits would not be captured. Study objectives would not be achieved.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current study scope includes an approximate labor estimate to run G2CRM for FWOP and FWP
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: approximate labor estimates to run G2CRM
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate to run G2CRM for FWOP and FWP.  Concurrent with all other modeling for FWOP and FWP.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Determination of Flood Pathways & Interior Drainage
RISK_STATEMENT:
HEC RAS will be  used:
To determine flood pathways that will assist in developing alternatives.
To feed Life Sim
To Conduct a drainage analysis on the TSP to make sure that it does not cause adverse impacts to local drainage conditions.
If HEC RAS is not used, the life safety objective, flood pathways, and local drainage will not be able to be accurately quantified.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Use of Hec Ras has been included in the current study scope, schedule, and budget for the 3 items listed above.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If HEC RAS is not used, may have inefficient designs since flood pathways are not known, not quantify life safety benefits (not meet objective), and not know drainage conditions (worse local drainage = failed project).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: current labor estimate to run HEC RAS is approximate

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Multiple SLC scenarios needed for plan formulation
RISK_STATEMENT: The current scope, schedule, and budget only anticipate formulating to 1 sea level change scenario. The TSP will be evaluated under all three scenarios. If the PDT determines that multiple scenarios are needed for formulation of certain alternatives to identify the TSP then additional time and money may be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is unlikely that this risk is realized but it is possible given the area's potential sensitivity to sea level rise due to the low topographic elevations of the study area.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Failure to consider multiple sea level scenarios may pre-maturely screen out possible effective alternatives if the area is determined to be sensitive to certain sea level scenarios.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If this risk is realized, then additional modeling runs during plan evaluation may need to occur, which will increase the needed budget.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If this risk is realized, then additional modeling runs during plan evaluation may need to occur, which will increase the needed scheduling time. However, it may be possible to absorb the additional modeling time during under project tasks depending on when this risk is realized.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Structural measures along road alignments not implementable
RISK_STATEMENT:
Required elevation of road raising not possible given real estate constraints -- verbally told 100 ft of right of way on each street. Request sent to NFS to provide documentation --- not received yet 
Not possible to develop implementable solution given all the ingress/egress to private and commercial properties.
Result ? Measure may have to drop out
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
All roads (particularly Harbor Dr) drive border many private residences that would require not affecting existing ingress/egress.

Required flood protection elevation too high to implement structural solution within given right-of-way,
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If cannot implement road raising or in-water measures, may only be able to implement lower elevation structural measures that may not be as effective or only non-structural measures.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: labor cost to identify road right-of-way and if any additional parcels need to be obtained and design so as to not affect existing ingress/egress
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Time to identify road right-of-way and if any additional parcels need to be obtained and design so as to not affect existing ingress/egress

RISK_STATEMENT: O&M volumes are partially based on the NFSs historical dredge requirements.  Projected values assume complete restoration of depth in the FWP condition, and similar rates of deposition into the future.  A change in sediment transport or deposition in the future would result in changed volumes.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The team used long term historical data to determine likely dredge volumes averaged over time.  Changes to dredge volumes will likely fall within the range of contingency on an annualized basis.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Higher costs than projected would result in a decrease to net benefits in the future.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk would not be realized until after project implementation and are limited in nature

RISK_STATEMENT: Waiving Shipsim requirements or delay to D&I would result in potential cost and schedule savings.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The footprint of the proposed turning basins can likely be validated without shipsim.  The PDT will request waiving the shipsim requirement (cost and schedule savings) or delay to D&I (schedule savings)
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Non-award of the shipsim line item would result in a $120,000 savings to the feasibility study
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Removal of ship sim would result in minor schedule benefits

RISK_STATEMENT: Complexities associated with accurately modelling current and future conditions in HarborSym has resulted realized schedule delays to TSP and any rework may result in further delays to report completion.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: HarborSym appears to be accurately modelling current conditions and producing outputs consistent with identified problems.  Reviewers may identify areas that require adjustment after release of the draft report.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Costs are associated with adjustments and rerunning of the model as well as updates to all relevant economic analyses.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This rework would likely delay release of the draft report or add time between TSP and ADM.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Understanding the timing of valley storage impacts of the interior channel, partial tie-in A, and tie-in B compared to Corridor Development Certificate compliance (5% variance).  Includes timing of trees within the floodway and interim impact to roughness coefficient.  Updates in construction sequencing could impact schedule.

Additionally, this analysis has indicated that while the interior of the bypass channel and partial tie-in A can proceed forward, tie-in B will be required to be constructed in parallel or prior to the raise of University Drive Valley Storage.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Construction packaging and available funding must be aligned with construction sequencing.

PROJECT_NAME: Key Biscayne Coastal Storm Risk Management Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Sea Level Application to Economic Models
RISK_STATEMENT: Water levels in Beach-Fx, G2CRM, and Lifesim may need to be modified to account for sea level change between 1992 and the model start year. If a policy-compliant strategy is not developed then the project modeling may not be approved, which would impact schedule and budget.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sea level change from 1992 to the model start year will certainly occur. Each model handles sea level change differently and a strategy should be developed to account for the change in sea level that is policy compliant.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Economic modeling may not be compliant with USACE policy on climate change if a strategy is not formulated.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A non-compliant modeling effort may result in modeling that needs to be redone.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A non-compliant modeling effort may result in modeling that needs to be redone.

RISK_STATEMENT: Though designed along depth contour more so than target (as contour aligned w 1977 shoreline) significant changes in depths along island or further erosion could affect stone quantities needed or tie in designs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Bathymetric depths not expected to significantly change outside channel - shoaling generally more likely than spontaneous deepening outside channel. Hence would be less stone rather than more.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Going off 10% change (either in more rock and geotextile and breakwater length) or lress
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May need to alter overall length of breakwater

RISK_STATEMENT: SAV could be present where it was previously not. We have committed to avoiding impacts to existing SAV beds. This was thought less likely with contour depth of design. May be more of an impact for Ops BU of material (leveraged, but not directly part of the project). If significant SAV along breakwater site, could demand pushing outwards and more material costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Was not present before at rubble mound breakwater alignment and is typically shallower in these waters.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Any requirements to shift could affect overall area protected
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Would have to alter wall alignment

RISK_NAME: Rising relative water level due to SLR
RISK_STATEMENT: SLR will elevate water level.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sea levels will rise.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Even if water levels rise, as ER project, breakwater will still provide some edge protection to some degree.

RISK_STATEMENT: Rubble mound breakwater could settle through time. Along with SLR this would lower relative crest height.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Some minimal settling may occur.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Would lower crest height and decrease wave protection. Though would still provide some.

RISK_STATEMENT: Continued inflation could impact getting a contract that meets cost levels required for CAP project and NFSs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Expected increased costs.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If costs get too high, could end up going over CAP limit and would need a waiver.

RISK_STATEMENT: The CAP project assumes that the Nav project will have future sediment nearby that has shoaled within channel and can be beneficially used. If no sediment is available the project will still have benefit, but not all benefit may be realized. Rubble mound breakwater may need to allow for variability in future sediment (though minimal would be against it in either scenario)
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Limited to expecting varying BU in future.

All three features will be constructed under a single construction contract administered by USACE.  Delays in answering RFIs or reviewing submittals could impact cost and/or schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Trees within the floodway are required to meet the roughness coefficient of the H&H model.  In the interim condition, the north bypass channel may be needed for valley storage.  Implementation of landscaping too early may invalidate the warranty.  Phased O&M turnover to the NFS would likely lead to increased effort to keep landscaping healthy through project completion.  Phased implementation of landscaping has been incorporated into the Construction Sequence Analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: USACE position has been that for the bypass channel, landscaping (e.g. trees) would only have a standard warranty of one year.  The one year is anticipated to start from the point when the NPDES permit is closed (90% coverage).  For phased turnover, TRWD has indicated concerns with the warranty period.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: TRWD O&M would likely increase to keep landscaping (e.g. trees) healthy.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_NAME: Blasting to Excavate North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: North Bypass Channel will likely require blasting of bedrock (~200,000 CY) for channel excavation.  Blasting may be required adjacent to Atmos gas line.  Submittal review will take 60-90 days to review.  Delays could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Geotechnical information and industry meetings have indicated that blasting will be required.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Blasting will require a permit from the fire department, vibration monitoring of adjacent structures, and compliance with noise regulations.
