RISK_STATEMENT:
Additional placement area may be needed - unknown availability of known placement area

There are two known placement sites within the study area, but only one is currently in use. The active placement site is located on the opposite side of the island north of the Henry E. Rohlson airport, and is utilized for all dredging operations within the USVI, including St. John and St. Thomas. The closest offshore disposal area is located off the coast of Puerto Rico, so a new offshore disposal site may be investigated during this study. There are opportunities to utilize beneficial use of dredged material within the study area, and it has been used on the island for previous dredging events.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
The placement site at the H.E.R. airport is known to be quite large (dimensions pending). Material to be dredged is still to be determined, but likely to be a small quantity.
Frequency of dredging is still to be determined, but likely to be infrequent.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost increase due to approval and permitting of offshore placement area (one-time or ODMDS)
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Time needed to include approval and permitting of offshore placement area (one-time or ODMDS)
Schedule impact can be completed concurrent with other scheduled tasks

RISK_STATEMENT:
Limited data available for existing environmental resources.

There is expected to be hardbottom, coral, and submerged aquatic vegetation (habitat) impacts within and around the Federal Channel as a result of any dredging activity needed to provide navigation improvements. Sediment transport modeling and environmental surveys will be conducted during the study to better understand the potential direct and indirect impacts. There is uncertainty in the detail and reliability of the existing data, and these new surveys will help inform the level of data collection and environmental/cultural analysis needed for compliance for channel and placement options.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: There are limited National Economic Development (NED) benefits. The primary benefit account for this study is likely Regional Economic Development (RED), and there could be generous Other Social Effects (OSE) benefits to be claimed.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_NAME: Dewatering to Construct the North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Care and diversion of groundwater and surface water will be required for the North Bypass Channel and is a significant cost consideration (there is a perched aquifer in the construction footprint).  Gaps in plans & specifications could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Construction contractor will have to deal with stormwater via Cemetery Outfall and water within the excavation limits.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Construction contractor may run into issues with dewatering operations.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: The excavated rock will be used for erosion protection, which requires the contractor to control excavation/blasting means and methods to produce sufficient product and optimize rock production.  A permit will be required from TCEQ, which is anticipated to take six months.  Delays in permitting process could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Dust and noice from rock processing will need to be managed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If contractor is not able to process rock, rip rap will need to be imported.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Per industry feedback, permit will take six months.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Unforeseen site conditions and the construction contractor hitting unknown utilities, buried foundations, etc. could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Construction will occur in a densely populated urban environment.  While due diligence has been exercised, it is likely previously unknown utilities and structures will be encountered.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: With ongoing utility relocations, may have multiple contractors accessing the site.  Changes to the timing of staging areas could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: City utility relocations are delayed, and contractors are currently occupying expected footprint of North Bypass Channel laydown areas.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Significant flood event occurring during construction could lead to damage and rework.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Under the default clause, contractor is due additional time.  Contractor would be compensated for any rework required due to the event and not related to contractor not protecting site/negligence.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Plans and specifications include sole source items.  A J&A compliant with FAR Part 6 is required.  Delay in approval of J&A could result in schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Will result in the requirement for a sole source J&A to be approved by the KO if under the simplified acquisition threshold or senior contract official if exceeded.  Current estimate is under the simplified acquisition threshold.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: TRWD Emergency Ops relocation and facility demolition must occur prior to the start of Partial Plug A construction.  Delays could impact the award of the option and result in rephasing of work.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current schedule projection of October 2025 will result in the delay of the start of Partial Plug A construction.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A-E modification required to repackage construction base.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: AE contract modification require to resequence construction base.  Schedule contingency exceeded.

RISK_STATEMENT: Uncertainty in bid climate (# of competing job opportunities) and interest could have significant impacts to the value of the contract award.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Deep foundation treatment (piles) could tend to be a specialty that could have tendency to reduce competitive bidders.  Contracting recommended a few options for encouraging bidders, including:  sources sought (will help judging small business restrictions), industry day, and/or pre-bid site visit.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Lowest cost assumed 10% reduction from base estimate.  Highest cost assumed market conditions at time of solicitation could result in 15% higher bids due to reduced competition, saturated construction market, or other factors.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Construction modifications can impact contract cost and duration.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Contract mods exist on every project and can vary based on the feature of work.  This contract will have general risk exposure to unforeseen site conditions, design revisions in the field, and coordination with the nearby public and residences.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Most likely case assumes 3% contract cost increase for modifications.  Highest case assumes 6% contract cost increase for modifications.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Most likely assume up to a month for contract modifications, highest assumes up to 2 months of schedule increase.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Variability in material pricing could impact project cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Market research has been performed for all key material items, however, risk remains of future variability in prices and market uncertainty are likely to impact project costs.  Key materials include aggregates, cementious materials, and resteel.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Lowest assumes 2% cost reduction. Highest assumes 7.5% increase in material costs, except 20% on steel materials.  Increases based on cost engineer's judgement from material price volitality experienced in 2004 and 2009 (Chinese steel demand, steel $ increases as much as 30%) and general material cost jump as much as 7.5%.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Estimated production rates and crew composition assignments could vary among bidders.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Estimated production rates and crew composition assignments could vary among bidders.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Loweest assumes 95% production rate while the highest value assumes a 85% production rate from the base estimate of 90% production rate.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Additional requirements may arise above and beyond current assumptions, such as tree cutting (minimal) will be required to be performed outside of the Indiana bat nesting period.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Environmental considerations (nesting period) for the Indiana Bat are known.  Impacts could occur should the construction start around this time frame.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assumed 1/2 month of critical path schedule delay.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Adverse weather (precipitation) could impact cost/schedule as well as how much dewatering must be constructed and utilized during construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The project is in a geographic area that could see significant amounts of precipitation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: assume time-related cost impacts only (WC assume that contractor can recoup these costs from the Govt).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assume worst-case scenario is 3 MO of weather delays due to excessive precipitation affecting the dewatering and earthwork portions of the site.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: If the local area is saturated with work, availability of skilled labor could impact costs and construction due to inflated labor pricing or recruitment.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Assumption based on amount of funding provided for infrastructure and construction projects.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Allow up to 15% increased labor cost for recruitment and retainage incentives such as premium pay, bonuses, per diem, travel/subistance, etc.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Economist Human resources are strained within LRH due to Supplement work and normal District workload.

RISK_STATEMENT: The intent of this project is to have a PED package ready to go for PBUD 25 funded in-house construction. Missing early milestones may be an indicator of schedule delays later on, potentially affecting time for funding execution if delays are significant.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that some delay will occur due to PM inexperience, PDT member availability due to workload, or possible holds due to funding may cause delays in schedule.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If PED begins to affect construction and execution of funds, then it may lead to a rushed construction timeline or cause issues with acquiring items that have long lead times.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It's estimated that most issues that would impact schedule during the PED phase could be identified and corrected between the time of 2-4 biweekly meeting intervals.

RISK_STATEMENT: The Lower Dam is a water structure which will require additional safety precautions for any on-site work.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Work near water will be very likely for all project phases.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT:
The City of Atlanta has directly contracted with an AE for the design of the project. While USACE will have the ability to review and provide input on the design, USACE will have no contractual authority over the AE.

DOR hired by the City of Atlanta may not have a full understanding of the ER requirements for Plans and Specifications to include review requirements and timelines for incorporation of comments.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Delays anticipated between City of Atlanta contract requirements and USACE federal guidelines.

RISK_STATEMENT:
While initial coordination with GA Safe Dams has been completed by one of the City?s AEs, there is no written agreement between GA Safe Dams and the City of Atlanta allowing/approving removal/declassification of the dam.

Until the classification of the dam has been finalized between City of Atlanta and GA Safe Dams, it is unknown what level of involvement the USACE RMC for dams and levees will be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: City of Atlanta has indicated they would like to utilize an early contractor involvement-type acquisition strategy, but this has not been vetted with USACE. Risk is recommended due to the lack of a consensus on acquisition strategy between USACE and City of Atlanta.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: Prior to contract award, USACE will require significant supplemental funding from the City of Atlanta (likely an additional ~$7M). The timing of getting the additional funding from the City of Atlanta is out of USACE control and may be subject to City of Atlanta legislative approval before release to USACE.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Anticipated delays, combined with other risk delays, could delay award of construction contract. The longer the delay, the more the project will cost due to inflation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Ultimately, construction timelines will be based on design, which has not been started (or even contracted). Significant schedule risk must be applied due to the uncertainty in the design and potential issues with re-routing traffic from Lakewood Avenue and re-routing the North Fork South River itself.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: Conceptual alignment proposed by the City's AE would go through a historically significant archeological site, which would lead to significant cost implications. USACE needs additional detail on the 35% design to fully understand ramifications and coordinate mitigation w/ SHPO.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Cultural resources will be impacted as part of this project and current conceptual alignment would have significant cost impacts. USACE will monitor as the project approaches the 35% design.

RISK_STATEMENT: There are multiple stakeholders and partners on the project that require coordination (TRWD, City of Fort Worth, USACE, CDM Stanley, HNTB, Transystems, Kimley-Horn, Rios, etc.). If proper coordination doesn't take place, then key decisions are re-questioned and rework is needed.  Rework could lead to cost and schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_NAME: Lower Promenade Safety (Interim Condition & Post Const)
RISK_STATEMENT: Initial design assumption was for no public access during interim condition. Safety concerns during interim condition will require fall protection if TRWD allows public access prior to full completion of project. Implementation of a permanent fall protection system could result in H&H impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Must provide interim fall protection. Permanent fall protection over a body of water is not a code requirement.  408 process would require mitigation of H&H impacts.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Property owner has requested vibration monitoring for additional geotechnical investigations.  Assume that vibration monitoring will be required for construction.  Misaligned requirements could lead to Section 106 concerns.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Could add burdensome requirements on the contractor that slows production and increases removal costs.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Contractor performance may be impacted by monitoring if concerns are identified.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_NAME: Rock Surface Elevation Along the Soft Edge Channel Slope
RISK_STATEMENT: Variation in the assumed rock elevation will impact the slope tie point location.  Unforeseen site conditions could impact cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Variation in the assumed rock elevation will impact the slope tie point location.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If there rock is at a deeper elevation than shown the levee slope will become extended and could go beyond the assumed rock cut location. This could result in a change condition during construction requiring a design and construction change.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: Update to "Below the Bluff" is required as part of the North Bypass Channel AE contract and requires public input and consultation.  Mitigation for adverse impacts will be required, which could have schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Addendum is part of requirements of Programmatic Agreement.  Delays in approval could impact start of construction.  Programmatic Agreement for indirect adverse impacts requires creation of an eligibility form and provide to landowners and creating educational material.  Educational materials will likely need to be contracted out.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_NAME: Transform 1012 N. Main Street and THC Consultation
RISK_STATEMENT: Design originally was required to avoid impacts to this property due to cultural significance; however, property owner has requested embankment in lieu of floodwall.  Geological conditions in the area of the building create an elevated risk to the structural under proposed conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A floodwall will encroach into property requiring additional consultation with THC.  Could require some back and forth design coordination with landowner to get an acceptable approach. Additional measures may be needed to protect the building and require additional consultation with building owner and THC. Additional agreements may be required.

PROJECT_NAME: Modified Central City - North Bypass Channel
RISK_STATEMENT: TCEQ permits are required for rock processing and concrete batch plant.  For portions of work in the water (Tie-In A, Tie-In B, and cofferdams), additional permits will likely be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The rock processing and concrete batch plant will require permits from TCEQ.  For portions of the North Bypass Channel in the water (e.g. Tie-In B and Remaining Tie-In A), The construction contractor will likely need to perform a mussel survey  and  apply for TPWD permit. The construction contractor's means and methods must be described in the request for permit and submitted to TPWD 4 weeks before "unwatering."
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: TCEQ permits require public comment periods.

RISK_STATEMENT: Proposals received could be out of awardable range.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Construction costs have steadily increased over the past few years and awarding around the end of the FY can also drive costs up.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The lowest is the contingency provided above estimated contract amount.  The highest value assumes 25% over the contract value.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Comprehensive approach to Flood risk reduction may require defining flood contributions by source for policy and technical  reviews.  Initial scoping discussions with VT indicate interest in  eventual cost sharing decisions at earliest scoping phases.  PDT scoping and formulation approach must balance interest in sources of flood hazard with study schedule and budget goals.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Consultation with VT and SMEs on formulation and modeling approaches considered cost sharing early in scoping and first iterations. Balancing study cost and schedule priorities with identifying the right plan might be complicated by cost sharing concerns if it is applied to shape formulation and evaluation events.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Any additional sediment within the channel due to continued bank failure or sedimentation within project area rivers or tributaries. Changes in flow characteristics of the channel affecting accuracy of the models.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Models cannot model the sediment transport at a fine enough scale.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: May result in model inaccuracies that affect any channel modification measures that are developed and anaylzed.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: New land uses within the project area causing increase in imperviousness and possible inaccurate representation of the future without project condition.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The City of Charleston is a rapidly growing city with high demands for commercial and residential development.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: May result in higher storm flows, or structures within the floodplain.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Bathymetric data for tributaries is not currently available for the project area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Missing topographic data.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Missing topographic data will affect the accuracy of the model.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Sub-basins within the project area were delineated using a 50-foot hydrocorrected grid developed from the LiDAR data collected in 2017. Basins were delineated with an average size of approximately 10 square miles.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: No models are being utilized for AMM this is a low risk.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: 1.) Not capturing all flood risks and damages if data is not current and accurate.  2.) The measures and/or alternatives may not address the actual conditions.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: More PDT members may be needed for additional modeling.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: More PDT members are not needed for AMM.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional cost for additional team members.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time may be required for current team members in order to complete site work.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Increase in rainfall and extreme storm events directly impacts the hydrologic analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Climate Change
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Increase in rainfall and extreme storm events directly impacts the hydrologic sensitivity analysis.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Uncertainties associated with different climate variables is relevant to the accuracy hydrologic analysis. Additional time (<1mo) for coordination may need to be included.  Will be concurrent with other Hydrologic impacts.

RISK_NAME: Loss of stability in existing structure during construction
RISK_STATEMENT: Existing timber crib and stone revetment not in as-built condition. Timber crib is deteriorated, and stone revetment has settled into channel, as evidenced by loss of concrete cap on east side of dam. Shoring during demolition and construction will need to be considered to mitigate risk of existing structure failing during construction.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Unlikely to occur, shoring of existing structure will be considered during design and construction.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Failure of existing structure will increase construction cost. Additional funding will be needed for design.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Failure of existing structure will pause construction until repairs are coordinated.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: Environmental assessment for project construction site hasn't been completed as of the CSRA meeting on 5-Dec-23.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The status of the Environmental Assessment for the project construction site is unknown and it is likely that it won't be complete prior to the scheduled contract award date for the Tinker AFB FY26 Child Development Center.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact, if the Environmental Assessment isn't complete prior to the award of the FY26 CDC contract, will primarily consist of escalation costs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The most likely schedule impact, if the Environmental Assessment isn't complete prior to the award of the FY26 CDC contract, will be 1 year (assumes the completion of the EA and cleanup of the contaminated site will take 2 years).

PROJECT_NAME: Illinois Waterway Dredged Material Management Plan
RISK_STATEMENT: High pressure gas lines intersect the study area and would need to be avoided during operations and maintenance of the navigation channel.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are documented existences of high pressure gas lines crossing the study area at RM: 156.4.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The existence of a high power gas line in the study area is known. The team has identified other nearby options for dredge material placement.

PROJECT_NAME: Illinois Waterway Dredged Material Management Plan
RISK_STATEMENT: The US Fish and Wildlife IPaC website, indicated multiple ESA-listed mussels within the Dresden and Brandon Road pools and prior mussel surveys were needed for the Illinois Waterway on prior civil works projects in the study area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: For site placement on banklines and in-channel, multiple HREPs and projects in the area have also had to survey for mussels, which would stop construction until District and USFWS biologists can determine location of mussel bed(s). Formal consultation and preparation of BA/BO is required to document take of a listed species before construction can continue (Around 150-200 day delay).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Formal consultation and preparation of BA/BO is required to document take of a listed species before construction can continue (Around 150-200 day delay).

PROJECT_NAME: Liverpool Flowing Side Channel, Navigation Ecosystem Sustainability Program
RISK_NAME: Public perception of negative impacts to public use areas
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a risk that the public will perceive or assume negative impacts to public use areas by the Project. For instance, Quiver Lake is downstream of the Project area and currently has minimal flow to it (does not flow 90% of the time, according to the Project Sponsor), but the public enjoys that area and may assume that any work the Project entails will negatively impact Quiver Lake and their use of it.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on conversations with the Project Sponsor and Partners, this is a likely event due to public use and interest in recreation in Quiver Lake and other areas.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The public may be upset with USACE, the Project Sponsor, and/or the Project partners if they feel recreation is negatively impacted.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Public education will occur as normal with the Project and information will be provided in the PIR about site conditions and how the TSP impacts (positively or negatively) the Project area, including recreation.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Public education will occur as normal with the Project and information will be provided in the PIR about site conditions and how the TSP impacts (positively or negatively) the Project area, including recreation.

RISK_NAME: Project Fatigue and Loss of Public Support
RISK_STATEMENT: Loss of momentum (lack of construction progress) could impact public support.  Decreased public support could impact Congressional support, which impacts cost and schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The likeliness could increase with the retirement of the projects strongest Congressional supporter, Ms. Granger.

RISK_STATEMENT: Project is only partially funded, and additional funding is needed to complete construction. Not receiving Federal funds impacts cost and schedule and interim conditions of constructed features increases the O&M burden to the non-Federal sponsor.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Project is subject to supplemental appropriations and workplans.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional funding is required to complete construction.  If funding is not received timing, remaining features will not be completed.  As more time progresses, remaining features will become more costly due to inflation.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Not constructed the South Bypass Channel interior in one construction phase will impact critical path by approximately two years.

RISK_STATEMENT: Project is not allowed to be budgeted in President's Budget and is only able to compete for supplemental and workplan funds. Workplan releases may impact schedule due to construction packaging.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The strongest Congressional proponent for the project retires in 2024. Without a proponent in Congress to provide funding, it is unclear how the remaining funds will be provided.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Opportunities for funding are limited.  Higher liklihood that smaller increments would be supported versus larger increments. Portions of the project may be short funds depending on when these increments come and depending on the amounts. Pushing these portions of the project out will make them susceptible to inflation.

RISK_NAME: Total Project Cost Increases Impacts NFS Funding Requirement
RISK_STATEMENT: Total Project Cost inceases place a burden on the amount of "proportinate" funding the sponsor must provide for the cost share.  FRM is 65/35, ER is 65/35, and REC is 50/50 up to a limit of $11M.  Additional non-Federal cash may be required, and the funding capability of the non-Federal sponsor could impact schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Project is not fully funded. As the schedule moves to the right, inflation increases costs.

RISK_STATEMENT: PPA includes betterments. Analysis and documentation are required to describe the base project, betterments, and the incremental difference between the base project and betterment for the whole project.  Documentation will likely be reviewed by vertical team and will be critical in communicating funding requirements to sponsor.  Some features are more progressed than others, and repackaging leads to schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: The more the schedule moves to the right, costs escalate due to market conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Prices have been increase about 2.5% per year

RISK_STATEMENT: The 2022 Total Project Cost was based on conceptual designs and appeared to include betterments.  Design has progressed and the updated 2024 Total Project Cost update is projected to slightly exceed the 902 limit, which will require a Project Authorization Change Report.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_NAME: Using Existing HMS and RAS models

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_NAME: Complex flood risk in H&H modeling
RISK_STATEMENT: Complexity and size of the project area watershed. Intricate compound flooding risks.  Multiple types of flooding to mitigate over vast size of watershed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Characterization of flow, different focus areas have different flooding types within them.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Being able to capture the intricate features of the project area due to its size and type of flooding in the modeling which may affect the ECON deliverables

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Missing site-specific geotechnical data for the project area. Project area has high seismic hazard.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Missing data.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Incorrect assumptions for structural measures can affect the cost during PED phase. Geotechnical sampling is higher cost in the project area due to seismic hazard and large depth of stable rock layer.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PDT could run out of funding.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
The OSE/EJ methodology for this project intends to gather essential information to incorporate into plan formulation.  Engaging with communities, particularly those that are historically underserved or marginalized, poses significant challenges. The lead would like to include strategies to overcome these challenges by collaborating with local organizations and using culturally appropriate engagement techniques (in addition to quarterly public meetings). However, without proper funding and planning, these efforts may be insufficient.
Consequences of the Risk: 
?	Underrepresentation of Marginalized Communities: Failure to effectively engage marginalized communities can lead to their underrepresentation in project decisions, potentially resulting in inequitable outcomes. 
?	Inadequate OSE Assessment: Insufficient community input could lead to an incomplete or biased assessment in the Other Social Effects (OSE) account, undermining the comprehensive benefits analysis. 
?	Increased Project Risk: Without proper community engagement, there is a risk of community pushback, legal challenges, or project delays, increasing the overall risk to project success.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Funding stream challenges limit ability to accomplish certain EJ OSE tasks prior to AMM.

PROJECT_NAME: Charleston Tidal and Inland Related Flood Risk Management Study

PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Liverpool Flowing Side Channel, Navigation Ecosystem Sustainability Program
RISK_STATEMENT: The alignment of the side channel may change post construction due to natural processes.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: According to a 2004 Washington Department of Forestry "Side channel/Off Channel Habitat Restoration" document, "There is a risk of the bed and banks of an overflow side channel shifting during the first few years following construction until the channel form has stabilized to accommodate high flows." While velocities in the Illinois River are relatively low, the proximity of the project to cultural resources is a concern.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Armoring may be required to ensure that the channel does not meander towards certain areas.

PROJECT_NAME: Liverpool Flowing Side Channel, Navigation Ecosystem Sustainability Program
RISK_STATEMENT: The Illinois River experiences high sediment loading. The rate of sedimentation in the Liverpool Ditch will determine the lifespan of the project. If sedimentation rates are underestimated, the project may not remain a flowing side channel for the 50-year design lifespan. However, sedimentation rates for the Illinois River are not well defined.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is high uncertainty in sedimentation rates in the Ilinois River. The value of 1.94 in/yr from the Chautauqua HREP is within the range of observed sedimentation rates for the East River Channel portion of the Lake Peoria HREP 23 years after construction.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The side channel must have at least 4 feet of depth in order to function. Underestimating the sedimentation rate will reduce the lifespan of the project.

RISK_STATEMENT: Communications with the public and other interested stakeholders is important. Many local residents support the continued management of Optima as public land for recreational and wildlife access.  Families of the original land owners strongly support the return of lands to the families from which the USACE purchased the property.  Well executed communications plan will mitigate this risk.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Lack of Interest in taking over the property
RISK_STATEMENT: Stakeholders that have expressed interest in taking the project from USACE are not interested if the dam embankment remains in place.  The FRM function of the structure would need to be eliminated by notching in multiple locations or complete removal of the embankment.  The team is evaluating the cost and effort based upon input from the public and agencies expressing interest in the project and contacted to discuss transfer of the project.  PTD will ensure this risk is adequately communicated to the VT.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT hasn't reached out to all possible state and federal entities that may be interested in taking over the property from USACE.  Apache Tribe has indicated cultural links to the project lands.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current cost to dispose of embankment.

RISK_STATEMENT: Lipan Apache Tribe of Texas has expressed to USACE cultural and historical ties to project lands.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: They are aware of the existence of cultural resources important to the Tribe.  They would like to have continued access to the lands. There are historic cultural surveys and one site is NRHP eligible.  Multiple settlement sites are also present on project lands.  Cultural data from USACE doesn't fully support the Tribe's stated concern.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: USACE is making good faith efforts to coordinate with multiple tribes.  At present there is very little or no risk to agency reputation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: No known impacts at this time.  No additional surveys would be required to complete NEPA documentation.

RISK_STATEMENT: USFWS has requested cooperating agency status and has requested the opportunity to review PDT deliverables prior to public release. Additional reviewer risk schedule impacts/slips.  The USFWS, as a cooperating agency, will be a member of the PDT and has requested ability to review documents at the local, refuge level, prior to public and agency review related to participation on the PDT and as the land managers with an interest in assuming management of all federal fee lands if the embankment were removed.  The USFWS Regional Office will be the P&A reviewer for the Service.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Likely at the present time until further coordination is completed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: USFWS concerns to ensure continued operation of the Wildlife Refuge, however has indicated the agency is not able to take over the project with the embankment in place.

RISK_STATEMENT: The Optima disposition study is included in the FY24 PRES BUD for $100,000, however this is zeroed out in the House and Senate FY24 markups.  CR guidance is request the lessor of PRES BUD or House/Senate markup. Risk of funds being depleted prior to completion of draft report/policy and legal review.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Unlikely at the present time, however in the event of a year-long CR the PDT may deplete funding prior to completion of 2nd Iteration.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Inability to complete the 2nd Iteration will result in a schedule shift to the right leading to additional study completion delays.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact if funds depleted prior to addressing comments received from the concurrent public and agency reviews and policy and legal reivews.

RISK_STATEMENT: Potential future changes to the project area's sediment budget may lead to the incorrect recommended plan. The current study assumes that the current bypassing at Santa Barbara Harbor continues indefinitely and there are no new substantial inputs of sediment that have been historically present. Additional sediment inputs to the system may lead to an over-designed project. Reductions of natural sediment inputs may lead to an under-designed project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sediment transport patterns are well-known near the project area. This risk would also not be realized until the project has been constructed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Uncertainty in the future sediment budget may lead to a inadequate project design and poor performance.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential adaptive management after initial project construction would be required. An additional construction phase would be required.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May require additional design and construction to support changed conditions in the future.

RISK_STATEMENT: Actual construction equipment, means and methods may differ than assumed during feasibility. This difference may result in insufficient environmental analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Contractors are typically allowed to propose their own construction means and methods to provide for the most economical construction.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional environmental analysis may be warranted.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Time to perform additional environmental analysis.

RISK_STATEMENT: There may be unidentified utilities in the area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Historic records indicate no structures were ever constructed within the construction limits but previous experience suggests that utilities may be present.

RISK_STATEMENT: There has been a delay in NFS funding contributions which may affect workflow. If funding does get delivered before the PDT runs out of funds the PDT may need to pause work.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_STATEMENT: Petitions to establish a Marine Protected Area (MPA) are ongoing. It is unknown the affect the MPA will have on the study. There is an ongoing comment period that is likely to last over a year. This risk is being added to ensure the PDT tracks the MPA and considers it in the Integrated Feasibility Report.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Depending on the outcome of the MPA. We could lose the ability to construct a project in the study area. It is possible to get an exemption from the MPA and that process is ongoing.

RISK_STATEMENT: Failure to adequately predict impacts of unwilling landowners to sell real estate needed for aquatic ecosystem restoration measures could lead to incorrect selection of the recommended plan since the benefit-cost ratio/annual net benefits would be wrong.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This risk was realized in previous studies of the Yolo Bypass. However, since the PDT is aware that real estate acquisition for AER could be a challenge for the study, flexibility in design will be part of the planning process. This will reduces chances of future changes altering the benefit-cost ratio for the project.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a patchwork of ownership in the study area, including land owned by another federal agency. This is a study risk because USACE cannot restore land owned by another federal agency, with some exceptions. Additionally, there are private landowners and ownership at state, county and/or city level.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the Recommended Plan includes restoration features that ultimately cannot be implemented because they are on private land, the ecosystem restoration may not realize all estimated project benefits, such as quantity of average restored and longitudinal habitat connectivity.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There may be a cost to the study if additional real estate coordination internally and externally (e.g., with BLM and County) is required beyond what is scoped. At this time the cost risk is unknown.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: he schedule may extend if additional real estate coordination internally and externally (e.g., with BLM and County) is required beyond what is scoped. At this time the additional coordination, if required, would be a few weeks.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: CRAM Model Approval for AZ and Training
RISK_STATEMENT: PDT proposes to use the Episodic Riverine Module of CRAM (California Rapid Assessment Method). CRAM is a cost-effective and scientifically defensible rapid assessment method for monitoring and assessing the ecological conditions of wetlands throughout California. The model is not yet approved for use in Arizona by the ECO-PCX, so there is a risk that the model will not be approved for use in the GRR.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Initial coordination with the ECO-PCX has been positive and indicates that CRAM will be determined as an acceptable model for this study.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the model is not approved, additional funds will be required to identify another suitable model and re-scope the study analyses. The additional study cost could be substantial but is unknown at this time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the model is not approved, additional time will be required to identify another suitable model and re-scope the study analyses. Additional time required could be substantial.

RISK_STATEMENT: Risk of lawsuit due to lack of stakeholder confidence in analysis and recommended plan.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current lawsuits underway within the Yolo Bypass.

RISK_STATEMENT: Risk of having to rerun hydraulics and economic analysis prior to the TSP.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: If this is discovered prior to TSP it will require rerunning the hydraulics and economics analysis. Preliminary feedback from Vertical Team engineers and economists indicated that the use of FLO2D results might have inconsistency with HEC-RAS channel stage assumptions.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate of level of effort for staff to revise the modeling.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Revising the modeling would require other subsequent, dependent models to need to be rerun as well.  This would lead to repeating the plan comparison effort to select a TSP.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Risk of inaccurate description of the FWOP Conditions due to the exclusion of current configuration of the Sacramento Weir and current Folsom Dam operations if using DWR stage frequency curves. 

Risk of changing the stage frequency curves late in the study would require reformulation and analysis due to all plans based upon assumption of FWOP conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The most likely project benefits would not be accurately depicted if current configuration and operation of the Sacramento Weir and Folsom Dam are excluded from analysis.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost reflects SME staff time (majority of the PDT) to rerun models, analysis, and comparison for the FWOP and all alternative plans to get to a recommended TSP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Time necessary to repeat the modeling, analysis, and comparison of the FWOP and all alternative plans to arrive at a recommended TSP.  Assumes repeat of all handoffs across the PDT.

RISK_STATEMENT: Risk that analysis will need to be repeated using FDA 2.0 if the sensitivity analysis effort to confirm that the existing FDA 1.43 results for the Yolo Bypass are significantly different than FDA 2.0.  The sensitivity analysis will test an important reach within the study area.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: New model versions have a history of being preferred by USACE Vertical Team members and Agency Technical Reviewers, thus indicating a likelihood of being asked to use FDA 2.0.  The sensitivity analysis would need to be performed in order to confirm or deny any significant differences between the model versions.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The Economics Section staff would have primary responsibility to revise approximately 50 model runs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate Economist team needing 2 months to perform the approximately 50 model run update.

RISK_STATEMENT: Risk is a delayed TSP with potential reanalysis if the decision-makers are unwilling to accept the uncertainty of 10-year old fragility curves created by NFS.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Possibility that the input from The Risk Management Center (RMC) may not occur until after/at the TSP.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Geotechnical SMEs must perform new fragility curve analysis, economist must perform new LifeSim analysis and FDA analysis for all alternative plans and FWOP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The alternative plans and FWOP involve extensive number of reaches, which must each be analyzed in turn. The timing of the risk being potentially realized is late in the study (TSP milestone).

RISK_STATEMENT: Action by by local stakeholders (such as BRRT) has already led to plans to remove barriers at several dams, including Dams 2, 4, and 6. USACE assumes these will be removed or modified for aquatic community restoration. The PDT considers the likelihood of these barrier removal actions not to be taken to be low. However, the impacts of any of these barriers not being removed would be significant.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Third-party working groups have been investigating and designing removal strategies and are currently in an advanced state of design for the process.  Dam #1 was removed in 2019 and mitigation funding has been identified for #2 to aid in fish passage.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If third party removal activities do not continue at dams downstream of this project, adjustment of scope and effort may need to be considered for improved fish passage in the waterway.

RISK_STATEMENT: Dams along the Brandywine have varied ownership, with a number having multiple owners (from both banks). Barrier removal feasibility depends on engaging these dam owners and finding mutually acceptable solutions. Property owners immediately beyond the dams also have vested interest in them (e.g. aesthetics and related property value). Some of them are more favorable than others towards dam modification.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Previous communications and interactions with the property owners has resulted in varying levels of interest expressed in the removal or alteration of the dams. A number of the dams have overlapping property owners or the state of DE.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Without access to the dam by the property owners removal/modification activities cannot be designed and completed. Easements would be needed potentially permanent and temporary for each of the dam locations.

PROJECT_NAME: San Joaquin River Basin, Lower San Joaquin River, California
RISK_STATEMENT: "Quantities could vary significantly.  Earthwork and cutoff wall quantities are probably conservative and are likely to be reduced during PED.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: No PED level survey is available. No specific designs/quantities based on surveyed cross sections has been developed. Quantities were calculated using tables with typical cross sections generated to capture the types of fixes needed along the levee as well as the existing geometry of the levee.  These sections were then referenced into a  spreadsheet where the type of fix, hydraulic data, and existing levee geometry were identified.  Many fixes with varying levee geometry were developed and quantities did not interpolate between the fixes, but used the next larger fix (taller levee, higher floodwall, deeper cutoff wall, etc.).
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
The base case is based on the MCACES Estimate Values			
Low assumes quantities decrease 5% for 11-Levees and Floodwalls			
High assumes a 10% increase for all other quantities.

The base case is based on the MCACES Estimate Values

RISK_STATEMENT:
Delay to TSP decision due to failure to get ecological models certified or approved by the ECO-PCX. USACE planning policy requires model certification or approval before they are used to a make a decision. The PDT needs to get approval for the California Vole Habitat Suitability Index (HSI) model, Chinook Salmon Habitat Quantification Tool or Yolo Bypass Salmon Benefits Model, and recertification for HEC-EFM. 

The California Vole HSI model has been used by the regional USFWS office to model benefits to fallow farmland. Some model document is available. 

A model is needed to model benefits to fish from floodplains or inundated farmland. No existing certified model is available. Both the Chinook Salmon Habitat Quantification Tool (created by UC Berkeley and Stillwater Sciences for the NRCS) and the Yolo Bypass Salmon Benefits Model (created by USBR) have been used in the Central Valley of California to model benefits to salmonids. 

HEC-EFM can be used to graphically display habitat suitability models to help identify opportunities for ecosystem restoration or to identify patterns. The current version is not certified by the ECO-PCX, while prior versions were certified.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT has discussed model approval and certification timelines with the ECO-PCX. Since less than one year is typically needed to get approval or certification and there are almost two years in the schedule until the TSP decision, it is very unlikely that the TSP decision would be delayed. In addition, the environmental team has successfully gotten three models approved by the ECO-PCX within the last year and, therefore, has experience compiling the needed model documentation and working through the approval process.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Model documentation already exists for all of the models. Therefore, the mostly likely cause of delays in approval or certification would come from staff workload issues at the ECO-PCX. Even if there were delays at the ECO-PCX, it is very unlikely that they would extend to two years and there would be no cost impacts. However, as an alternative, the PDT could pursue a policy exception for a cost of $50,000. Even in that situation, it is possible that the ECO-PCX would approve the models before the policy exception process was complete.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: In the worst case scenario, the TSP decision could be delayed by up to six months (180 days) while a policy exception was pursued.

RISK_NAME: Use of existing Tule Canal AER designs
RISK_STATEMENT: Use of existing Tule Canal aquatic ecosystem restoration designs could lead to study delays (e.g., to the TSP decision) due to lack of stakeholder buy-in. The California Department of Water Resources (DWR) and other organizations have preliminary designs for restoring parts of the Tule Canal. For example, the Conaway Preservation Group and Reclamation District 108 have created preliminary designs for restoring the middle portion of the Tule Canal. However, the PDT risks lack of buy-in and support from stakeholders/regulators if these designs are used.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NMFS, USFWS, and the California Department of Fish and Wildlife have stated in meetings that they want to be involved in designing AER alternatives for the Tule Canal. In addition, USBR (a cooperating agency) stated that the current designs fail to address uncertainties within the Bypass from other projects (such as widening the Fremont Weir). These uncertainties pertain to probable changes in hydroperiod (inundation frequency, depth, and duration) from other projects in the upper Bypass. Given this input, it is very likely that the TSP decision would have to be delayed to allow collaboration with the Services and cooperating agencies on Tule Canal restoration designs.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Since the Tule Canal provides irrigation water and drainage for landowners within the Yolo Bypass and habitat passage for listed species, it is likely that lack of stakeholder involvement in the designs will lead to litigation. Yolo County is currently suing DWR (one of the study sponsors) over the Big Notch Project based on how much water it allows into the Yolo Bypass for salmonids since the timing of water can impact landowners.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Creating new designs for the Tule Canal in a collaborative fashion with all of the stakeholders would take about $50,000 (with a range from $20,000 to $100,000) based on similar efforts for other feasibility studies within region.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on the Lathrop & Manteca study, it would take about 6 to 12 months to create designs for the Tule Canal through a collaborative process.

RISK_STATEMENT: Any limitations on barrier removal/modification for historic purposes could limit the number of viable solutions for barrier removal. Historic considerations are key across these dams as a number are in historic districts. The Hagley Museum and Library in particularly could have constraints on barrier removal options based on the historical dams and mill races present.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: With ownership of some of the dams by museums which detail the use of the dams as mill historically and the potential for some of the properties to be listed as state historic assets. The general area has a rich history in use of the water for industrialization.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If historic preservation dictates the need to keep the barrier in place it, depending on the specific dam, it could jeopardize the opportunities at other dams upstream.

RISK_STATEMENT:
The study assumes that sediment released through barrier removal would be acceptable in quantity and quality, such that it would not degrade river bottom habitats and water quality beyond its current location upstream of dams. DNREC (2020) reports that most sediment is along the banks rather than the central portions of the river, and mobilization will be dependent upon solution design. Barrier removal is not expected to increase toxicity due to metals, mercury, PCBs, dioxins, furans, and pesticides. o	There can also be short term increases in turbidity and downstream sedimentation.
o	Though risk here seems limited, any dam removal should consider the release of sediment that has built up behind the dam. While these dams are limited in size, given the working history and development within the region, any dam removal work should acknowledge the potential for the mobilization of contaminated sediments previously buried upstream of dams.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Available data suggests height of the dam and disposition of sediments would not cause additional impact to the aquatic community.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Various modeling and design alternatives could be considered for sediment management.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT has made the assumption that barrier removal would not significantly alter flood risk along the course of the river.  Removals are expected to result in reduced flood risk and water surface elevations at adjacent properties and along the impoundments up to moderate events, however these effects will likely be reduced during largest events when these structures are likely subject to backwater influence.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current dams are low head run of river type of dams that once removed should not significantly alter the flow dynamics of the river. Flood risk exists in the current state of the river and would be expected to decrease with the removal of the dams.

RISK_STATEMENT:
o	Precautions should be taken to ensure aquatic ecosystem restoration does not come at the expense of other species any endangered or threatened species in the study area. A database search of the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service Information for Planning and Conservation (IPAC) database was conducted on January 22, 2023 and the following threatened and endangered species have the potential to occur in the study area:
?	Indiana bat, Myotis sodalis, endangered
?	Northern long-eared bat, Myotis septentrionalis, endangered
?	Bog turtle, Glyptemys muhlenbergii, threantend
Given the presence of the dams, habitat for these species is not expected in the study area and should not be adversely impacted by barrier removal; however, potential impacts on these species should be considered during the feasibility study.  Barrier removal has the potential to provide beneficial effects for Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon.  USFWS and NMFS ESA Section 7 consultation should be conducted as required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Species screening tools from resource agencies were used to inform the potential presence of endangered species.

RISK_NAME: Use of existing USBR/DWR habitat model
RISK_STATEMENT: Use of the existing habitat model for waterfowl could delay TSP decision due to lack of buy-in from the USFWS.  The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) and California Department of Water Resources (DWR) developed a waterfowl habitat suitability index model for their Big Notch Project. Lack of support for model could delay the CE/ICA process and selection of TSP since relying on only one model could fail to adequately capture benefits for all habitats, especially for habitats that support species of resource significance. In addition, this could cause the study to fail to have net benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: USFWS has stated in several meetings that they would prefer that USACE use as many models as needed to capture all of the benefits across the varied habitats within the Yolo Bypass. Due to the presence of 21 ESA listed species and millions of migratory birds that use the Bypass, a varied approach is needed to correctly quantify benefits. It is very likely that by using only one habitat model that the USFWS would not support the project (this threat has been used by the same USFWS staff member on other projects this year). In addition, since the existing model only calculates benefits for waterfowl, it is very likely that benefits from several other habitats would not be captured in the model.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on current coordination with USFWS, four additional models would be needed to appropriately capture all of habitats within the project area. Gathering data and running these models will cost about $40,000 more (with a range of $20,000 to $60,000 based on the Lathrop and Manteca Study).
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on experience from other recent studies, it would take approximately six to nine months to run the additional models and reinitiate the consultation process.

RISK_NAME: Use of existing USBR/DWR fish ecology model
RISK_STATEMENT: Use of the existing fish ecology model to calculate benefits and effects could delay TSP decision due to lack of buy-in from the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS). The U.S. Bureau of Reclamation (USBR) and California Department of Water Resources (DWR) developed a fish ecology model for their Big Notch Project. Lack of support for this model could delay the CE/ICA process and selection of TSP. In addition, the existing model does not appear to appropriately quantify benefit to fish from seasonally flooded agricultural land.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that not involving NMFS in the model development would cause lack of support and delays to the schedule. The entire Bypass is critical habitat for Green Sturgeon, which is under the jurisdiction of NMFS. Having their involvement on model selection and development is essential to getting their support. In addition, the existing fish ecology model was designed to capture benefits from notching the existing Fremont Weir. Based on meetings with the DWR contractor that developed the model, it is likely that this model does not have all of the components needed to capture benefits from flooded agricultural lands.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on level of coordination needed for similar models on other studies (e.g., Lathrop and Manteca Study), the necessary model coordination with NMFS should cost about $15,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on level of coordination needed for similar models on other studies (e.g., Lathrop and Manteca Study), the necessary model coordination with NMFS would take about three to six months.

RISK_NAME: Significant impacts require an EIS instead of an EA
RISK_STATEMENT: Significant impacts to EJ communities, T&E species and habitat, and air quality cannot be mitigated to less than significant requiring completion of an EIS instead of an EA.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on prior studies, there is a likely chance that at least air quality impacts will be significant. The study area is either in non-attainment or maintenance for several criteria pollutants. Based on prior construction projects, any extensive concrete work such as widening the Fremont Weir by two miles, will have significant impacts on air quality. Sequencing to avoid impacts is not usually possible due to the nature of concrete work.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There are several recent examples of USACE getting sued by advocacy groups for failing to conduct an EIS (e.g., San Juan Bay dredging project). The risk of legal exposure could be reduced by spending funds and taking the time to do an EIS.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on the complexity of the Yolo Bypass system coupled with data on the cost differences between an EA and an EIS, the increase in costs would range from $200,000 to $500,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Shifting from an EA to an EIS would require requesting additional funds from HQ. This would most likely take about 6 months to secure. The additional analyses, writing, and CEQA coordination required for an EIS would take an additional 6 months beyond the current study schedule.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact would be dependent on whether or not a lawsuit is filed and the duration of time needed to resolve the legal actions.

RISK_NAME: Lack of willing sellers delays construction start
RISK_STATEMENT: Lack of landowners willing to sell real estate needed for aquatic ecosystem restoration (AER) portions of the project could delay construction due to re-design or reformulation. The non-Federal sponsors (NFS) can only use condemnation to acquire real estate for compensatory mitigation if there are no other options available. Condemnation is not an option for real estate needed for AER. Failure to acquire real estate would lead to re-designs and could impact the benefit-cost ratio of the project from increased real estate and design costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Several recent projects in the Central Valley of California have had challenges acquiring real estate needed for habitat mitigation. This has increased duration and costs during PED since lack of real estate leads to changes in designs, need for re-initiation of consultation with USFWS and NMFS, and additional NEPA documentation. Since USACE policy requires AER/mitigation to proceed concurrently with construction, and the USFWS would like mitigation to be started one year prior to the beginning of FRM construction, it is likely that real estate acquisition issues would delay the start of construction for the project.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Delays during PED that lead to construction delays tend to damage USACE's reputation by adding evidence that the agency experiences regular delays and is slow to get projects completed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on experiences with similar projects, the costs for re-design, reinitiation of consultation, and additional NEPA documentation would range from $500,000 to $1,500,000. This does not cover costs if additional plan formulation was needed.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It typically takes about one year to do re-designs, reinitiate consultation, and complete NEPA documentation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Delay to ADM due to discovery of unexpected HTRW could require a Phase 2 Site Assessment.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PDT conducted a preliminary assessment for HTRW prior to the AMM. No records of HTRW where located within the Yolo Bypass. In addition, the Bypass has been used for flood conveyance since the early 1900s. Flowage easements precluded development within the Bypass. Therefore, the risk of HTRW is low. Therefore, it is extremely unlikely that a Phase 2 Site Assessment will be required. PDT has scoped for a Phase 1 Site Assessment to be performed prior to the TSP.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A Phase II Site Assessment would most likely need to be contracted out. Given the contracting process, size of the project area, and impacts to study schedule, the costs are likely to be around $500,000.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: SPK does not currently have existing capacity on a MATOC to cover a contract for a Phase II Site Assessment. Typical contracting times range from 9 to 12 months. It takes three months to conduct a Phase II and then about three more months to update project documents.

RISK_NAME: Geotechnical Exploration Plan- Scope Change after TSP
RISK_STATEMENT: At the current study phase, a focused array of alternatives has been developed (a final array of alternatives has not yet been developed). Assumptions have been made for scoping purposes regarding the measures that will be included in the Recommended Plan; however, there is potential for those assumptions to change as the study progresses. The geotechnical exploration plan is adequate for a design supporting a class III cost estimate for the potential range of plans currently being evaluated by the study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Changes in the scope after TSP could necessitate changes (increases or decreases) in the scope of the geotechnical work; however, the estimated number of borings is deemed adequate for the range of measures under consideration in the focused array of alternatives. Identification of additional measures could necessitate additional explorations, while screening of measures could result in fewer explorations.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional measures may require more borings to inform site characterization based on assumption of minimum boring program spacing frequency of 2,000 ft along proposed improvements.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Any required additional explorations could be performed concurrent with currently scheduled borings.  Risk will be known at TSP milestone and further refined during final report milestone.

PROJECT_NAME: San Joaquin River Basin, Lower San Joaquin River, California
RISK_STATEMENT: Modifications will be experienced on any construction project.  Project Construction is heavily dependent on geotechnical design solutions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
"Modifications are to be expected.
Inherent with any geotechnical design comes the possibility of differing site conditions such as constructed depth of cutoff wall due to change in key in layer elevation and site geology which would not have previously been noted due to the density of explorations in a given area, groundwater chemistry issues affecting curing of the cutoff wall etc.
Most cutoff wall is 50' depth or less.  Few reaches go as deep as 70'.  Conventional cutoff wall construction can go as deep as 80'-85' therefore risk of change in construction approach is minimal. It would become vastly more expensive if additional depth could require a different construction method (i.e. standard cutoff wall to deep soil mixing)."

No Change			
Low assumes no change from the base case value			
High assumes 10% increase for Mods and Claims

RISK_NAME: Combined NEPA/CEQA delays release of integrated report
RISK_STATEMENT: Failure of NFS to complete draft CEQA portion of joint document could delay public release of the integrated report. This could be caused by insufficient design details for FRM/AER to complete CEQA analyses, lack of agreement among the NFS team on CEQA analyses, or failure of the NFS' consultants to complete the work NFS required to complete a joint NEPA/CEQA document. The level of resourcing scoped for NEPA/CEQA coordination could be insufficient. Currently, there are no published examples of a joint NEPA/CEQA document that follows the newest feasibility report template. The Lower San Joaquin River Lathrop and Manteca Feasibility Study has started to work on a draft integrated report with joint NEPA/CEQA. Therefore, some lessons can be learned from that study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT scoped some time for coordination with the NFS on integrating NEPA and CEQA. The PDT assumed that lessons from the joint NEPA/CEQA efforts on the Lower San Joaquin River Lathrop and Manteca Feasibility Study would lead to efficiencies on the Yolo Bypass Study. The NFS has an experienced team of consultants who are familiar with CEQA. However, the amount that was originally scoped was reduced based on feedback from USACEHQ. In addition, conducting CEQA for a USACE feasibility study is different from typical CEQA efforts and the level of detail provided by the PDT for effects analyses is less than typically required under CEQA. Finally, if the NFS failed to complete CEQA in a timely fashion, USACE could decide to move forward and release the draft integrated feasibility report without CEQA since it is not a requirement for public release. Therefore, it is unlikely that issues with CEQA would delay the release of the draft integrated report. However, since the NFS might push back against separate NEPA and CEQA, there could still be delays to the public release, but it is unlikely.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Based on the scope that was provided for the Lathrop and Manteca Feasibility Study, additional coordination would require about $100,000. However, if the PDT decides to proceed to public release without CEQA, then the impacts to budget would be $0.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the PDT decides, to wait for CEQA before public release, the likely delay is 180 days. However, the PDT could decide to proceed to public release without CEQA, which would not cause a delay to the schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: NESP Lock and Dam 25 New 1,200 ft Lock
RISK_NAME: Concrete Mix Design and Thermal Analysis
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT has identified the need to perform a LEVEL III NISA thermal analysis for the concrete mix design. The resource availability across USACE with this level of expertise is limited and resources must be procured from ERDC, USBR or AE services. The current schedule assumes the IDaC contractor will conduct this work but due to procurement delays we are attempting to leverage other resources. The risk is that we are not able to obtain the resources within the current baseline schedule and that we have to delay the design completion.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The resources within USACE that have expertise to conduct these designs and analysis are not readily available. The team is working to engage USBR, ERDC and/or an AE but it is likely that lead times to obtain these services could delay the project design schedule.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This delay would have some reputational risk tot he agency but also would be a relatively understandable dealy.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The baseline labor estimate for PED already includes accomplishments of these tasks. So there is no cost impact to the PED phase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The highest likely delay is probably 9 months just based on the level of effort estimated for the NISA analysis. A more likely delay would be around 6 months because of the work that has already occurred to advance this effort.

PROJECT_NAME: NESP Lock and Dam 25 New 1,200 ft Lock
RISK_STATEMENT: The risk includes the possibility that in coordination with navigation industry certain constraints and assumptions are incorporated into the design that could lead to construction cost and schedule impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While it is possible that some constraints that navigation industry proposes gets incorporated into the P&S the team also has tools to evaluate and potentially mitigate for these potential outcomes.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk has some reputational considerations as well but operationally this risk could lead to challenges in day-today operations of the existing 600 ft chamber and our ability to be responsive to the users of the lock.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Most impacts to cost are likely due to potential delays and how escalation could affect total project costs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts could be related to the need to minimize impacts to the 600 ft chamber which could lead to increases in construction duration/schedule.

PROJECT_NAME: NESP Lock and Dam 25 New 1,200 ft Lock
RISK_STATEMENT: The seismic design requirements for many large USACE civil works projects are nebulous at best. Currently a variety of USACE SMEs are engaged in the project to determine what the requirements, criteria and design load cases should be for the project. This has a chance to increase design times and construction costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The chances that the seismic design criteria impacts the project are likely. There is enough uncertainty involved that most USACE SMEs will tend to require conservative approaches.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Delays in project schedule and increase in project costs due to seismic criteria changes can have negative impacts to agency reputation.

RISK_STATEMENT: Could increase the cost and lower the BCR of the alternative(s) that include adaptable features.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Alternatives should be resilient, so it is likely that there may be some adaptable features included in alternatives under consideration.

RISK_STATEMENT: Geographic scope is limited to political/corporate limits of Norfolk, which could limit the ability of the study to identify the "big solution" for Hampton Roads. Watersheds and some large infrastructure/utilities cross municipal boundaries. Will have to ensure that recommended project does not negatively impact surrounding municipalities, Naval Station Norfolk, etc.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: May forego a bigger, more holistic solution; and therefore, flooding may not be reduced as much and other areas (outside of Norfolk) would not benefit. The consequence is more for regional neighbors.

RISK_NAME: Planned but unconstructed projects in FWOP.
RISK_STATEMENT: Inclusion of planned but unconstructed projects in the FWOP. Generally, these projects, such as the Willoughby Spit and Vicinity CSRM project, are going to be constructed before the TSP for this study is authorized, but it is possible that the projects do not perform as planned and/or there is a small chance that due to some extenuating circumstances they might not be constructed as planned.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The projects included in the FWOP condition have full funding and authorization and it is completely reasonable to assume they will be constructed by the time this study is complete.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The FWOP condition is what alternatives are compared against and what drives a lot of plan formulation assumptions. Assuming that certain projects will be completed and part of the FWOP condition means that some measures may be screened out and there is an assumed level of protection applied to those projects that impacts plan formulation for the study.

RISK_STATEMENT: Use of new NACCS data vs FEMA accepted data. NACCS has higher water levels than FEMA data.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Water levels are an estimate.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Analysis may be skewed toward higher damages and project design, thus cost may be higher than they would have been if FEMA values were used.

RISK_STATEMENT: Defer new GeoEnvironmental exploration/testing to PED phase. Using existing information for feasibility study could lead to contaminated material being found during PED and incomplete information about subsurface conditions. Both of these could result in the need for a more expensive design and could also increase construction schedule and cost for change orders/modifications.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The study area is relatively large, and it is probable that there will be some incomplete GeoEnvironmental data.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May result in additional design and construction costs. If conditions are different than what existing information indicates, the design will have to be modified.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: May result in additional design and construction time. If conditions are different than what existing information indicates, the design will have to be modified.
