RISK_STATEMENT: There are several drainage inlets in the project vicinity that are unknown. These inlets are assumed to have a very small impact on removing flow from the system. According to the local municipality these inlets do not connect to any other drainage path that they are aware of. The model will not consider these inlets as the effect on flow will be negligble.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Will need to update the hydrology model

RISK_STATEMENT:
Independent External Peer Review is not included in FS Review Plan. Mandatory triggers for IEPR have either not been met (EIS, controversy, Governor request) or are unknown (cost); no EIS is an exclusion consideration and life safety considerations are not loss of life, so team determined not to warrant an IEPR.

Evidence: The flood hazard impacts on life safety are less consequential than direct loss of life; significant controversy is not expected based initial scoping and screening and on existing information from NFS; see EIS risk entry for understanding of that risk.

If measures and alternatives and their analyses are not evaluated outside of the agency by experts in the field, there is a risk that information could be overlooked and that credibility is affected if not reviewed externally.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The liklihood that the decision to not conduct IEPR would need to be changed because one of the triggers is met is met is very low.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If measures and alternatives and their analyses are not evaluated outside of the agency by experts in the field, there is a risk that information could be overlooked and that credibility is affected if not reviewed externally.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: While there would be a cost to organize and fund external peer reviewers to conduct the review, funding for IEPR does not come out of the 3x3 FS allocated funds; separate programmed funds are used so it would not impact the $3.9M budget that has already been approved.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Ideally, IEPR is done during concurrent review of the Draft FS Report so would not require additional time in the schedule

RISK_STATEMENT: Increase in rainfall and extreme storm events directly impacts the hydrologic analysis. Uncertainties associated with different climate variables is relevant to the accuracy hydrologic analysis. Additional time (<1mo) for coordination may need to be included.  Will be concurrent with other Hydrologic impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Increase in rainfall and extreme storm events directly impacts the hydrologic analysis.  Based on the evidence by the Climate COP, intensity and frequency of events are occuring.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost estimates would increase if rainfall or climate chnage increases.  Unsure on the exact cost implication but wall heights would increase.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Including into the projected model shows that there is an increase in wse.  Increase the height of walls.

PROJECT_NAME: Tennessee Tombigbee and Black Warrior Tombigbee Waterway Navigation Improvement Study
RISK_STATEMENT:
Implemenation Risk - Depth or width increase may cause impact to utility causing potential for relocation. High Cost and Schedule increase if a utility line is found to be w/in the deepening/wideing area and relocation is necessary by Atty Opinion of Compensability.

In implementation, Utility/Pipeline relocations require extensive coordination, development of drawings / cost estimates, and in this scenario, the USACE Real Estate Contracting Officer would need to enter into a relocation agreement w/ the impacted utility owner.  In conjunction w/ the actual relocation, the timeline can be protracted considerably.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: An impact to previously unknown pipelines in implementation may cause environmental or other damage depending on the type of the pipeline.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There is a very wide range of potential cost drivers for utility / facility relocations depending on the nature of the utility and other factors
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Pipeline relocations require extensive coordination, development of drawings / cost estimates, and in this scenario, the USACE Real Estate Contracting Officer would need to enter into a relocation agreement w/ the impacted utility owner.  In conjunction w/ the actual relocation, the timeline can be protracted considerably.

RISK_STATEMENT: Tide floodwalls/line of protection may tie into existing infrastructure (highways, dams, etc.) that is not certified for FRM. Unless the infrastructure can be certified for use as part of the line of protection, then the alignment of the measures may have to be altered to not include existing infrastructure.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is likely that levee safety regulations would apply to existing infrastructure that is tied into and/or used as part of the line of protection.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Alignment of the structural line of protection may have to be changed if existing high ground/infrastructure cannot be used.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Alignment of the structural line of protection may have to be changed if existing high ground/infrastructure cannot be used.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Alignment of the structural line of protection may have to be changed if existing high ground/infrastructure cannot be used.

RISK_NAME: Cost variation up to construction award.
RISK_STATEMENT: Unexpected market forces driving up cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Experience with Hurricane Sandy has had an effect on dredging cost regionally.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Inflation, national disasters can affect regional prices. BCR could change ranking of alternative.

RISK_NAME: Using 50% CI for NACCS water levels.
RISK_STATEMENT: Increase chance of overtopping, since we are choosing the median value for all return periods.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: First generation of CSRM projects using NACCS water levels; revision will occur in the second generation of projects.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Reiteration of alignments and height of structures. Lack of consensus among technical authorities; NACCS numbers are higher than FEMA numbers.

RISK_NAME: Lack of utility survey and analysis for road relocations.
RISK_STATEMENT: Lack of utility survey and analysis for road relocations may underestimate the construction cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: In general, it looks like there will be a lot of utility and road locations, but it seems that these costs are not significant enough comparing to the vast construction cost elements of the project.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Lack of utility survey and analysis for road relocations may underestimate the construction cost. There is contingency for design unknowns, but it may not be adequate.

RISK_STATEMENT: Lengthy project alignment in some areas may result in multiple construction phases. The current estimate does not include such consideration.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Usually, large construction projects will cause multiple phasing and incremental funding.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Multiple phases usually cause cost increase due to multiple mob/demob and due to different acquistion strategies.  These cost increases should typically be in medium range considering project of this size. There is a contingency for design unknowns, but it may not be adequate.

RISK_NAME: Additional Sediment in channels from erosion

Change in flow characteristics of the channel affecting accuracy of the models. May result in more sediment to remove from the channel or a change in the floodplain bench elevation.

SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Inaccuracies of the models may cause to redo models.  Mitigated by CCU bathymetric surveys in heavily vegetated areas. Occurring while project is ongoing.

RISK_STATEMENT: New land uses within the basin  causing Increase in imperviousness. May result in higher storm flows, or structures within the floodplain

Different Focus Areas have different flooding types within them

RISK_STATEMENT: There are currently 24 recorded archaeological sites within the Reservoir boundaries.  Approximately ten sites, including 3 rock shelter sites, are between the existing water level and the proposed high flood retention limits.  These indigenous archaeological sites are currently unevaluated, but may be eligible for listing on the National Register of Historic Places.  Rock shelter sites are a unique type of archaeological sites, as they often show continual human habitation with a wealth of artifacts spanning thousands of years.  Inundation of these sites will cause erosion and changes in context.  Context, which is where an artifact is found and its association with others, is the most important information archaeologist gather from a site.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Resources are well know and previous studies and consultation have occurred to understand what is present.

RISK_NAME: Operation Data to Support Trenton Flow Objective Modeling
RISK_STATEMENT: Preliminary study results show limited benefit to the Trenton Flow Objective but have not incorporated updated operating procedures from DRBC. Further understanding of how FE Walter water would be used to support the Trenton Flow Objective is needed from DRBC during Feasibility.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: To date limited operational data has been provided from DRBC in regards to how the additional storage volume would be used to support drought resilience in the basin.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Without the information needed to model the additional water storage project benefit would be hard to estimate.

RISK_STATEMENT: Adjacent to the Hoosic River there are potential Hazardous, Toxic and Radioactive Waste (HTRW) areas due to historical mill, textile, and coal storage sites.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There may be some sites that might impact where we are able to implement measures.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk is directly related to compliance for HTRW regulations. It potentially impacts how many measures we will be able to use based on what is found within the EDR and Environmental Site Assessment.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The PDT decided to do a EDR study to see what is within the site area and that costs $1200. If more detail is needed the PDT would add an additional cost up to the originally quoted $4000.

RISK_NAME: Floodwalls More Deteriorated / Unknown Existing Conditions
RISK_STATEMENT: 2022 condition assessment was provided by town.  Potential for further deterioration of existing concrete chutes, walls, and dams is potential risk. Additionally, there are unknown detailed existing conditions about the floodwalls.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: 2022 condition assessment for the concrete chutes and walls in pretty recent; however, show systemic issues and potential for continued panel failure and deterioration.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Continuation of annual condition assessments and validation from the USACE study team significantly lessens this risk and its impact.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Several alternatives include limited and system wide concrete repairs to the concrete chutes and walls.  The limited repairs alternative to just known failures carries the most risk for potential cost to repair growth.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: 2023 engineering condition assessment report of the town concrete chutes and walls is due from their A-E by Jan 2024.

RISK_STATEMENT: NA
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Adverse Effects to Cultural Resources or Operating within Hi
RISK_STATEMENT: There may be an adverse effect on historic properties if alternatives are proposed in undisturbed areas, or if alternatives are proposed to demolish or alter existing structures. Evaluations would be needed for affected properties that have not been evaluated for the National Register of Historic Places (NRHP). Archaeological investigations may be needed for alternatives proposed in undisturbed areas.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on the MA SHPO cultural resources database, there are several properties within areas of proposed NNBF that have not been evaluated for the NRHP. Any areas of proposed restoration (stream or wetland) would need to be assessed for the nature and extent of previous disturbance. Any floodwall and levee setback would need to be assessed for the nature and extent of previous disturbance.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is a risk that NRHP-eligible properties are identified that would lead to adverse effects mitigation if the effect could not be avoided.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact would be the cost of evaluations and investigations
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If needed, these would be conducted between AMM and ADM.

RISK_NAME: Borrowed historical costs may not be adequate.
RISK_STATEMENT: Historic cost of similar flood closure structures from different project sites that may not have the same geotechnical conditions may not be adequate for this project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It's a 50/50 change that historical cost of flood closure structures may not be adequate for this project. Historical costs may also be too conservative.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Historical costs can be conservative at times and can also be underestimated because of site differences.

RISK_NAME: Estimates for future storm intensity/frequency not included.
RISK_STATEMENT: Due to a lach of data, the study does not incorporate estimates for future storm intensity or frequency. Changes in storm frequency and/or intensity would change the design water surface elevation which will impact project benefits, costs, and/or flood risks
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Literature citing evidence regarding climate change impacts on storm frequency and intensity are not well established such that estimates can be made, however, there is enough literature discussing the topic that there is a reasonable case to believe higher frequencies and greater intensities are possible.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Due to the low-lying nature of Norfolk, relatively small changes in water surface elevation can have large impacts on project costs and flood risks. Increased storm intensity and/or frequency could cause the design to change which could increase costs for the project. Flood risks may rise which would reduce the level of risk management of the recommended plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Due to the low-lying nature of Norfolk, relatively small changes in water surface elevation can have large impacts on project costs and flood risks. Increased storm intensity and/or frequency could cause the design to change which could increase costs for the project. Flood risks may rise which would reduce the level of risk management of the recommended plan.

RISK_NAME: Use of HAZUS and repetitive loss data.
RISK_STATEMENT: Use of HAZUS and repetitive loss, developed during the update of the Hampton Roads Regional Hazard Mitigation Plan, was used in combination with NACCS Tier 1 and Tier 2 grids to characterize risk and locate structural measures. HAZUS is not a USACE approved model and data is estimated by FEMA's methodology and not the Corps.  Also, FEMA repetitive loss does not include privately insured or non-insured structures.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: HAZUS information is a very effective way to generalize and focus area of study. This area is heavily studied and datasets are considered best available data.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Influences location of structural measures. This area is heavily studied and datasets are considered best available data.

RISK_STATEMENT: The study is a coastal-based study and there may be tidal influences, so wave action (if any) will not be considered in economic formulation outside of Willoughby Beach. Coastal Modeling System output cannot be used as an input to HEC-FDA.  Beach-Fx will be used in the sandy beach area of Willoughby. The remainder of the city is coastal, but the shoreline is not sandy beach.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: With most of the structures outside of the coastal footprint, there may be little to no wave impact on the structures.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Damages assessed could be underestimated. Damages assessed could be underestimated.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Project scope and schedule did not permit the ability to survey 60,000+ structures.  Surveying should be completed, as needed, as the project enters PED.

Use LiDAR to determine lowest adjacent grade (LAG). Use site visits, Google Maps, and parcel data to determine foundation type and height. LAG + foundation height equals first floor elevation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are structure surveys for the Willoughby area and some elevation certificates available which can be combined with assumptions based on foundation type and ground truthed with some windshield surveys.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: First floor elevation will not be exact. Inaccurate elevation levels impact damage amounts. Reduction in damages is key to determining net benefits and BCR.

RISK_NAME: Use parcel data to populate structure inventory.
RISK_STATEMENT: Parcel data will be used to populate structure inventory. Some of the information may not be complete or accurate.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The team believes that the parcel data is the best source of information in spite of any errors.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Some of the structures may be characterized incorrectly or missing. There may be some additions/structures not permitted throughout the city or information may be inaccurate.

RISK_STATEMENT: Inaccurate assumptions will impact the formulation and evaluation of alternatives.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Inaccurate representations are not uncommon at this stage of the study. Various flood reduction efforts are being implemented by Horry County are in different stages of permitting. The project delivery team considered prior studies and reports, consulted policy reviewers, and ensured compliance with engineering regulations to inform the inclusion or exclusion of each effort in the FWOP.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impact range reflects if and when Horry County implements each flood reduction effort and during which study phase implementation occurs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact range reflects if and when Horry County implements each flood reduction effort and during which study phase implementation occurs.

RISK_STATEMENT: Misidentifying problems and opportunities can lead to ineffective plan formulation, evaluation, and implementation. Limited site condition information including first hand accounts from the sponsor, stakeholders, and the public could result in misidentification of problems and opportunities. This is most likely to occur earlier in the scoping phase. The risk to plan formulation will be reduced as the study progresses.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The planning process is iterative. To mitigate the risk of misidentified problems and opportunities, the team will seek consensus at various checkpoint leading up to the tentatively selected plan milestone. At which time the problems and opportunities may be restructured.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk is not expected to have a substantial impact on cost. The cost estimate was determined assuming restructured problems and opportunities may require additional coordination and labor.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk is not expected to have a substantial impact on the schedule. The schedule estimate was determined assuming restructured problems and opportunities requires additional coordination and labor.

RISK_STATEMENT: The nonstructural aggregation strategy limits the application of management measures. The nonstructural plan applied measures based on estimated damages to community, structural, and topographical characteristics. This risk would occur during the scoping phase and impact plan evaluation and selection.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Application of nonstructural measures is determined using estimated flood depths above the first floor elevation under existing conditions. The nonstructural aggregation strategy assumes flood risk under existing conditions is equivalent or less than flood risk under FWOP conditions. Likelihood of realizing this risk accounts for the variation between existing and FWOP conditions, but remains very unlikely because increases in population size, development, sea level rise, and other climatic changes are expected to increase flood depths and worsen flood risks.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Limited application of management measures based on the nonstructural aggregation strategy has the potential to minimize flood risk reduction. This impacts the performance of of the nonstructural plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The formulated plan may include areas exhibiting flood risks during existing conditions that are not be present under FWOP conditions. This could cause overestimation of the nonstructural plan.

RISK_STATEMENT: Section 106 consultation is ongoing. The need for a programmatic agreement has yet to be determined. Administering a programmatic agreement could extend study timeline and cost. This risk may be realized if it is determined that a programmatic agreement is needed and is not considered during schedule and budget development.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The likelihood was assumed based on the duration of the study. Consultation for Section 106 will be complete prior to the agency decision milestone which will determine the need for a programmatic agreement.

RISK_STATEMENT: The current decision document for compliance under NEPA is planned to be an Environmental Assessment (EA) to be integrated into the Feasibility Report. Its possible at some point in the study, following consultation with cooperating agencies and development of more information, that an EA is determined to be inadequate in scope and that an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) is required. This would extend the feasibility phase budget and scope needs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: I believe the currently proposed measured could be designed with conservation measures in place to reduce the likelihood of significantly adverse outcomes, in addition to compensatory mitigation measures to offset loss of wetlands. This may prevent the need to prepare an EIS. However, the need cannot be discounted.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This would prolong the Feasibility Phase for upwards of a year.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This estimate is based on budgeting for an entire year of additional environmental funding.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This would likely add an additional year of work

RISK_NAME: Stability of the Existing Floodwalls if the Base Slab is Rem
RISK_STATEMENT: If the concrete slab/chute (not walls) is removed for the purpose of restoring river ecology and natural stream restoration, there is a high risk that the vertical walls will need to be buttressed, reinforced with anchors, or stabilized in some manner.  This would furher be complicated if impacted by shallow bedrock.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The existing walls are designed with the current slab in-place for passive resistence.  If the rigidity of the slab is removed, that stability will need to be compensated with buttressing or anchors.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Buttressing decreases channel capacity and forces stream deepening.  Channel flow conditions may change due to width and depth changes from current state.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The impacts for cost are significant due to additional engineering, specialty construction methods, and materials. Cost noted here is for the engineering needed to complete the additional engineering.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Design schedule would be increased due to additional stability analyses and alternatives analysis.  Construction would have time impacts for construction of additional features.

RISK_NAME: Climate Impact Hydrology - Frequency of Storms
RISK_STATEMENT: Due to unknown information about climate in inland areas from the Climate CoP, the study could be impacted should additional requirements be necessary. Could have impacts on design team and could have large impacts on the design of the alternative.

RISK_STATEMENT: Potential large impacts to the study due to the need to eliminate impacts to surrounding areas. Due to new requirements, may not be able to show any increase in water surface elevations.

RISK_STATEMENT: The City may have political difficulty acquiring properties along the Hoosic River in the central downtown area, especially for Alternative 5, due to the land not being able to be acquired (such as if it is owned by the State), or the unpopularity among residents and businesses in condemning homes or land owned by important/influential City businesses such as MASS MoCA
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: We have not yet heard from riverfront landowners, especially MASS MoCA museum, which owns much of the land near where where the North and South branches meet

RISK_NAME: NACCS water elevation data with 50% CI.
RISK_STATEMENT: Use NACCS water elevation data for the entire project analysis. The 50% confidence interval (CI) was chosen for use for all return intervals analyzed. There have been other studies on water elevation levels, including FEMA and the results have varied. Using a 50% CI increases the uncertainty in water surface elevations for a given return interval but closes the gap between NACCS and FEMA (locally recognized).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Elevation levels at the 2-percent annual chance event varies by almost 2 feet in some areas of the study.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Water surface elevations per frequency will vary from other sources (FEMA). Analysis would differ from FEMA's flood insurance rate maps.

RISK_STATEMENT:
Use of depth-damage relationships developed as part of NACCS and depth-damage relationships from 2013 expert elicitation sessions for non-residential occupancies rather than generic residential depth-damage relationships and depth-damage relationships from another area of the country. 

Since generic depth-damage relationships and contents-to-structure value ratios (CSVRS) are not being used and the relationships are not site-specific, then the damages and content values estimated for inundated structures may be over- or under-estimated or could be judged by reviewers to be not compliant with Corps regulations.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The depth-damage relationships CSVRS developed as part of NACCS and 2013 elicitation are similar to those developed for other areas.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
Depth-damage relationships and CSVRs are an important input to developing flood damages for the project alternatives.  If the flood damages are not accurate or do not meet Corps guidelines, then the plan selection and economic justification of alternatives could be determined with a high level of uncertainty. 

Site-specific depth-damage relationships and CSVRS are not readily available, especially for non-residential structures, however, the relationships developed as part of NACCS and the 2013 expert elicitation sessions are for similar structure occupancies and were developed for coastal areas.

RISK_NAME: Several prototypes of historic structures vs full inventory.
RISK_STATEMENT: Developed several prototype historic structures rather than a complete inventory of historic structures in the evaluation area.  The prototypes will be used to develop inputs for RSMeans 2017 to calculate depreciated replacement values for each individual structure. The individual building values will be based on characteristics of the prototype structures which could lead to over- or under-valuing the individual historic structures.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There are distinct neighborhoods containing historic structures within the evaluation area.  This should allow for prototypes for be developed for structures in separate neighborhoods.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
The valuation of the structures will affect the damage calculations used for the project alternatives.  If the historic structures that are not individually similar to the prototypes, then the damages used for the project alternatives will have a high level of uncertainty. 

While the historic structures are not all alike, they are expected to have similar structural characteristics to each other within a neighborhood.  This should allow for a relatively accurate valuation of the structures and reduce the uncertainty surrounding the values. 

In addition to the economic valuation of the historic structures, the significance of the historic structures, to Norfolk and the region, will be addressed in the Environmental Quality (EQ) project account.

RISK_STATEMENT: Beach-FX will only be used for structures north of Ocean View Avenue (approximately 500ft upland from the beach). The rest of the city will be evaluated using HEC-FDA. It is possible that some benefits may not be captured in the areas where the two models meet. This may result in under estimating damages caused by Pretty Lake flooding to beach front homes.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is not standard procedure to use two models for one study, so there is not a lot of prior experience in this method to help inform how it works in practice.  However, the other focus area studies are also combining Beach-FX and HEC-FDA so it is expected that there will be lessons learned shared between studies as each District begins evaluation of alternatives.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC:
It is possible that some benefits may not be captured in the areas where the two models meet. This may result in under estimating damages caused by Pretty Lake flooding to beach front homes. 

It is possible that some benefits may be lost where the models meet, however, compared to the total number of structures in the entire study area, the number of structures along the model boundaries is relatively small, so if some benefits are not captured, it would not be expected to significantly alter the outcome of the economic analysis.

RISK_NAME: Identification of Unknown Cultural Resources/Inadvertent Dis
RISK_STATEMENT: Potential for unknown Cultural Resources that could impact access. Potential for unintended cultural resources impacts. Previous surveys focus primarily on historic properties and known archaeological sites. These surveys may have missed resources in those areas or in other project areas that were not surveyed.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Conduct required SEC 106 consultation. Perform investigations/recovery efforts as required per consultation.

RISK_STATEMENT: There is some inherent risk of uncertainty in accuracy of evaluating resource conditions of impacts from alternatives when done without site visits and field data collection.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a relatively high degree of likelihood that the accuracy of desktop evaluation of resource impacts will not be as accurate as performing site visits and collecting a host of field data.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Though a more accurate strategy is optimal, it is not feasible given the scale of the project and limited resources and time. Planning will perform as much field data collection as is feasible and determined to be beneficial.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This is a qualitative effect to the project as there is now ay to assign a dollar value to accuracy of scope.

RISK_STATEMENT: Given the scale of the study area and the number of structural measures being proposed across a vast area of a watershed, there is likely a significant degree of error in estimating the calculable extent of wildlife and environmental resources significantly impacted both directly and indirectly by implementing the TSP(s). The method currently being applied for calculating impacts is based on the concept that impacts can be assessed using geographic information system (GIS) software and comparing hydrological modeling with existing databases which classify and define extent of resource boundaries. There is not only inherent human errors common to all methodology, but error from a lack of spatial and temporal accuracy that is inherent in land classification databases, as well as error which may originate in hydrologic models. The cumulative potential for error represents the risk captured here.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The likelihood that error exists is practically inevitable. Thought the relative impact is of greater importance.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk represents a minor problem, as the relative degree of uncertainty in calculations does not impact the overall performance of the project from a flood risk management perspective. It does, however, reflect a minor problem in the sense that public and agency relations are affected by the degree of reliability on our studies and inherent accuracy. Furthermore, the accuracy in estimating mitigation needs determines the amount of real impacts which are offset and the degree to which resources conserved or not.

RISK_NAME: Study Area Boundary Does not Capture Full Extent of Impacts
RISK_STATEMENT: Given that the current iteration of the study area boundaries end abruptly outside of some structural measures considered or selected for TSP(s), it is very possible that hydrological impacts associated with the measures are not captured in the analyses based on data clipped within the study area boundaries.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It has already been established that this is applicable to the current study area boundary as the proposed road raising measure in Bucksport is not captured in its entirety.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This represents what is likely a relatively minor problem as it is assumed most of the impacts are captured in the study area analysis, and that this issue may still be addressed prior to the end of the feasibility phase.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assuming about 15 acres of wetlands/sensitive wildlife habitat may be impacted beyond the current boundary of the Bucksport Highway raising measure, and assuming a low estimate cost of restoration at $1k an acre and contingency, its is very possible this could increase costs associated with this measure by $20k. Other areas may include upstream of the Socastee Floodwalls, upstream of Simpson Creek, and upstream of the Longs Floodwalls. In total, for environmental mitigation alone, this could increase costs by up to $50k.

RISK_STATEMENT: Nonstructural alternatives could pose significant real estate administrative costs (such as relocation benefits, condemnation costs, etc).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: most of the real estate intensive plans are no longer being considered. It is less likely now that real estate costs are not within expected ranges.

RISK_STATEMENT:
This risk is for construction activities in the river for the new lock that are susceptible to high water, weather delays caused by river elevation or velocities, etc.

High water could cause stoppage of certain construction activities,  such as Divers, concrete placement, or cofferdam overtopping after the lock chamber is unwatered.

Since construction is being done on the river it is very likely to impact the project cost and schedule over the 7 year construction timeframe. Impacts of project delays or temporary demobilizations would be marginal. Cost and time would increase if the lock chamber cofferdam is overtopped while in an unwatered state.

RISK_STATEMENT: The current study scope assumed that measures are likely to involve a combination of rehabilitation of the deteriorated FRM system and ecological improvements to the project. If dam modification/removal is included in the study scope past-AMM, there may be additional need for funding and time to complete any required risk and engineering analysis for dam removal.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Likelihood is based on a fish passage improvement alternative that includes dam removal or modification. This alternative is unlikely to move forward based on the PDT's professional opinion since it would require removing a sediment catch basin (the Eclipse Dam) which would involve a significant amount of additional effort and may compromise the original concrete chute design.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE:
Cost is based on need for RMC risk analysis, further engineering analysis, and Hydraulic modeling for dam alternative for similar projects.
Dam removal is the lower end and the higher end is inclusive of the dam modification process.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Risk analysis is the task that may require additional time and is not captured in the current schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: USACE Hydraulic modeling is outdated and is missing significant portions of the modeling inputs to be able to accurately represent the hydraulic conditions of the watershed. A  HEC-RAS model developed by the non-Federal sponsor's contractor is available and may reduce the need for substantial site surveys and development of model features.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
6-month delay in federal funding could push the originally approved schedule to the right.
 
Likelihood is occurring and its based on current availability of data and missing flood inundation data to adequately characterize flood risk.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Additional time requires to complete future without project modeling following the AMM to capture existing conditions and flood risk in the study area.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost estimates include this assumption and this is accounted for in another risk. (Study Cost Increase Required Engineering Analysis)
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Accounting for the time it takes to perform the task and the targeted DQC and ATR, the most likely delay is 150 days.

RISK_NAME: HEC-FDA does not take erosion into account.
RISK_STATEMENT: HEC-FDA does not take erosion into account and erosion rates are expected to increase as sea levels rise in the future. Damages may be underestimated by the model due to the risk not being fully captured by the model.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: All recent USACE FRM projects have successfully used the HEC-FDA model to develop projects.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: It is possible that benefits may be underestimated because model is not accounting for land loss due to increased erosion. HEC-FDA does consider SLR, just not the erosion aspect of climate change that can exacerbate land loss.

RISK_STATEMENT: Consider community continuity/cohesion for nonstructural measures after TSP. Possibly lower BCR for total area, but better outcome than cherry picking individual structures based on positive or highest BCR.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: In speaking with other planners from the New Orleans District and the Nonstructural Committee, this is common practice in FRM projects that involve a nonstructural component.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This consequence is actually a benefit in terms of neighborhood cohesion and environmental/social justice.

COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Possible underestimation of total project cost. Comparison with construction projects in similar areas can help minimize potential impact.

RISK_NAME: Study Cost Increase - Required Engineering Analyses
RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT has estimated that in order to perform the tasks outlined in the PMP for the three chosen example alternatives (3, 4, and 5), additional funding will be needed to reach a feasibility level of design for a Class 3 Cost Estimate.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The lack of additional funding would not allow the engineering team to perform enough analysis to review all of the alternatives that they estimated for.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The Engineering section estimated the need for an additional $800,000 to accomplish the tasks needed to get to the required engineering analysis for a class 3 cost estimate for the selected example alternatives.

RISK_STATEMENT: Sediment Transport Analysis, beyond Level 1 that would require field testing to ascertain exiting field conditions
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The likelihood depends on which of the alternative are determined to move forward. If an alternative with Stream Restoration or channel removal is selected, Sediment impacts will need to be analyzed.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Depending on State requirements, this may be deemed a Major problem.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Sediment Transport analysis past the Level 1 minimum requirements will require additional geotechnical sample collection, analysis and modeling
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts would be several months (180 is an estimate).  The reason for this would be, a site visit to determine Bed and Bank sample locations, then sending the crew out for sample collection, followed by sample analysis, then then Sediment transport modeling could be conducted.

RISK_STATEMENT: Modeling Levee Breach scenarios
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The system is made up mostly of Flood Control Channels and a section of levee that is located along the south branch of the Hoosic.  The system was constructed in the 1960's and has been tested multiple times and has held up very well.  If the Levee did breach, the areas adjacent to them includes multipurpose regional park and associated buildings and industrial areas.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If breach scenarios are required, the cost covers the breach analysis and associated inundation mapping
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional time to compute the breach analysis

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT will be utilizing multiple H&H models from other sources including USGS and LimnoTech. These models do not cover the entire study area and will require additional modeling efforts. If the existing information in the available models is determined to be unreliable, the PDT will need to find a replacement and/or supplement data source which could require additional time and cost.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is very unlikely that the PDT will encounter issues with this data since it has been vetted by the PDT before the next phase. However, the data could be incorrect, so the risk is accounted for.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If this risk is realized, it would likely not impact performance since the information needed on either end would be included.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: In order to gather the information needed, additional cost would be added.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The schedule could be affected if the lack of data is discovered late in the process.

RISK_NAME: Sewalls/levees hugging shoreline of upper Eastern Branch.
RISK_STATEMENT: This area has a suburban development, primary cultural deposits may be relatively undisturbed, and proximity to water is a strong probability factor for sites, especially Native American sites.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Correlation of archaeological sites, particularly Native American sites, with estuarine shorelines is well established in regional archaeological records.  Evidence is good from known sites for these being high probability areas.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Greater probability of sites, higher survey costs, probable greater mitigation costs. Cost of mitigating sites can be considerable based on comparison with past projects.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impacts likely due to required cultural resource surveys and potential findings.

RISK_NAME: Regulatory Agency/Public approval of certain alternatives.
RISK_STATEMENT: Regulatory agencies may not approve of alternatives that include closing the Hague off to tidal exchange to increase freshwater storage; or implementing any of the storm surge barrier alternatives. These types of measures appear to be the largest potential (and unknown) impacts and/or regulatory uncertainties and may or may not be unacceptable to the public (for a variety of reasons), because nothing like this has been done in our area before, (or at least recently).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It seems that we would have a reasonably good idea prior to completing the study whether or not either the regulatory agencies or the public outcry would prevent these alternatives.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: We could find that these are unacceptable to regulatory agencies and will not be permitted.  If this happened, then we could not implement those alternatives and would have to go back through NEPA and consider and reformulate alternatives.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: We could find that these are unacceptable to regulatory agencies and will not be permitted.  If this happened, then we could not implement those alternatives and would have to go back through NEPA and consider and reformulate alternatives.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: We could find that these are unacceptable to regulatory agencies and will not be permitted.  If this happened, then we could not implement those alternatives and would have to go back through NEPA and consider and reformulate alternatives.

RISK_NAME: Various tasks completed before EIS is complete.
RISK_STATEMENT: Putting together a draft mitigation plan (and a nature-based features plan), and determining costs for both, using interim impacts analysis, without knowing what mitigation sites are available and before EIS is complete. All mitigation requirements may not be captured before EIS is complete.  It is liable to be uncertain what sites are actually obtainable for mitigation before the EIS is complete.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Most of the impacts analysis for the EIS will be complete by the time the TSP is selected; however, regulatory mitigation requirements may change over time, and/or it is difficult to know what sites are actually available until further research.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Because mitigation requirements depend directly on impacts (which may not fully be captured during the preparation of the draft EIS), the mitigation plan may not include all mitigation requirements and/or costs.  Second, the costs of mitigation could later influence a preferred alternative to the point where it would no longer be practicable. Third, it is difficult to determine what sites might be appropriate and available for mitigation without further onsite investigation and real estate research.  And finally, regulatory agencies will not give their final acceptance of a mitigation plan until after the permit process is complete, and mitigation requirements of agencies could also change over time.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Because mitigation requirements depend directly on impacts (which may not fully be captured during the preparation of the draft EIS), the mitigation plan may not include all mitigation requirements and/or costs.  Second, the costs of mitigation could later influence a preferred alternative to the point where it would no longer be practicable. Third, it is difficult to determine what sites might be appropriate and available for mitigation without further onsite investigation and real estate research.  And finally, regulatory agencies will not give their final acceptance of a mitigation plan until after the permit process is complete, and mitigation requirements of agencies could also change over time.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Because mitigation requirements depend directly on impacts (which may not fully be captured during the preparation of the draft EIS), the mitigation plan may not include all mitigation requirements and/or costs.  Second, the costs of mitigation could later influence a preferred alternative to the point where it would no longer be practicable. Third, it is difficult to determine what sites might be appropriate and available for mitigation without further onsite investigation and real estate research.  And finally, regulatory agencies will not give their final acceptance of a mitigation plan until after the permit process is complete, and mitigation requirements of agencies could also change over time.

PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Could be a considerable problem if we are forced to push the project out another year, assuming we cannot come up with suitable mitigation..
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If not completed, many unknowns would be pushed to the design-build contract, increasing that cost significantly.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Not being able to begin the survey prior to the start of the irrigation season has already pushed the schedule out by 6 months.  If we cannot complete the channel bottom survey in October 2024, we will be forced to make more assumptions and leave more unknowns OR pass them off to the contractor in the during build process.

RISK_STATEMENT: Private lands abut the channel on both sides in several locations.  The sponsor has very limited resources to acquire the necessary easements and rights-of-way.  Waivers will likely be required to consider solicitations.  In addition, because this is a cost-share project with the majority of the NFS portion in LERRDs, it could potentially hinder the design-build contract from being awarded if we don't have the NFS portion of the cost-share.  Over $9M in Federal funds could be unavailable for use on the contract.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While design can be completed without the real estate rights being acquired, construction cannot start on properties requiring some sort of right-of-way or easement without waivers from HQUSACE.  The city owns a lot of the property next to the channel, but not all.  We do not have enough hard information to inform the design and let the sponsor know what land acquisitions need to happen.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This could present a major issue in completion of this project and reaching its logical conclusion.  If the city or the Corps is forced to go to eminent domain or condemnation to complete the project, it may not ever be finished.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This has almost unlimited cost risk if the city cannot acquire the necessary rights-of-way and easements. About $9M in Federal funds could be held up until they can meet their cost share.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Again, real estate acquisition could be a huge juggernaut for this project in terms of time and schedule.  The contractor could work around properties that still require real estate to some degree, but that would increase costs and schedule time.

RISK_STATEMENT: Dewatering the channel for construction would lead to fish stranding over many miles of nearly dry channel. Idaho Fish and Game has recommended leaving at least 10% of the flows in the river.  If that cannot be done, a fish salvage may be required.  There is limited access for a fish salvage over the great area that would need to be included would be very costly and time consuming.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Working with water in the channel will be much more difficult than working in the dry.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: There is high potential for stranding many fish if the channel is dewatered at the "Safety Way" diversion.  Also, working in the channel with flowing water would be much more difficult than working in a dry channel.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential fish salvage over 8 miles of river in difficult to access areas.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is estimated that about one week of effort would be required to salvage fish.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT provided cost estimates for the study based on the assumptions of following 3 alternatives in-depth to the Tentatively selected plan and one following the TSP milestone. If these circumstances change, the PDT may need to increase their estimates and add additional time to accommodate additional alternative assessments.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This is unlikely to occur, but it is uncertain at the time of the AMM.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This could impact the efficiency of the PDT to accomplish the alternative comparison.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional funding that may be needed if the PDT pursues more than 3 alternatives up to the TSP or past the TSP is estimated here.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional alternative assessments may impact the timeline for completion.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT is utilizing existing Lidar and digital elevation model (DEM) data from the Massachusetts state website. They provide contour data for 3 meter contours and 1 foot contours, and the data was collected from 2010 to 2015. Since this data is out of date, there is a risk that the terrain has changed. The PDT is planning to collect survey data on areas of need, but until that data is collected, there is a risk that the PDT is using outdated data and may make incorrect assumptions or run a HEC-RAS model that is no longer as accurate.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Since the data is utilized but is only 3 Meter contours, the team will be very unlikely to realize the risk since they are aware that the precision is low.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The PDT may not be as efficient with designs and assumptions until the surveyed data is collected. The HEC-RAS modeling may be out of date unless more precise data is found.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The data may lead the PDT to make incorrect assumptions about the terrain in the HEC-RAS modeling which could impact time for design and could lead the model to produce lower-quality data.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT will perform a Levee Screening Tool 2.0 evaluation on the existing levee and floodwall systems in North Adams. They will supplement the evaluation with information from the LST 1.0 screening performed between 2013-2023. If it is determined that additional screening or evaluation is needed based on life risks, additional effort will be needed to facilitate a more detailed life safety evaluation. This additional effort if realized is reflected in this risk identification. Other effort that may need to be included is whether LST 2.0 will be adequate for this effort or whether a Risk Assessment may be needed and determining the need for a Probable Failure Mode Analysis (PFMA).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on the information from LST 1.0 that shows that the System Levee Safety Action Classification (LSAC) is low, it is unlikely that the LST 2.0 screening will show that the PDT will require additional effort for life safety risks.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This could impact performance of the PDT if the life safety risk is determined to be higher. This would impact the weight of the life safety factor in the decision criteria.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This may take additional time to perform the evaluations

RISK_STATEMENT: Based on a recent Idiker decision, the study may need to complete a takings analysis with counsel for any induced flooding.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Depending on the alternatives, the takings analysis may need to be completed.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional disciplines may need to be involved in completing the analysis.

RISK_NAME: EIS completed under SMART Planning are less detailed.
RISK_STATEMENT: EISs completed under SMART Planning are less detailed than what regulatory agencies are used to seeing from prior (non-SMART planning) Corps studies and those completed by others. The large scope of the study (citywide) necessitates less detail initially, but once design is more complete, the EIS will be updated to reflect increased level of detail.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Most of the study impacts will be on the study schedule. Coordinating agencies are unfamiliar with SMART planning NEPA documents.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Coordinating agencies are unfamiliar with SMART planning NEPA documents. Agencies will have significant comments on the NEPA document and could slow the study process.

RISK_NAME: Water quality modeling will only consider a few parameters.
RISK_STATEMENT: Including more parameters in the water quality modeling would allow for better quantification of environmental impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Other sources of information can be used to determine impacts associated with the recommended project.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Without modeling all water quality parameters it will be difficult to quantify all impacts in the EIS.

RISK_NAME: NACCS storm frequency doesn't account for future increases.
RISK_STATEMENT: NACCS Storm Frequency does not account for increased frequency in the future. Surge barriers may be closed more often than originally planned and impacts assessment may not account for that.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Other sources of information can be used to determine impacts associated with the recommended project.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Environmental impact assessment may not be accurate.

But we do not yet have any alternatives to compare and share with them.  They did not have any comments during the meeting, and they have not submitted any comments for our consideration.

They may decide that they do not concur with our NEPA document/findings. They may decide that they do not concur with our NEPA document/findings. They may decide that they do not concur with our NEPA document/findings. RISK_STATEMENT: Much of the Little Wood channel runs along the backsides of private properties.  These properties will be torn apart to some degree during construction and there are some outbuildings that will have to be removed. Townspeople are supportive now, but things may change once the really think about starting the construction process.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Most townspeople are, we are told, very excited to have USACE in the town working to get this project done.  However, it is likely that there will be property owners who are not anxious to have their properties deconstructed during the construction phase.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: At present, the Little Wood channel walls are sloughing into the channel, along with debris. Chain-link fences along the channel are misshapen and broken.  Just be cleaning the channel of vegetation and debris, there will be major improvements. Providing stable channel walls alone will be a 100% improvement.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The total LERRDs figured for this project is $1.8M. That figure is an estimate, and could be more or less.  However, if land owners are unwilling, the price of LERRDs could skyrocket.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assuming all necessary acquisitions and easements are completed, there will be no delay.  If any property owners are unhappy enough to refuse to sell rights to the city, the schedule could be impacted significantly.

RISK_STATEMENT: Because velocities that come through the Little Wood channel are quite swift, even 1 foot of water within the channel makes it too dangerous for a survey crew to work within the channel.  During construction, the channel will need to remain as dry as possible to replace the walls.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: If water cannot be diverted to either the safety way or another of the small irrigation diversions upstream of the city, some type of pipe will have to be placed either in or alongside the channel to keep water for fish, stock watering, etc. moving for use downstream.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If Idaho Fish and Game determines that it is necessary to keep 10% of the river flows in the channel at all times for fish, it will impact the schedule.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If a pipe is in the only solution to diverting the channel, it will drive the contract price higher.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the pipe can be placed outside of the channel, delays might be avoided.  However, if that is not a possibility, there will be an initial delay of about 1 week, and the pipe will need to be moved from one side to the other during construction.

RISK_STATEMENT: To date, no decisions have been made regarding the aesthetics of the project (e.g., wall texture, fencing, wall height, etc.).
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Currently, the channel is unsightly.  It is full of vegetation and debris, fencing is broken and falling down in many places, the basalt walls are sloughing into the channel.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Unknown at this time - would depend on materials used.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If stakeholders object to what USACE proposes, delays could occur.

RISK_STATEMENT: Archeaological/Cultural Resources found within site and potential project footprint.  This has potential to constrain alternatives and cause schedule delays.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on previous evaluation, it is like that cultural/historic resources are present on the site.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Long project timeline would reflect poorly on the Agencies strategy.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The costs impacts would be vairoble and depend on what resources are discovered. Most likely new concept plans would likely be developed, however it is possible additional surveys would be necessar.y
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Depending on the timing of the determination of historic resources, additional surveys may be necessary or at a minimum, additional plan formulation to modify concepts to avoid impacts
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: The project may involve placing sediment ranging from fine silty sand, cobbles, to larger boulder sized rock. Sediment transportation is expected. The PDT assumes that the sediment that is redeposited along portions of the California coastline outside our project limits will not have a significant impact due to the fact that the California coast is sediment starved already. The risk if the assumption is wrong is there may be a need for impact mitigation which could impact schedule or cost of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The PDT includes experts in coastal storm risk management with experience working on the California coastline. Numerical models will aide in determining potential impacts due to material placement.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impact is based on man-hours required to complete additional environmental coordination and management.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Schedule impact is based on additional time required to complete and EIS instead of an EA

RISK_NAME: Uncertainty on impact to biological diversity
RISK_STATEMENT: There are uncertainties on whether project alternatives formulated for shoreline protection would potentially have significant impacts on biological resources, which would require an Environmental Impact Statement (EIS) for NEPA compliance. The project alternatives currently considered are variations of the following: Beach Nourishment, Dune Creation with Buried Revetment, or a Cobble Berm. As part of the GI study, the Planning Aid Letter from USFWS indicated that any alternative involving beach fill may have detrimental impacts on marine vegetations, thus impacting shorebird species. Also, the borrow areas and staging/alternate staging areas, which are not identified fully at this time, could trigger a significant impact to environmental resources, and thereby, require an EIS. Preparing an EIS instead of an EA will require additional time and cost to conduct field survey(s) if requested by the Services, and analyze the extent of direct/indirect biological impacts.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The TSP schedule was pushed out to accommodate some additional analysis, but may need additional time and cost as NMFS and/or USFWS may request new field surveys. The existing habitat survey was conducted in 2013, which is 10 years old now and it is likely that the Services request a new habitat survey unless we can demonstrate 2013 data are representative of current conditions.

RISK_STATEMENT: The project alternatives currently considered are variations of the following: Beach Nourishment, Dune Creation with Buried Revetment, or a Cobble Berm. There are uncertainties on whether project alternatives formulated for shoreline protection would potentially have significant impacts on air quality, which may arise from transportation emissions for transporting sediments, cobbles and stones to the project area, which may require additional time and cost to develop extensive avoidance and mitigation measures and monitoring plans.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on comparable projects, air quality did not trigger an EIS.

RISK_NAME: Climate Change: Unknown Future Storm Frequency and Intensity
RISK_STATEMENT: Changes in storm intensity and frequency impacting the project site in the future are unknown.  Storms may be under- or over-predicted. Also, modeling limitation require a single set of storm events that cannot change in magnitude or frequency throughout a single lifecycle.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Climate change is occurring but there has not been sufficient studies to quantify the storm effects on the project site in the future.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Premature failure of the project in response to higher than estimated storm magnitude or frequency would risk harming USACE reputation.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional study is required to quantify potential storm effects in the future due to climate change. The additional study would focus on the Southern California region.

RISK_NAME: Potential environmental mitigation costs are unknown at TSP.
RISK_STATEMENT: Potential mitigation costs for Endangered Species Act, Marine Mammal Protection Act, and/or Essential Fish Habitat mitigation, if any, are unknown at the TSP.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The Endangered Species Act Section 7 process; the Magnuson-Stevens Act (Essential Fish Habitat); and the Marine Mammal Protection Act coordination is ongoing and is not likely to be complete until the final report date.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If we do not have their findings until the final report, we will not know what mitigation is required, nor the costs of it. Monetary costs likely would not be substantial, but there could be time of year restrictions for instream work, which could impact construction schedules.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If we do not have their findings until the final report, we will not know what mitigation is required, nor the costs of it. Monetary costs likely would not be substantial, but there could be time of year restrictions for instream work, which could impact construction schedules.

RISK_STATEMENT: All alternatives include privately owned property. Permanent real estate owned by the city is required for project implementation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Almost all USACE civil works projects require some LERRD.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Failure to acquire privately owned land would impact the selected plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Time and additional cost for the city to acquire land and/or get easements necessary for the project. Almost all USACE civil works projects require some LERRD.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Time and additional cost for the city to acquire land and/or get easements necessary for the project. Almost all USACE civil works projects require some LERRD.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: Tribal concerns regarding potential water sources
RISK_STATEMENT: The tribe is not a stakeholder, sponsor or partner, this is the best category to identify this risk.  Based on the information from previous USACE projects and knowledge from USACE team members, it is understood that a cultural practice of the Community is considered to be in conflict with the use of effluent water, particularly if that water can come on to their property (held in trust by Bureau of Indian Affairs). They may be unaware of /or unsupportive of the alternatives if adequate consultation does not occur during the alternative formulation and evaluation steps.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: There may be cost impact if additional consultation activities and face to face meetings that were not scoped are requested by Tribal Nations. The cost impact at this time is unknown as no such tasks have been requested.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If additional meeting(s) are requested, the time required to find a suitable time with the Tribe would likely take between 3 weeks to 6 weeks, depending on time of year.

PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If relevant water rights issues are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. If a project were to proceed and not have enough water supply to support the recommended restoration measures, the project may fail.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If relevant water rights issues are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. The cost impact at this time is unknown.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If relevant water rights issues are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. Resolution of legal issues, if realized, may take weeks.

RISK_STATEMENT: Climate Change could negatively impact the project's effectiveness
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

RISK_NAME: Climate Change: Sea Level Change Inclusion in Beach-fx
RISK_STATEMENT: The Beach-fx model, a combined engineering-economics model used to assist in the NED plan determination, only applies an increase in still water level to simulate sea level change. This assumption limits the potential hazards experienced at the project site by not incorporating larger wave heights due to the increase in water level. Also, the natural shoreline parameter (dune elevation/width/slope, berm elevation, foreshore slope) will not response to changes in water levels in the modeling.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This is a known limitation to the Beach-fx model and, in the current form, cannot be altered to address a more realistic description of sea level change and impacts.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The combination of sea level change coupled with the natural effects of shoreline evolution in response to rising water levels may not be properly accounted for. Project failure or reduction in potential protection may observed.

RISK_NAME: Lack of Sufficient Borrow Source and Material Quantitiy
RISK_STATEMENT: Unknown borrow sources for sand and cobble sized material. Beach nourishment activities requires a source of compatible sand (similar grain size and distribution). Inland sources may be too costly to mine and transport. Environmental and institutional barriers can restrict the use of nearshore or other littoral sand sources. Although some nearby borrow sources have been selected, no additional sampling or borings will be collected during the feasibility stage of the study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Reviews of other studies in the area indicated potential borrow sources, but sampling has not been performed since the 1980's.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Insufficient material quantity will require investigation for an additional borrow source. Environmental documents will need to be updated to reflect updated site. Insufficient material parameters may require investigation of an additional borrow source.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Requirement for geologic investigation program to sample and test multiple borrow locations to determine the approximate quantity and material parameters (size, distribution, color, etc).

RISK_STATEMENT: The chosen numerical model to simulate wave processes and sediment transport has not been extensively validated for runup and overtopping. Additionally, only a single transect will be modeled so to keep to the project timeframe and horizontal affects will be extrapolated from the one-dimensional model. Failure to properly incorporate wave runup and overtopping may limit the amount of modeled damages which may lead to the wrong recommended plan.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Propagation of a wave bore over the beach and between buildings is a very complicated hydrodynamic problem to solve, and very sensitive to specific geometries and ground permeability.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Modeling results may lead to the selection of the wrong recommended plan and potential failure once constructed.

RISK_NAME: Inclusion of Sponsor's Winter Berm Construction Program
RISK_STATEMENT: Including the sponsor's winter berm program into the Beach-fx model is not straight-forward. Limitations of the model requires either a binary presence of absence of the berm. Failure to properly account for the sponsor's efforts may under- or over-predict the project benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The Beach-fx model will not account for the sponsor's winter berm program. A revised method must be applied to account for the winter berm.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Failure to account for the sponsor's winter berm program may lead to and over- or under-estimation of the project performance.

RISK_NAME: Shoreline Recovery after Coastal Storm Events
RISK_STATEMENT: Natural berm rebuilding after a storm event is poorly understood. Inaccurate recovery timing may lead to an incorrect recommended plan. The Beach-fx model utilizes a duration threshold to define the amount of time the beach berm requires to return to the pre-storm condition. This linear threshold may under- or over-estimate the actual beach rebuilding process. Failure to account for a deflated, post-storm berm condition for a sufficient time may lead to under- or over-counting of damages.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Previous use of the Beach-fx model and experience of coastal processes in the area.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Incorrect rebuilding assumption may lead to incorrect plan selection.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: Sand and gravel mining operations along river
RISK_STATEMENT: Sand and gravel mining operations will continue, until resources and demands dictate that they are no longer viable. The location of both active and inactive sand and gravel mining operations will impact the formulation of restoration alternatives. Active mining operations areas are to be avoided for restoration, while mining operations no longer in use may be opportunities for restoration.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Long-term success of the restoration project relies on having an accurate understanding of current and future mining operations within the study area. If feasibility analysis of existing conditions and assumptions for future conditions regarding mining locations/demand are inaccurate, the restoration areas may be at risk.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: Climate change stresses to the system
RISK_STATEMENT: Drought is exacerbating the limitations on the water budget.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If climate concerns and the existing and future water budget are not appropriately considered during the restoration plan formulation and evaluation process, the incorrect plan may be identified for the TSP and/or Recommended Plan. If a project were to proceed and not have enough water supply to support the recommended restoration measures, the project may fail.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: Water Budget and/or availability is a known unknown
RISK_STATEMENT: The water budget and water availability are a foundational element of the analysis, as it determines which restoration features may be viable. The volume of available water has direct implications for plan formulation and evaluation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the water budget and availability are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. If a project were to proceed and not have enough water supply to support the recommended restoration measures, the project may fail.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the water budget and availability are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. The cost impact at this time is unknown.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the water budget and availability are not considered appropriately during the feasibility study, it may lead to an incorrect TSP or Recommended Plan and re-formulation. If it is discovered that the water budget and/or availability assumptions are inaccurate, additional evaluation/comparison of the plans may take weeks.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_NAME: Defining aquatic ecosystem restoration in an arid enviro
RISK_STATEMENT: The 2006 feasibility study was determined to be policy non-compliant by ASA(CW) and OMB, as documented in a 12 Jan 2009 letter from OMB to the ASA(CW), because the Recommended Plan features were upland, not aquatic ecosystem features. If the GRR feasibility study does not appropriately define/justify that the Recommended Plan is aquatic ecosystem restoration, the study could end up in the same place with a policy non-compliant, unbudgetable recommendation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the Recommended Plan is not supported by Administration, the project is at risk of not being budgeted for PED and Construction in the future.

PROJECT_NAME: RIO SALADO OESTE ECOSYSTEM RESTORATION PROJECT
RISK_STATEMENT: The hydrologic analysis will use existing peak discharges computed in the 1996 hydrologic evaluation of Water Control Plans for the Salt River Project to Gila River at Gillespie Dam. If this dataset does not accurately represent existing and future conditions, the analysis may over or underestimate water supply to a degree that impacts project performance.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
The likelihood that the dataset does not accurately represent existing and future conditions to a degree that would impact project performance is unlikely because:
1) The water being supplied for the restoration is from treated wastewater effluent, so watershed hydrology is not a limiting factor for restoration success.
2) The region has been in a multi-decadal drought and is trending drier according to climate change research. Therefore, in assessing induced flood risk from the restoration features, the existing hydrology data is likely more conservative than using recent data.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the analysis using existing hydrology data over or underestimates water supply, the risk of induced flooding may be assessed incorrectly.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Creating a current hydrology dataset would be very expensive for a study that is already scoped to exceed 3x3.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Creating a current hydrology dataset would take on the order of months for a study that is already scoped to exceed 3x3.

RISK_NAME: Consultation with Agency for Endangered Species
RISK_STATEMENT: Since the FONSI was signed in 2020, a new sea turtle in the project area has been added to the list of Threatened and Endangered Species. This means the Environmental lead will need to consult with the Agency to verify the project will not impact this species. The Environmental lead assumes this will be an informal consultation (90days) instead of formal (120+days). Risk is schedule based.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If the consultation takes longer than 150 days, the PED phase could be delayed in completion.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If the consultation period is longer than expected, the budget developed by Environmental lead would be low.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assume 90 days consultation included in current schedule. If a formal consultation is required, by law the Agency must respond within 120 days, but due to work load this has not been accurate timing and should be expected to take longer.
