RISK_NAME: Environmental assumes Design will not change drastically
RISK_STATEMENT: The EA provided a FONSI for the design footprint as outlined in the Project Deficiency Report from 2020. The Environmental Lead assumes that the design will stay within that footprint, which would mean that the EA and FONSI are good to proceed with construction with a minor consultation required due to a new threatened/endangered species. If the design changes significantly and deviates from the original footprint, a supplemental EA would be required.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The project will still move forward, but schedule may change depending on when the change to the design footprint was identified and relayed to the Environmental team.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: For their budget for PED, the Environmental lead assumed only a minor consultation will be required. If the design footprint is significantly altered, a supplemental EA would be required, which would require more work from the Environmental lead and more funding.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A risk to schedule is possible, but if the change in design footprint is noted during 30%, the Environmental team would have time to complete an EA before construction. If the Environmental team is not notified until 60 or 90% design that the design footprint has changed, the Environmental team would need additional time and completion of PED would be delayed.

RISK_NAME: Duration and Cost is SWG completes ROE tasks
RISK_STATEMENT: ROE is complicated for this project due to 400+ parties involved in an undivided interest ownership of land needed for ROE/Construction. If SWG completes the ROE, RE estimates it will take a minimum of 1 year and $1.8M to complete, but these numbers are on the lower end of expected time/money required to complete ROE. RE proposes NFS complete this task. Decision pending.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: ROE is required before E&C can obtain survey and geotechnical data required to complete significant portions of design.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current estimate includes the estimated $1.8M for SWG RE to complete ROE task. Cost could go up or down depending on how this plays out.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current schedule assumes 365 days to complete complete ROE task. Schedule could push left or right depending on how this plays out.

RISK_STATEMENT: Assuming SWG RE is tasked with completing ROE (instead of NFS), it is unclear how many landowners would need to provide approval to consider ROE authorization obtained. There are 400+ owners, so assume a percentage would be required. RE is working with OC to determine requirement.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: ROE is required before E&C can complete survey and geotechnical tasks needed to complete a significant portion of the design work.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current estimate is $1.8M and is considered on the low end. A high percentage would likely increase cost due to the effort required to obtain approval of a larger number of owners, while a lower percentage would likely decrease costs.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Current schedule includes 365 days to complete ROE and is considered the minimal time required. A high percentage would likely increase duration needed to complete ROE task due to the effort required to obtain approval of a larger number of owners, while a lower percentage would likely decrease duration.

RISK_NAME: Additional Site Visit May Be Required
RISK_STATEMENT: One site visit at the beginning of the design process is currently scheduled. ROE may be a concern and may not allow the team to access all areas of the site. If the team cannot access the full site during the initial site visit due to ROE concerns, a second site visit may be required .
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: RE has noted that it is likely the team can visit the full site as long as no actual work is completed (survey, geotech, sampling, etc), in which case a second site visit would not be required. RE will work with OC to verify and determine when/if the team can visit prior to ROE or if ROE will be required.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: A second site visit would cost additional funds for the boats and personnel.

RISK_STATEMENT: Current schedule shows work occurring over extended holiday breaks in Nov/Dec/Jan timeframe, which may or may not impact the overall schedule based on completion of prior activities and personnel schedules. While specific government holidays are built into the schedule, the 2-4 week holiday leave period at the end of the year that SWG tends to see was not included because personnel leave schedules and prior task completion cannot be foreseen.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is common for personnel at SWG to take extended leave at the end of the year.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Potential 2-4 week delay at the end of every calendar year, but is dependent on personnel schedules and previous task completion.

RISK_STATEMENT: Cultural resource investigations indicate areas of concern within the CWL.  This is predominantly a lay down area where mitigation or avoidance is possible.  The cultural resources identified appear to be more than 4 feet below grade and would only be encountered in excavated areas.  coordination with SHPO, Tribal authority, and USACE will documented in the programmatic agreement.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Evidence of cultural resources were found in Phase 1 and Phase 2 investigations.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Our diligence in preserving the site could be recognized by other agencies and the public as being good stewards of historical artifacts.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimate based on expected cultural resource Phase 3 costs and potential for discovery.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Estimated guess on schedule delays to re-sequence construction activities while cultural artifacts are exhumed.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

PROJECT_NAME: Brunswick County Beaches, Oak Island Portion, General Reevaluation
RISK_NAME: Discovery of previsously unknown offshore cultural resources
RISK_STATEMENT: If previously unknown offshore cultural resources sites or features (e.g. shipwreck) within borrow area or pipeline route are found, it may require additional consultation with the State Historic Preservation Office, federally recognized Native American tribes, and the public, revisions to borrow areas, and potential avoidance measures.  Areas offshore of Oak Island are largely unsurveyed; however, submerged resources have been located in nearby waters (e.g. Carolina Beach) with similar bathymetry and maritime history.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Existing data indicates a possibility.

PROJECT_NAME: Brunswick County Beaches, Oak Island Portion, General Reevaluation
RISK_NAME: Sand limitations & long distance hauling may impact BCR
RISK_STATEMENT: Sand limitations nearby may require long distance hauling of sand to support a TSP.  Long distance hauling may increase costs beyond justification, or study may not identify sufficient sand sources.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Available data demonstrates scarcity of sand in the area.  Current available data indicates that most suitable sand borrow sources may be farther offshore than 10 miles.  However, there are still significant data gaps which the PDT will search.  One large known source of sand (Frying Pan Shoals) likely has environmental barriers to access.

PROJECT_NAME: Brunswick County Beaches, Oak Island Portion, General Reevaluation
RISK_NAME: Cost increase for marine archeological survey
RISK_STATEMENT: The marine archaeological survey has a cost estimate of $250k and is based on past similar work.; however, cost may increase based upon the results of offshore geotechnical investigations and borrow area suitability/boundaries.  This could increase overall study budget if not covered within contingency costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: It is unknown at this time if a project sand borrow source would b e comprised of one or multiple locations, or what the size(s) of those locations will ultimately be.

PROJECT_NAME: Brunswick County Beaches, Oak Island Portion, General Reevaluation
RISK_NAME: Resource Agenecy Barriers to using Frying Pan Shoals
RISK_STATEMENT: In a sand-scarce environment, one known quantity of quality sand is Frying Pan Shoals.  This locations is considered a high-value marine habitat and resource agencies have signaled resistance to the use of this resource for CSRM projects.  If there are not sufficient compatible sand sources elsewhere within reasonable hauling distance of the project, there will be more pressure to consider using Frying Pan Shoals.  This could result in additional negotiation, analysis and mitigation for the study/project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Although the overall region is sand-limited, there are other possible sources outside of Frying Pan Shoals.

PROJECT_NAME: Brunswick County Beaches, Oak Island Portion, General Reevaluation
RISK_NAME: Competing sand interests/conflicts between neighboring towns
RISK_STATEMENT: Neighboring communities (Oak Island, Holden Beach, Bald Head Island) have historically not cooperated and are competing for the same sand sources, which are limited.  Both Oak Island and Holden Beach have concurrent USACE CSRM studies underway.  The communities have been guarded with sharing information, even with USACE.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The general area has limited sand resources and the communities have already demonstrated  a guarded approach to data sharing and strategic manuevering.

RISK_STATEMENT: Battered Piles are in the CPKC Right of Way. This has created a condition where the battered piles encroach on the deadman supporting the piers for the Valero Rail Terminal. USACE Real Estate has sent standard easement language to CPKC. LCR is exploring shifting the alignment at the location where the battered piles are in conflict with the deadmen.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Deadman supporting the piers for the Valero rail terminal provide primiary support for the existing structure. The design and placement of the battered piles will need to accomodate this physical constraint.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The placement of the battered piles for the flood wall in this segment of the levee system needs to be located and constructed in a manner that doesn't compromise the foundation supporting the Valero Rail Terminal. The adjusted location is required to provide adequate flood protection for the terminal without compromising the existing foundation system.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently a minimum cost impact is recognized as the design is being evaluated to possibly shift alignment to miss locations.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The schedule impact is minimal as shifting the alignment to miss the deadmen is being evaluated within the timeframe of the updated 95% design submittal.

RISK_NAME: PAV03 - Battered Piles Encroaching onto Railroad Property
RISK_STATEMENT: Similar to the conflict between the battered pile and deadmen, there are potential concflicts between the pile(s) and tie-back structures.DD7 is moving with the proposed investigation of the conflicts between the piles and tie back structures (pending evaluation of proposal). In the interrim, LRC is revising the alignment based on the data we have now, requiring a minimum clearance between proposed and existing piles. The current design scenario being evaluated is moving the last few hundred feet of the alignment ~3-5 feet towards the side. This scenario will required redesign of approximately 6 monoliths.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A partial shift of the alignment would be required to avoid the design of a different foundation system in the area of the conflict.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Shifting the alignment preserves the majority of the design and performance of the levee system.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The cost impact for additional time required to revise the design to reflected the partial shift of the alignment will be realized as services will need to be provided by LCR & their consultants.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently there is no scheduled impact for this risk as the coordination of this design is within the timeframe of the updated 95% design submittal which is scheduled to be received 28 JAN 25.

RISK_STATEMENT:
The study assumes that sediment released through barrier removal at Dam 6 would be acceptable in quantity and quality, such that it would not degrade river bottom habitats and water quality beyond its current location upstream of dams.  Barrier removal is not expected to increase toxicity due to metals, mercury, PCBs, dioxins, furans, and pesticides.  There can also be short term increases in turbidity and downstream sedimentation. 
Though risk here seems limited, any dam removal should consider the release of sediment that has built up behind the dam. While the dam in size is small, given the working history and development within the region, any dam removal work should acknowledge the potential for the mobilization of contaminated sediments previously buried upstream of dams.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Available data suggests height of the dam and disposition of sediments would not cause additional impact to the aquatic community.

RISK_STATEMENT: The PDT has made the assumption that barrier removal would not significantly alter flood risk along the course of the river.  Removal is expected to result in reduced flood risk and water surface elevations at adjacent properties and along the impoundments up to moderate events, however these effects will likely be reduced during largest events when these structures are likely subject to backwater influence.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Currently, Dam 6 is a low head run of river type of dams that once removed should not significantly alter the flow dynamics of the river. Flood risk exists in the current state of the river and would be expected to decrease with the removal of the dam 6.

RISK_NAME: Presence of Endangered and Threatened Species
RISK_STATEMENT:
Precautions should be taken to ensure aquatic ecosystem restoration does not come at the expense of other species any endangered or threatened species in the study area. 

Species include: 
? Indiana bat, Myotis sodalis, endangered
? Northern long-eared bat, Myotis septentrionalis, endangered
? Tricolored Bat, Perimyotis subflavus, proposed endangered
? Bog turtle, Glyptemys muhlenbergii, threatened
? Dwarf Wedgemussel, Alasmidonta heterodon, endangered

A database search of the National Marine Fisheries Service (NMFS) Endangered Species Act (ESA) Mapper was conducted on February 7, 2023. No threatened and endangered species under NMFS jurisdiction are expected to occur in the project area. A database search was also conducted for essential fish habitat using the NMFS Essential Fish Habitat (EFH) Mapper on February 7, 2023. No EFH is designated in the study area. Potential impacts on threatened and endangered species and EFH should be considered, as necessary, during the feasibility study.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Species screening tools from resource agencies were used to inform the potential presence of endangered species.

RISK_STATEMENT: Decision requiring approval from CPKC can add as much as 60 days to the project schedule to go through the internal process for formal decisions by the railroad. This would impact physical features, features of work, structures and other property within the CPKC ROW. In addition to the following design documents, submittals, technical data and other plans for implementation where CPKC is the end user and the AHJ having jurisdiction for compliance would also be subject to the 60 day approval window.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Since CPKC holds the sole authority to confirm compliance to their railroad standards, the event likely hood is extremely high (100%) for features, properties and design impacting areas within the railroad ROW. With the departure of the incumbent CPKC representative responsible for facilitating railroad compliance based decisions (Bently Tomlin), the likelihood of decisions with a 60 day time range is increasingly high.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: CPKC decisions are needed for the final alignment of the levee PAV03B & the finalized design of the closure gates that server the railroad lines.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Currently the there is no cost impact associated with this risk, however that would change if delayed decisions have direct impact on the execution of the contract.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The time impact for decisions requiring direct approval from the railroad averages between 45 to 60 days, leaning toward the upper value of the time range at 60 days.

RISK_STATEMENT:
The PAV03 contract is located on a Valero petrochemical refinery identified as a commercial/industrial land use site. Communication with HQUSACE Office of Counsel provided guidance that no soils containing hazardous substance will remain on project lands and that the non-federal sponsor is responsible for providing a clean site free of HTRW for construction.

Initial soil boring samples were taken along the levee alignment. Based on the analytical results of the waste characteristic assessment,  TCLP analytical data suggests no indication of any soils exceeding EPA regulatory levels for hazardous waste. However, concentrations of total TPH exceeded the respective Texas Class II non-hazardous regulatory level within the Docks Area of the Valero facility. The non federal sponsor will be responsible for the safe handling and disposal of Class I and Class II soil along the PAV03 alignment.

Annual soil boring samples will be taken to reconfirm the soil profile for excavation of the upcoming year of construction. Residual risk still exists that the non-federal sponsor will encounter hazardous waste. Hazardous waste could result in project delays due to USEPA requirements and land acquisitions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Results from the initial analytic samples did not indicate that the site contained soils that exceeded USEPA regulatory levels for hazardous waste along the alignment.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost is associated with NFS responsibility to acquire real estate along the alignment that contains contaminated soil.

RISK_NAME: PAV04 Amendment - Loading Pressure Discrepancies in RFP
RISK_STATEMENT:
Amendment 0018 includes a spreadsheet with loading pressures that shows the toe elevation (top of slab) as El. +4.34?.  The loading pressures are different from the toe elevation (top of slab) for the 35% design drawings (El. +2.00?). The pressures will directly impact the service load of the pilings.
The PDT reviewed the data and found that the loading pressures provided in the RFP are not correct.  The impact of this is that the elevations provided are also not correct.  This change impacts approximately two miles of wall.  The elevations will increase 2 ? 3 feetby more than one foot due to this change.  There is a substantial cost and time impact to this issue.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Updating & providing the correct loading pressure directly impacts the design of the levee & flood wall system, as the toe elevation and the height of the flood wall will likley need to increase to successfully provide protection. The area that this segement of the levee system services experiences some of the highest waves during storm events. History has shown that this part of Port Arthur has experienced overtopping of the levee during Hurricane Ike.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: While the current cost implication of this issue is not known, it is likely a multi-million dollar change.  The PDT can prepare a cost estimate regarding this change but that cost estimate will take about a week to two weeks to prepare.  The PDT requests that leadership decide how to proceed prior to the cost implication being fully known.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This issue is substantial in nature and as such it is appropriate to give the offerors an additional 30-days to revise their proposals after receiving the Amendment with this revised information.  Additionally, it will take the PDT one to two weeks to prepare and issue this amendment.

RISK_STATEMENT: DMMP approval with a 20 year plan occurs later than needed to implement a placement strategy beyond the 5 years identified in the preliminary assessment base plan at CDF12. CDF12 will run out of traditional capacity after the 2029 dredge cycle. A DMMP approved base plan and federal standard must be approved to allow for enough time for design and if applicable, an updated cost-share agreement with the NFS.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Current schedule is still being scoped and drafted. Initial estimates populating a DMMP schedule template starting 1 July 2024 indicate an approval date of the final document on 4 Feb 2028. This is inclusive of full durations for all listed template activities but may not account for some specific project activities yet. Additionally, this does not include an EIS level of effort which is expected for the CHEERS alternative analysis if not screened from the final array. Design for a recommended alternative may be completed via a 217 agreement for the CHEERS alternative which is currently drafting and being refined by the Port of Cleveland. Design for other alternatives may be relatively light workload if nearshore beneficial use alternatives are selected. Design may be a heavy workload if an upland facility is selected and requires design that would not be accomplished by the NFS. 217 agreements require significant review and approval at the ASA(CW) office which could take up to a year if not well communicated. The current 217 agreement with the Port of Cleveland for CDF12 should help alleviate any possible friction points early and allow for a faster 217 agreement negotiation if required for  the 20 year DMMP recommendation.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Significant stakeholder and congressional attention has been placed on the Cleveland DMMP and disposal strategy in light of the Ohio law requiring upland placement. A congressional letter from Senator Brown was received by USACE requesting priority attention to deliver this DMMP as quickly as possible to avoid disruptions in port business due to dredging delays or stops.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Delays or canceling a cycle to the operational dredging in Cleveland harbor would likely require communication with the stakeholders of the Port including possible public/marine notices associated with shoaling, answering requests for information, and possible congressional delegation interactions. These are all labor based cost impacts.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: EIS activities and review duration requirements, complexity of the design requirements, and the need for a 217 Agreement approval at ASA(CW) all contribute to the possible extension of the DMMP 20year plan completion and approval. These items may have no impact to the operational dredging contract for 2030 but could delay up to one year if each trigger occurs.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT:
Three mandatory triggers apply for determining an IEPR requirement including:
1. Chief of Engineers determines one is needed based on significant public controversy.
2. The governor of the affected state (OH) has requested an IEPR.
3. The cost of the project is more than $200M.

If CHEERS is selected as the proposed alternative or an upland CDF, the cost of the project may meet the $200M threshold. If CHEERS is selected as a locally preferred alternative and is over the cost threshold it would trigger an IEPR. 

IEPR would require additional costs to the budget and drive some review time to the overall schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The total cost of the CHEERS facility as communicated by the port is very likely over $200M total project construction cost which would trigger an IEPR. However, it is uncertain if CHEERS will be the recommended plan or a locally preferred plan.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: $100k is the estimated standard scope for an IEPR review.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: IEPR review may be conducted in parallel or waterfall to other reviews and has potential to add time to the schedule. If parallel, it is assumed that some review time would not perfectly align to fully eliminate impacts to the schedule. If separated completely from other reviews in a waterfall schedule, 90 days is estimated for the review duration as a stand alone.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_STATEMENT: A tentatively selected plan is identified with a benefit to cost ratio that is below 1.0 but justified still as the least cost alternative that is technically feasible and environmentally acceptable with OSE, EQ, and RED benefits. This would require a non-NED waiver from ASA(CW) in order to be approved and may elevate the approval authority beyond the MSC.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a chance that beneficial use, low cost alternatives that would change the base plan and federal standard for some material placement in an open lake or littoral zone setting are not permitted under a water quality certificate. OEPA is the permitting agency and have been hesitant to support any of these plans in the absence of key data. Strategic placement in the open lake was not supported in previous scoping and in the preliminary assessment. Beneficial use projects for coastal storm risk management were supported including CHEERS. No opinion was provided on the littoral placement option but it does align with CSRM goals.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional coordination, briefings, and submittal packages required to route the package through HQUSACE for ASA(CW). Will require additional communication and may require additional analyses to detail specific non-NED benefits.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional review times and coordination will increase overall project schedule. The review will need to go through the MSC, HQUSACE, and then to ASA(CW). The chief, planning and policy may decide to pull the decision authority for DMMPs up to HQUSACE if a non-NED TSP is put forward.
MSC_DESCRIPT: Great Lakes and Ohio River Division

RISK_NAME: Coastal Hazards Data Inaccurate affecting Design Elevations
RISK_STATEMENT:
In early July of 2024, Hurricane Branch personnel determined that there were inaccuracies in the data provided to the team. The inaccuracies were due to the inappropriate use of Coastal Hazards data from a model run in 2022 and potential flaws in the StormSim program used to process the coastal model run in 2023.
Most of the 1% AEP still water levels (SWL) for the system appear to be very similar, at this point in the review. The largest differences are about 1ft higher from the 2023 model, occurring on the furthest inland extents of the system alignment.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Based on preliminary review the existing elevations may be adequate to meet USACE requirements with the corrected H&H loading.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: With the multiple inaccuracies found with the H&H data our NFS and the public if known will loose faith in our engineering capabilities due to so many errors. However there is opportunity to tell the story that we take quality serious and will stop a project and focus on the right thing to do.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Reviewing the data and establishing the correct elevations and understanding any change in conditions will affect the project 20K to 30K if the elevations must change the impact will be significant 5-10M range.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Year delay is estimated to update the designs, however for actual design and construction that will be determined on a case by case basis.

RISK_NAME: PAV04 - Engineering Findings Leading to Design Changes
RISK_STATEMENT: If Engineering Findings from the H&H Modeling are determined to required a design changes and/or major changes to the footprint of the levee,  the MATOC award date will be negatively impacted (Delayed). Any findings that show a need for design changes would negatively impact the environmental analysis / NEPA compliance work that has already started. The environmental team would need to essentially start their work over, and those tasks are closely related to completing the environmental compliance requirements needed for that contract. An answer of regarding the likelihood of or avoidance of redesign is needed by 25 SEP 24.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a possibility that some portions of the alignment will need to be redesigned.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The results from the modeling will determine what segments need to be addressed to raise the system to properly account for anticipated wave action, still water elevations, overtopping heights and the correct ACE.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The likely schedule impact is about 1 Month

RISK_STATEMENT: The current project management plan (PMP) does not assume conducting surveys specific to identifying the presence/absence of Federal or State endangered and threatened species within the study area. The risk is that as alternative alignments and features are advanced, the regulating agency (USFWS for Fed E&T; NJDEP for State E&T), may require presence/absence surveys in order to adequately assess adverse effects and to determine the level of consultation needed and/or mitigation requirements.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Listed Federal E&T species that could occur within the study area include several bat species. The requirement to perform presence/absence surveys is highly dependent on the amount of tree clearing resulting from the proposed action and the proximity of it to known hibernacula. In addition, the typical mitigation measured utilized to protect listed bat species is a tree clearing restriction. As alternatives are currently being formulated, there is not enough information to determine if surveys will be required.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost is based on presence/absence surveys of species for similar projects.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Surveys can easily be incorporated into the PED schedule without impacting timeframes. In addition, presence/absence surveys are valid for five years.

The alternatives being formulated are similar to, if not exactly the same as alternatives that were Scoped to the public in 2016. In addition, the District received feedback on alternatives during a charrette and subsequent stakeholder/agency meetings.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: NEPA Scoping meetings have been incorporated into the PMP.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The formal NEPA Scoping process can be incorporated into the study schedule without impacting overall schedule completion.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Performance of Navigation Improvements in Emergency
RISK_STATEMENT:
The potential navigation improvements (e.g., widening Fort Armstrong Entrance Channel) aim to reduce the occurrence and duration of Port Shutdowns caused by vessel casualties and coastal storms. The risk and impacts of these events involves high uncertainty. Similarly, the successful performance of navigation improvements during an emergency situation is not certain. As a result, there is significant performance and reputational risk associated with navigation improvements.

Emergency management agencies will likely update emergency plans incorporating assumptions about the improvements associated with this project. This risks diverting resources for potentially more effective risk management and resiliency measures (e.g., improving emergency infrastructure at other Hawaii Ports).

The navigation improvements will likely have significant cost that are not economically justified by NED metrics alone. Project justification will likely rely on the ability of the project to keep the Port open during an emergency, which is not a certainty. If the alternative, which is designed to prevent Port shutdown, does not perform successfully, the USACE and HDOT face reputational risk.

Additionally, USACE and HDOT do not directly manage the risk associated with navigation in the channels beyond channel design and maintenance. Navigating the channel is the role of the Hawaii Pilots and vessel captains. Channel improvements could cause a change in behavior (e.g., faster transit through the entrance and two-way meeting) which could create new risks to the channel and port shutdown potential.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE:
There is limited historical record for port shutdowns resulting from vessel casualties. Predicting where and how a vessel casualty will occur and whether channel improvements change that risk involves significant uncertainty.

During tropical storms, the navigation channel is less likely to be the bottleneck to reopening the harbor than landside infrastructure. The incremental benefit of the proposed navigation improvements is very difficult to assess.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: The study will make assumptions regarding the performance of the project alternatives in terms of reduced shutdown days in the event of an emergency. There will be significant uncertainty related to how the actual project will perform in an actual event. Performance that is significantly worse than anticipated in the feasibility study presents a risk to operations in terms of the State and Federal Government's planned response to emergencies.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: High uncertainty associated with this evaluation will require scenario and sensitivity analysis to help describe the level of uncertainty associated with the performance of this improvements. The study also faces risk associated with authorization if the vertical team or technical review requires significant additional evidence gathering or rework.

PROJECT_NAME: Southwest Coastal Louisiana Nonstructural Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Non-fed Sponsor inability to provide funds
RISK_STATEMENT: State of Louisiana has a 35/65 cost-share with the Corps. All phases of current project actions would be impacted.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Project has been in works for several years now, with multiple, similar others upcoming that are also cost-shared with the non-federal sponsor. There is significant support and visibility from State and Federal leadership, likely to make this project a priority for funding.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Inability to acquire appropriate funding will impede award of Task Orders for multiple concurrent contracts, prohibiting screening and floodproofing of properties within Project scope.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Delay of geotechnical investigation to PED
RISK_STATEMENT: Reducing or delaying geotechnical investigation to PED will result in cost uncertainty and assumptions about soil and subsurface conditions that may or may not be conservative. The project area (especially offshore in the Ft Armstrong channel) is highly heterogeneous, with varying depths to bedrock, coral heads, and marine-deposited sediments. Onshore soil conditions at potential CSRM measure locations need to be quantified to develop reasonable understanding of the feasibility of proposed measures. For example, at locations where levees are proposed, an understanding of insitu soil permeability and depth to hard/impermeable layers is required to develop a design and assess risk and performance of a levee.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: At least a preliminary geotechnical investigation should be performed at all proposed CSRM measure and dredging locations to develop preliminary geotechnical assumptions.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Lack of a geotechnical investigation (or postponing the investigation entirely into PED) will require the designers to make assumptions about soils for design and cost estimating that may be incorrect. A limited geotechnical investigation in Feasibility will allow preliminary assumptions to be developed and reduce the risk but will not eliminate it.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Assigning a dollar value to cost impacts for geotechnical work is difficult as we don't know what we don't know. Having to perform additional geotechnical investigations during construction or addressing changed conditions claims during construction have significant cost implications.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Full geotechnical investigation during PED with a reduced/limited investigation in Feasibility will result in longer PED schedule, as the geotechnical program will have to be developed and performed. This process can take approximately 6 months. An insufficient geotechnical investigation during Feasibility results in lack of usable information in PED, which will result in potentially missing design milestones (e.g., 30%) and potentially require re-design of features.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: OSE Metric Acceptability and Application for Navigation
RISK_STATEMENT: The study will use multiple OSE metrics (e.g., reduced shutdown time) to evaluate the benefits of navigation improvements. This is a relatively novel methodology for feasibility studies for navigation at a major US port. There is risk associated with the study team's ability to assess the benefits of the study using these metrics and the ability to communicate the value of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The study team has completed significant literature review and initial analysis of the potential OSE benefits of navigation improvements. Results of this analysis have been presented to the vertical team, who requested additional analysis. Initial analysis revealed high uncertainty in this type of analysis and there is risk the study team will not be able to significantly improve the level of uncertainty associated with plan selection.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Given the high level of uncertainty associated with the performance of navigation improvements for this study, the ability of the study team and USACE to communicate the benefit of the project could create reputation risk. This is more likely the more abstract the OSE metric used for project justification.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impacts are mostly related to schedule delays associated with the need for additional work or rework to meet the needs of reviewers or the vertical team.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional analysis and/or meetings will require additional schedule time. This could include rework of the OSE analysis and/or more workshops with pilots and other stakeholders.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_STATEMENT: It is likely that an alternative plan with positive net NED benefits will not be identified. Previous NED analysis on deep draft navigation alternatives have shown that the costs of construction in Hawaii are high relative to potential cost savings from channel modifications. CSRM alternatives are likely to have low benefits relative to costs due to the limited number of permanent structures within Harbor property at risk of damage.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Large portions of the Harbor property are laydown area for cargo containers with a few administrative buildings.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: An NED waiver is expected and should be included as part of the project. Efforts should be made to expedite the waiver submission and approval to keep the study moving and avoid milestone slips.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional effort may be needed to capture benefits associated with reducing inundation risk to cargo containers and laydown areas. Coordination with POD and HQUSACE will be needed to submit an NED waiver.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Coordination with POD and HQUSACE to submit and approve an NED waiver could take up to 3 months.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Lack of required information/data would impact the development of the FWOP and analyses comparing the alternative plans. Lack of information would lead to the development of uninformed alternatives.  Study delay would increase costs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Collaborating frequently with the PDT on the information already collected and that which is required to inform the FWOP condition and alternatives development will minimize the likelihood of this event.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: This risk can be managed and mitigated through continuous data identification and collection as needed.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If event occurs, approximately 15 days would be needed to re-assess and collect required data.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Any additional sediment within the channel due to continued bank failure or sedimentation within creek may change flow characteristics of the channel affecting accuracy of the models. May result in more sediment to remove from the channel or a change in the floodplain bench elevation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: New land uses within the basin causing increase in imperviousness may result in higher storm flows or structures within the floodplain.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Increase in impervious regions is 0.2% in the past two years in the study area, and predicted doubled population by 2040 indicates that imperviousness will increase.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_NAME: Using Existing Grid from 2001 for Sub-Basins
RISK_STATEMENT: Sub-basins within Eagle Creek were delineated using a 50-ft hydro-corrected grid developed from the LiDAR data collected between January and March 2001. Basins were delineated with an average size of approximately 10 sq mi. This risks not capturing all flood risks and damages if data is not current and accurate, which may have the implication of the measures/alternatives not addressing the actual conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: 1. Unsteady flow models are more physically correct. They use the unsteady flow St. Venant equations, which better represent real-world hydraulic behavior. 2. Steady-flow models are simpler to calibrate and execute. They are suitable for scenarios where flow rates are relatively stable. In steady-flow modeling, the flow conditions remain constant over time. It assumes that the flow rates do not change significantly during the analysis.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Uncertainties associated with different climate variables is  relevant to the accuracy hydrologic analysis. Increase in rainfall and extreme storm events directly impacts the hydrologic analysis
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: NA

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Not incorporating the tidal effects in to Hydraulic modeling may not represent true site conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Sensitivity analysis showed that the tidal effects are not infiltrating up into Eagle Creek within project lines.

PROJECT_NAME: Southwest Coastal Louisiana Nonstructural Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Compliance with building codes and regulations
RISK_STATEMENT: Project team must ensure contractor design plans specs adhere to local regulations that apply to location, floodplain, type of floodproofing, etc. Failure to do so could result in revoked permits at best and failure of the floodproofing, at worst.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Hired contractors will be from the local area with significant experience in floodproofings in the region. USACE construction reviewers will also be checking lift and floodproofing plans for relevant regulatory adherence. However, the quantity of documents for review may allow minor oversights to slip through.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Failure to adhere to local regulations could require removal and re-constructing of floodproofing measures and reapplication of permits.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Restarting construction could lead to significant delays and slippage on not only the affected properties but other, less extensive delays others reliant on limited equipment resource availability.

PROJECT_NAME: Southwest Coastal Louisiana Nonstructural Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_STATEMENT: The Project is meant to manage coastal storm risks to local properties, but these same storms could pose challenges to timely and cost-effective Project completion.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Strong storm events are common in the region, especially during April-October extended hurricane season
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Will likely only affect the few properties that are in construction progress, but may limit overall project benefits by removal of formerly eligible properties.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: The properties in construction phase would likely require repairs to damaged portions upon storm conclusion, adding to the cost per property for those items. Properties still within the floodplain without floodproofing may be damaged to the point of removal from project consideration, reducing overall project costs but limiting benefits.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Storms do not typically last long, but recovery following the event may take as much as two months due to impacted supply chains and utilities.

PROJECT_NAME: Southwest Coastal Louisiana Nonstructural Coastal Storm Risk Management Project
RISK_NAME: Unforeseen changes or project scope changes
RISK_STATEMENT: Unknown site conditions, items of concern discovered during construction implementation, and other unforeseen issues (i.e. environmental, cultural, HTRW) that could expand project scope, schedule, and budget.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Extensive property screenings will take place prior to construction to address as many of these potential pitfalls as possible. However, there may be issues that are not visible or known until the residential property's foundation is revealed or other infrastructure beneath the home itself.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Items required to be addressed prior to residential structure elevations could impact the overall Project Participation Agreement and property owners' requirement to fulfill their obligation to repair such potential issues. Severe, late-discovery deficiencies may also remove the property from Project participation in a less-than-ideal timeline.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: These issues would impact individual properties' construction and would not halt overall process on the Project and remaining structures.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Public Response to Study and Proposed Improvements
RISK_STATEMENT: There is concern that the public, especially adjacent landowners and neighboring communities, that may be directly affected by the project are not adequately notified or provided adequate opportunity to provide study input. Public response to federal and state government projects is always an uncertainty that as of recent has been heightened within the context of revived anti-government sentiments throughout the State of Hawaii.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Public meetings for the navigation portion of the study held to date have not indicated that the study or recommended project are likely to generate significant public backlash. However, the PDT must be mindful of recent public opposition to other USACE projects in close proximity to the study area.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional public meetings may be required if there is indication that the CSRM measures could be controversial.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: This risk is unlikely to negatively impact the schedule. Additional public outreach could be accomodated within the existing schedule.

RISK_STATEMENT: The study will use multiple OSE metrics (e.g., reduced shutdown time) to evaluate the benefits of navigation improvements. This is a relatively novel methodology for feasibility studies for coastal storm risk management at a major US port. There is risk associated with the study team's ability to assess the benefits of the study using these metrics and the ability to communicate the value of the project.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: The study team has completed significant literature review and initial analysis of the potential OSE benefits of coastal sotrm risk management measures at Honolulu Harbor.  Initial analysis revealed high uncertainty in this the ability of the PDT to capture social benefits of CSRM alternatives and there is risk the study team will not be able to significantly improve the level of uncertainty associated with plan selection.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Given the high level of uncertainty associated with the performance of navigation improvements for this study, the ability of the study team and USACE to communicate the benefit of the project could create reputation risk. This is more likely the more abstract the OSE metric used for project justification
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Cost impacts are mostly related to schedule delays associated with the need for additional work or rework to meet the needs of reviewers or the vertical team
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Additional analysis and/or meetings will require additional schedule time. This could include rework of the OSE analysis and/or more workshops with HDOT and other stakeholders.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Delay of VTAM and Funding Approval
RISK_STATEMENT: There is a risk that the VTAM requesting the schedule and budget for the rescoped DDN/CSRM study will not be approved in a timely manner. Should the VTAM and release of funds take longer than anticipated, the PDT may run out of funds and the study may have to be paused until funding is released.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is a history of POH projects having to be paused based on failure to have policy exceptions and funding requests approved in a timely manner.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: Delays in completion of the feasibility study could result in reputational for the USACE and strain relationships with local partners.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: It is not known how long approval of VTAM and funding could take. 6 months of delay is included as a high-end estimate.

PROJECT_NAME: Honolulu Deep Draft Harbor Modifications Feasibility Study
RISK_NAME: Geotechnical Survey Contract Estimates Come in High
RISK_STATEMENT: Geotechnical investigations is planned to executed as work-in-kind using the Sponsor's contracting. Previous negotiations with the Sponsor's contractors have resulted in contract costs as high as 3 times the IGE.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: While previous rounds of negotiations have resulted in high cost estimates from the contractor, the current geotechnical investigation scope and budget is based on unit costs from the last round of negotiations, Therefore, it is unlikely that a cost estimate higher than the IGE.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: Previous geotechnical investigation estimates from the contractor have come a three times the IGE. While it is unlikely that the estimates will come in high, an impact equal to the current geotechnical investigation scope is included as a high-end figure.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: An additional 3 months is included to account for additional rounds of negotiation and coordination with the sponsor and vertical team.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Implementation guidance and examples for implementing comprehensive benefits to recommend a selected plan is still being developed. Since NED justification leans towards more valuable property, Comp Benefits/OSE potentially only path to reduce flood risk in underserved communities. Lack of real-world USACE studies justified on CB/OSE may make convincing decision-makers to approve non-traditional/non-NED plans for authorization. While this approach is relatively new given the CB Memo of Jan 21, meetings and discussions tend to lean towards looking at "economics" outside of the traditional financial-only purview. However, no idea how to predict Administration/OMB acceptance of BCRs not based solely on monetary conditions.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: This risk is likely due to the expected low BCR and the potential for integrating comprehensive benefit considerations.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Homes may have been built in floodplain after the 1991 cutoff as described in Section 308 Flood Plain Management, Public Law 101-640. Benefits are not allowed to be calculated for structures that were built after July 1, 1991 with a FFE below the 100-year floodplain BFE. Benefits may be reduced as a result of this, which would affect NED benefits.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: A few homes were constructed after July 1, 1991. The benefits that could be achieved for these structures have been removed appropriately.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study
RISK_STATEMENT: Study area may contain hazardous material sites, which would cause study delay and increased costs for hazardous material excavation and investigation.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: Desktop investigation of EPA clean up sites, etc. does not indicate HTRW sites in the area.

PROJECT_NAME: Eagle Creek Section 205 Flood Risk Management Study

PROJECT_NAME: Chesapeake Bay Oyster Recovery Program, Tangier-Pocomoke Sound
RISK_STATEMENT: The Chesapeake Bay Oyster Program authority is limited to $100M Federal. As of 2024, we have approximately $17M left in the authority with $13.8M at the District available for this project. If we are to achieve a portion of the goals as described in the 2012 USACE Master Plan which sets forth the goal of restoring approximately 3,900 acres in the Tangier-Pocomoke Sound we will need an increase in project authority. USACE cannot lobby for funds but we will need to develop a project scope and cost estimate to understand how much money it will take to achieve these goals. The risk would be that we do not get enough of an authorization increase to achieve the Master Plan goal which is the basis for our Decision Document. We will have enough to construct the nearshore reefs but this risk is solely to describe the risk associated with constructing the harvest/sanctuary reefs.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: There is currently a $20M authorization increase proposed in the Senate WRDA24 bill, however this is not guaranteed to pass through. Even if the $20M is authorized we would still need more (exact amount TBD during cost estimate preparation).
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If no increase in authorization is received, the project would end up being much smaller in scope and only construct the nearshore reefs. The goal of the project is to construct a network of nearshore/sanctuary/harvest reefs to provide a boost in the ecological benefits as well as economic benefits for the watermen community.
COST_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: For the initial first contract, which is proposed to be the nearshore reefs there would be no cost impact as we will have the funds available to award. However, the offshore reefs would be at risk for construction without the increased authority. If we receive the proposed $20M that might be enough to construct a few select sites, if we receive $50M we'd likely be able to construct the majority of the sanctuary and a portion of the harvest, if we receive $80M we'd be able to likely construct the entire reef network. These cost estimates are assumptions and will be revised upon receipt of the cost working estimate.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: If there is no authorization increase, the project would not continue to construct the harvest/sanctuary reef network until the money is appropriated. We would have to wait for WRDA26 for the next opportunity to increase the program authority.

PROJECT_NAME: Chesapeake Bay Oyster Recovery Program, Tangier-Pocomoke Sound
RISK_STATEMENT: A PPA needs to be executed on time in order to stick to schedule.
PROB_OCCURRENCE_EVIDENCE: PPA execution always has delays due to the language or signatories.
PERFORMANCEIMPACT_DESC: If a PPA isn't executed the project cannot be constructed.
SCHEDULE_IMPACT_EVIDENCE: PPA execution with VMRC specifically has seen delays of approximately 8 months.
